page_texts.5:
Foreword
In the Name of Him Who Has No Name
The book that passes before the eyes of the esteemed reader is a book on geography along with the wonders of the world, which was written in the year 748 AH by an unknown author for Amīr Mubāriz al-Dīn Muḥammad (713-759), from the Āl-e Muẓaffar dynasty. Several copies of this book are available. The author first learned of a copy in the Tabrīz Library, which is a relatively old copy. He requested a photograph of it from Dr. Yaḥyá Māhyār Nawābī, who at that time was the head of the Faculty of Literature at the University of Tabrīz. The burden of this effort fell upon Dr. Kāẓim, who at that time was engaged in teaching in the Geography Department of the Faculty of Literature of Tabrīz. He prepared a photograph of the copy and brought it to Tehran himself and handed it over to the author. Gratitude for this is obligatory upon this servant. From this copy, the original text was prepared and compared with copies from the National Library of Tehran, Paris, and Russia, which were old, and it was prepared for publication.
that
Wadi'i
The compared text was reviewed by the head of the Bonyād-e Farhang-e Īrān - Mr. Dr.
Khanlarī. He gave permission for it to be published in the series of books of Bonyād-e Farhang-e Īrān. I have great thanks and gratitude for his attention.
The work of comparing the copies and comparing the printed forms with the corrected text was done with the help of

page_texts.7:
Introduction

Title of the Book

Storey, when describing the manuscripts of this book, initially called it “Ṣuwar al-aqālīm” and put a question mark in front of this name, which shows that he himself had doubts and uncertainties in this naming.

Blochet, in his description of the Āṣafīyah manuscript, has named this book, quoting from that catalogue, “Majmūʿah-i rubʿ-i maskūn-i Aflāṭūn”.

In the Īvānūf catalogue, this book is called “Ṣuwar al-aqālīm”.

In the publication of the Central Library of Tehran University, this book is known as “Haft Kishwar” and “Sharḥ-i aqālīm al-sabʿah”.

At the end of the India Office copy, the scribe has named this book “Ṣuwar al-aqālīm”.

page_texts.8:
Twelve

In the Tabrīz copy, the name of this book is “Haft Kishwar”.

The Seven Countries

In the Paris copy, this book is called “Ṣuwar al-aqālīm” or “ʿAjāʾib al-Buldān”, and in its introduction in the film of the Central Library of the University, it is written: “The Ṣuwar al-aqālīm copy belongs to Paris, composed by the wise Plato.”

In the Leningrad Library catalogue, it is known as “Ṣuwar al-aqālīm sabʿah”, and on the first page of this copy, it is called “Haft Iqlīm”.

In the catalogue of handwritten books of the National Library, this book is introduced as “a book on geography” and is given number 626, but on the back of the first page of the book, in old handwriting, this book is called “Misāḥat-i Iskandar”, and on a paper that has been glued to the page, this book is called “Juġrāfīyā” and its author is considered to be “Aflāṭūn”. With the various names that the owners of the copies, scribes, and cataloguers have given to this book, we could not find its original name, so we chose the two names “Haft Kishwar” and “Ṣuwar al-aqālīm” for this book.

On this basis,

Value of the Book

The present book is a book on geography in which the wonders of the world are also described. The division of the inhabited quarter, which they knew until that time, into seven climes, took place in two ways: either the climes were circular, meaning that the land of Iran was in a circle in the center and six other climes around it, so that each of these circles was tangent to the other and tangent to the central circle. Then they showed the seven climes in the length of the world. That is, they would come up a few degrees from the equator and draw a line across the world; this was the first clime. The other climes were also located in proportion to the equator along the length of the world, up to the seventh clime, which is the inhabited area below the North Pole. Film no. 3108, Central Library of Tehran University.

Storey, vol. 2, p. 131. 9 Film no. 758, Central Library of
Tehran University

10 Leningrad Library copy, no. 11 253 A

page_texts.9:
Introduction
Thirteen
north reaches. The seven climes in this manuscript are such that the author begins with the east of the first clime and proceeds to describe it westward. Then he describes the second and third climes and the other climes. The Persian geographical book, Ḥudūd al-ʿĀlam min al-Mashriq ilā al-Maghrib, which was written in the year 372, exactly 376 years before this book, has the same classification.

The difference between these two books is that Ḥudūd al-ʿĀlam is a book whose author has not stepped outside the bounds of geographical topics. Whereas the author of the Haft Kishvar, when he comes to the major cities of each country, writes a description of the wonders and rarities,
some of which he has seen and most of which he has heard.

Most of these wonders are outside the normal course of nature, and today they cannot be accepted and believed, such as a spring from which elixir is secreted, or masses of bird eggs that have become large white domes, or the manner of ostrich egg-laying, or amber wax from honey bees, or a baby rhinoceros emerging from its mother's womb and eating grass, or a whale which is an animal that has one hole in its body, and that is its mouth, or fish eggs becoming locusts on land and fish in water, or a woman conceiving from a tree, or a crowd of musicians who bring ants out of a box with the sound of drums and set them to fight, or a description of the excessive obesity of Egyptian women¹¹, or a worm that, when kicked, makes a jug of water big¹², or hearing the sound of the spheres that comes from the rubbing of the spheres against each other¹³, or continuous circular motion¹⁴, and the like.

page_texts.10:
Fourteen
Haft Kishvar
In contrast to these incredible wonders, he gives a description of other wonders and topics that are very accurate and scientific and lack nothing of today's knowledge. Such as the description he gives about silkworms¹⁵ and honey mines¹⁶, or the statement he makes about the connection between the evening twilight and the true dawn¹⁷, or the description he writes about the twenty-three-hour and twenty-four-hour days¹⁸, or the explanation he gives about the six months of night and six months of day at the pole¹⁹, or the guess he makes about the existence of the American continent²⁰, or the news he gives us about the author's eyeglasses²¹ which is apparently the oldest
information about this.

Kraczkowski wrote the following description of this book in his book Arabic Geographical Literature²²:

Persian geographical writings increased in the fourteenth century (eighth Hijri). For example, someone named Muḥammad ibn Yaḥyā²³ wrote a book that was called Ṣuwar al-Aqālīm al-Sabʿa in several cases, but it did not always have this name²⁴. This

Therefore, the author of the Haft Kishvar should not be the Ṣuwar al-Aqālīmī, which was written and completed in Kermān for Amīr Mubāriz al-Dīn Muḥammad.

page_texts.11:
Introduction
Fifteen
The book was completed by its author in the city of Kermān²⁵ and presented to Amīr Mubāriz al-Dīn Muḥammad (713-759), who was one of the Muẓaffarid amirs. A copy of this global geographical book is among the manuscripts of the Soviet Union. The chapters of this book, according to the description of the Russian orientalist Zalman²⁷ and from the article of the French orientalist Huart, are as follows:

The first chapter is about the generalities of geography, and the second chapter is divided into seven sections according to the arrangement of the seven climes. Rieu's judgment about the contents of this book, which has pointed to its brevity and disruptiveness and considered it full of myths, superstitions and children's tales, is harsh and hasty.²⁸ This book is full of fresh material about northern Iran, and "Dorn" has come across this point, and it has a great deal of valuable information about Africa, the source of which is Arabic geographical books, the originals of which have not reached us."

Some of the vocabulary of this book has an old recording and is worthy of investigation and study. Among them are:

12/18 - ḫirʿitābī: Zebra.
13/18 - manj: Honey bee.
10/29 - hamshīrah: Two people who are breastfed at the same time.
918/46- There is something like a turnip that the Arabs call kamʾah and the Persians kahar and the Khorasanians samārūgh. Apparently, it is the same thing that is called donbalān in Tehran today.

page_texts.12:
Sixteen

The Seven Climes

18/51 - The word "morgh" (مرغ) in the past, besides meaning bird, was also used to mean butterfly. In 1360, that morgh is called "zurzūr" (زرزور) in Arabic, "sār" (سار) in Persian, and some call it "Kāsīneh Kord" (کاسینه کرد).

18/67 - Three hundred and thirty *qaṣabeh* (قصبه) equals seven *qafīz* (قفيز). 12/69 *Pāyāb* (پایاب) means a hole that is made with a slope in the ground to access water or minerals.

This book is a small volume, and reading it is not without benefits. Its contents are not uniform, and there are many correct and incorrect points in it. However, it is an engaging book and indicative of the general understanding and beliefs of the time it was written.

Map and Table of the Book

The *Haft Kishvar* (هفت کشور) book apparently came with a map that has not reached us. The author says in the introduction of the book: "This humble servant, who has long been devoted to serving and supporting *Mobārez al-Donyā wa al-Dīn Mohammad* (مبارز الدنيا والدين محمد), and has been regarded by that gentleman with consideration and mercy, desired to draw a plan of the inhabited quarter for his library and to bring together in a composition a summary of what is known about the world.”²²

Again, in the first chapter of the same book, he writes: "And we have divided the seven *aqālīm* (اقالیم) and what lies south of the equator in latitude and longitude into two-degree sections, and we have drawn a table and written the names of some famous cities that we knew, so that it may be known what relation each city has to another, and in what condition it is, and in which clime it falls. And there are many cities that we do not know, for it has become known that there are nearly four thousand cities in the areas and surroundings of Khitā and Khotan (ختا وختن), and only a few of their names have reached us.”²³

In this map, apparently, the names of cities that were in Arabic before the author's time and were called in Greek in his time have been recorded. He writes in

²² Ibid., p. 4

²³ Ibid., p. 7.
page_texts.13:
Introduction

India

this regard: "And the names of other cities have been established in Arabic and are now known in the language of the Greeks."²⁴

In addition to this map, this book also had a table in which the author had drawn the summer and winter paths of the sun and moon with different lines. The author writes about this: "And we have drawn two lines for example, and from this line of the sun's descent, which passes towards the zenith, to that other line, which is the moon's descent, is about one hundred and twenty *farsangs* in width."²⁵

It is in this table that the difference in the hours of day and night, from the equator, where these two are equal, to the last point of the pole, which is six months of night and six months of day, has been shown by the author with different lines. It is likely that this table was combined with the map. It is a great pity that this map and table do not appear in the existing copies.

Author of the Book

We do not have enough information about the author of this book, but it is clear that he spent some time in Kerman and has long been devoted to serving and supporting *Amir Mobārez al-Dīn Mohammad* (امیر مبارزالدین محمد) (713-759 AH).⁶² This sultan is from the *Āl-e Moẓaffar* (آل مظفر) dynasty, which conquered Kerman in 741 AH and Fars in 754 AH, and his son *Shāh Shojāʿ* (شاه شجاع) deposed him in Isfahan in 760 AH. The author wrote this book in his name in 748 AH. The author traveled to Hormuz and conducted studies on the coast of Hormuz. He mentions a mollusk from which China takes its ink, calling it a fish, and writes: “On the coast of Hormuz, it was observed that an animal had caught a creature that was like a wide shield and had a thin and long tail, like a rope tied to the edge of a shield, and had two wide eyes in the middle of its back, and its mouth was in the middle of its stomach and in the lower half.”²⁷

²⁴ Ibid., p. 119

²⁶ Ibid., p. 4.

²⁵ Ibid., p. 21

²⁷ Ibid., pp. 50, 519
page_texts.14:
Eighteen

The Seven Climes

And about the sawfish, he writes: "There is another creature in the sea that has something long growing from its head that has long teeth on both sides, and the *qalandars* (قلندران) hold it in their hands, and that creature sometimes attacks ships and strikes the ship and breaks it, and if someone is in the water and rises up, it strikes their waist and kills them."²⁸

On the same coast of Hormuz, the author saw and studied many creatures. In this regard, he writes, "And on the coast of Hormuz, we saw a hundred thousand species, large and small, that had been shed."²⁹

The author sat on a ship from the coast of Hormuz and saw other creatures. About this trip, he writes, "And we boarded a ship in Hormuz and saw a creature that was extremely white and had gathered in large numbers, and their heads were like wide hats, and their bodies grew from the middle, so that the surroundings were empty, and when they fell on the board, they died immediately."³⁰

The author also traveled to the province of Fars and other provinces. He writes: "For we observed in the province of Fars and several other provinces that black clay is brought from the mine and placed in a crucible and melted, and the essence of iron is separated from it."³¹

We see the author once on the road between Hamadan and Baghdad. He writes about this: "And on the road between Hamadan and Baghdad, on the south side, a spring of sulfur was witnessed that came out like a stream of milk and solidified."²

²²

Apparently, the author traveled to Baghdad by the same route and spent some time there. About this trip, he writes, "We have seen a lot in Baghdad and other cities that when a dump is filled, they pour lime into it and burn it, and what remains becomes stone and clay."³³

The author is a man of books and study and knowledgeable in astronomy. The explanation he gives about the stars *abadi al-khafī* (ابدی الخفی) and *abadi al-ẓohūr* (ابدی الظهور), and the calculation he made about the rising and setting of the star *Suhail* (سهیل) in Kerman and Fars, is sufficient evidence of his astronomical knowledge.

²⁸, ²⁹, and ³⁰ Ibid., p. 51 ³¹- Ibid., p. 43

³²- Ibid., p. 35

³³ Ibid., p. 43.
page_texts.15:
Introduction
Nineteen
His astronomical knowledge. ³⁴

The author also has information about the science of Tafsir. He has written this explanation and interpretation about one of the famous verses of كلام الله مجید. Several branches of the Nile's water, which is sweet, flow into the sea, strike the sea, and go out, and do not mix with each other until they join the city of Alexandria and the sea of ​​France, and the verse « مرج البحرين يلتقيان بينهما بررخ لایبقیان » which the commentators do not know for sure, and God Almighty has mentioned in the Quran that these are two seas.

Its introduction is like the two copies described, and at the end it is written: Six months are day and six months are night والله اعلم بالصواب The name of the scribe and the date of writing are not mentioned at the end.

This copy was part of the manuscripts of Nāṣir al-Dīn Shāh's library, and on top of the first page of the book is the large four-cornered, collared seal of Nāṣir al-Dīn Shāh with the inscription: «هوشاه شاهان ناصر الدین مهردر and the date 1270 can be read on it. page_texts.19:
Introduction

page_texts.35:
In the name of God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful
Praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds, and the (best) outcome is for the pious, and blessings and peace be upon the chief of the messengers, Muḥammad, and his family and companions, all of them. God, blessed and exalted, said: We will show them Our signs in the horizons and within themselves until it becomes clear to them that it is the truth.

To proceed: It is mentioned in histories that when Iskandar Faylafūs Rūmī reached the age of sixteen, by the command of God, glory be to Him, the ambition of world conquest spread in his heart. He sent to Aflāṭūn Ḥakīm, saying: I want you to draw for [me] a plan of the inhabited quarter of the world and the shapes and forms of the climes of the world, and inform me of some conditions and qualities of the horizons and regions of the world, so that I may become aware and gain knowledge, and so that you may befriend me and come to me, for indeed there is need for your presence.

Aflāṭūn drew a plan of the inhabited quarter of the world and sent Arisṭāṭālīs, who was the most learned of his students, in his place, and he became Iskandar's minister and began world conquest. This history was seven hundred and seventy years in the lunar calendar before the Hijra of the Messenger, may God bless him and his family and grant them peace. In a few years, he conquered most of the world, and
page_texts.36:
Haft Kishvar
What could not be achieved by armies, he conquered through wisdom.
Since this humble servant, out of sincere devotion in servitude and loyalty to His Highness of celestial eminence, the Lord, امیر اعظم, مالك رقاب الامم, مولى ملوك طوايف العرب والعجم, the Prince, Shāhzāda Shahryār Ghāzī, قهرمان الماء والطين, ظل الله في الارضين, المخصوص به عنایت رب العالمین, مبارز الحق والدنيا والدين, Muḥammad لازال مظفراً منصوراً على اعدائه و خلد الله ملکه, has long since bound his life [to this service], and through the nurturing attention and mercy of that presence, this servant has been favored:
he wished that for the library of that Presence, a map of the inhabited quarter be drawn, and whatever is known of the conditions of the world, a summary be expressed in prose; and if any statement appears wondrous, it be supported with an appropriate and reasonable account, and a few words from histories be cited as evidence according to the principle "العلام يجر العلام" so that it not be dismissed as conjecture, exaggeration, or impossibility, and that it be presented for review. تم بالخير ان شاء الله تعالى.
And this treatise has been arranged in two chapters:
Chapter One consists of two sections: Section One on the description of the earth and the measure of its dimensions and knowledge of the longitude and latitude of lands and the properties of places. Section Two on the description of the southern horizons and the equator وما يتعلق به وينسب اليه.
Chapter Two comprises seven sections: Section One on the description of the First Clime و ما ينسب اليه. Section Two on the description of the Second Clime. Section Three on the description of the Third Clime.
Section Four on the description of the Fourth Clime. Section Five on the description of the Fifth Clime. Section Six on the description of the Sixth Clime. Section Seven on the description of the Seventh Clime and the limit of habitation in the inhabited quarter from the northern side, and some places where the difference between day and night is great, and the uninhabited region beneath the celestial equator pole.
1 This phrase was added here from the Russian manuscript.
page_texts.37:
Chapter One of Section One
On the Description of the Earth and Its Measurement
God, exalted and glorified, created the earth spherical and covered approximately three-quarters of the earth, leaving one quarter exposed, and this quarter is called the inhabited quarter. The water of the Encompassing Ocean surrounds those other three quarters, and several seas that have entered upon the land are within the inhabited quarter, and deadly deserts and salt marshes and cold regions that have no habitation [also] are included within the inhabited quarter.
And the sphere of the earth is so large that it has been calculated by geometrical measurement that a mountain half a farsang in height, in proportion to the sphere of the earth, is an amount like the side of a barley grain that is divided into thirty-five parts, and if one part of it is placed on the surface of a sphere whose diameter is one girih, it is absolutely imperceptible that the sphere has lost its roundness.
Arshimīdis the sage measured the earth so that the measurement and size of the earth would become known, for without it the divisions of the celestial spheres and the size of the bodies of the sun and moon and other stars cannot be measured, and nothing can be known of them, and he found that
page_texts.38:
The Seven Climes
Each celestial degree amounts to twenty-two farsangs and one-seventh of a farsang, where one farsang equals three miles, one mile equals four thousand gaz, one gaz equals twenty-four fingers, and one finger equals six medium barley grains placed side by side. The scholars of Islam, in the time of the Caliph al-Maʾmūn, at his direction, in the desert of Sinjār—which is a plain with no mountains, rises, or depressions—faced the North Pole and measured the altitude of the star called al-Jadī with an instrument, and surveyed the earth, finding one celestial degree to be twenty-two farsangs and one-ninth of a farsang, which has a small difference from the measurement that the sage Archimedes made. Since each part of the earth corresponds to a part of the celestial sphere, and the celestial sphere is three hundred and sixty degrees, the earth must also be taken as three hundred and sixty degrees. When we multiplied by twenty-two farsangs and a fraction, it came to eight thousand farsangs, and this is the circumference of the terrestrial sphere. The diameter of the earth is two thousand five hundred and forty-five farsangs, and the total surface of the terrestrial sphere is twenty thousand thousand and three hundred and sixty square farsangs. The surface of the inhabited quarter from the equator to beneath the North Pole is five thousand thousand and ninety farsangs. The area of the Seven Climes with their seas, valleys, mountains, and deserts up to the complete obliquity, which is the limit of the world's habitation, is three thousand thousand seven hundred and fifty-six thousand four hundred and twenty farsangs. That which is outside the Seven Climes to the north, where there is no habitation, vegetation, or animal life, is one thousand thousand three hundred and thirty-three thousand five hundred and eighty farsangs. Since the length of the inhabited quarter is half of the terrestrial sphere, from the farthest east to the farthest west it is four thousand farsangs.
.
1 - In the original with "degree," the word "each" was added from the Russian manuscript. 2 Original: wādī. Corrected from the Russian manuscript.
page_texts.39:
Chapter One
Y
Since in the inhabited quarter they observe that from the northern direction the pole of the celestial equator is elevated, they call the inhabited quarter the northern horizons. And from the other side of the equator where the southern pole is visible [and] the northern pole is setting, they have found land and settlements to the extent of sixteen degrees, and that is outside the seven climes. The southern latitude of those places amounts to three hundred and fifty-six farsangs, and its length from east to west amounts to approximately four thousand farsangs.
.
The origin of the longitude of cities is taken from the beginning of the western settlements, which they call the Fortunate Islands (Jazīra Khālidāt), and in ancient times it was inhabited and now it is submerged. The sages of India take the beginning of longitude from the farthest east, a place they call Kangdiz. And the beginning of latitude is agreed upon from the equator, where day and night are always equal, and [around] ² the celestial sphere is biaxial, and in the oblique horizons, both northern and southern, the celestial sphere becomes like a shoulder-belt, and under the pole [it becomes millstone-like, and at the equator both poles are on the northern and southern horizon]. And we have divided the seven climes and whatever has southern latitude beyond the equator by two degrees of longitude and latitude, and we have drawn tables and written the names of some famous cities whose names we knew, so that it becomes known what relation each city has with another city and in what situation it is and in which clime it falls. And many of the cities are such that even we have not known them, for it has become known that approximately four thousand cities are in the regions and surroundings of Khitā and Khotan, and little of their names has reached us. And also each city has several towns, villages, and farmlands, and dependencies and annexes, the knowledge of which is not possible for anyone, except the dependencies of a city or places of a kingdom that can be known, which in relation to the inhabited quarter
1- Original: zamīn ʿimārat. Corrected from the Russian manuscript.
2- The word "dawr" was added from the Russian manuscript. This section was added from the Russian manuscript.
page_texts.40:
A
small
The Seven Climes
it would be. By estimation we have determined that daily approximately five hundred and fifty thousand people must come into existence from non-existence and pass from existence into non-existence. If in a region of the inhabited quarter a plague or famine or massacre occurs and people perish without limit, when distributed across the entire world, it would be small. And also the celestial decree by the command of God Almighty is such that if in one region plague or massacre occurs, in another region there would be abundance and security, and never would any calamity be universal such that it reaches all the people of the world,
except the Flood, which would be the Day of Resurrection.¹
Anecdote
The sages say that since the celestial equator circle with the circle of the ecliptic—which are two great circles of the starless sphere and the sphere of fixed stars—diverge from each other by twenty-three and a half degrees, from this proportion that some of the earth has emerged from the surrounding ocean and become exposed, it must be that another quarter opposite this quarter, whose horizons' latitudes are southern, should be inhabited. For if two circles are drawn, each having a center and intersecting at two opposite points, certainly inclination occurs from both sides. And since the inhabited quarter exists due to the inclination of the ecliptic from the celestial equator, another quarter must be inhabited and there must be another world. When it is day for us, it is night for them, and vice versa; when it is spring for us, it is autumn for them, and vice versa; our west is their east and vice versa. They say that once the king of the West, before the Fortunate Islands [جزایر خالدات] were submerged, conceived the desire to know what lies beyond this sea. He appointed several men to board a ship and sail forth to see where they would arrive and what they would see. When
.
1. Manuscript "م" does not have the phrase "except the Flood, which would be the Day of Resurrection."
"
page_texts.41:
Chapter One
"
After several days they went on and saw another ship coming from that direction. They sailed close to each other and questioned one another, but neither side knew the other's language. Through context and gestures they made their story known—the objective of both was the same. So if this is true, it indicates that another quarter of the terrestrial globe is opposite this inhabited quarter, and our west is their east, and their east is closer to our west than other directions, and the sea distance would be less—wa Allāh aʿlam.
Now then, we said that every part of the parts of the earth corresponds to a part [of] the celestial sphere, and several thousand fixed stars that God Almighty created in the regions of the eighth sphere—
and
each star of these passes over the zenith of some people and place, and the rotation of the spheres and the motion of the wandering and fixed stars appear in a different configuration at each place on earth. Thus each place on earth has a particular property, and the form, appearance, custom, way, language, and terminology of every people and nation differ. Due to their difference in relation to the celestial equator, it is possible that at every place on earth a total change may occur, such as ruin and prosperity, and the customs and conduct of people, and so forth. And the cause of change, by the command of God Most High, may be that a star whose passage is not at the zenith may come to pass at the zenith, or a star that rises and sets may become perpetually invisible, or a star that is perpetually invisible may come to rise and set.
For example, Nasr Wāqiʿ (Vega), which at this time—the date being the year 748 from the Hijra of the Messenger—is rising and setting in the vicinity of Khurāsān and ʿIrāq. There may be a time
1. Manuscript "M": that a star whose passage is at the zenith may have its passage fall away from the zenith, or a star whose passage is not at the zenith may come to the zenith. 2. Manuscript "M": "būd" instead of "uftad". This section was added from manuscript "M"
page_texts.42:
10
Haft Kishwar
that it becomes perpetually visible, and at this time Nasr Wāqiʿ, which is in the sign of Capricorn, in Bulghār and the regions at the end of the sixth and seventh climes is completely perpetually visible, and like Banāt al-Naʿsh it does not rise and set. And when it reaches the sign of Aquarius, in Khurāsān and Ādharbāyjān the same condition will occur. And when it comes to the signs of Pisces and Aries, in ʿIrāq and Fārs and Kirmān it will also rise and set, and until the sign of Cancer, which is at one hundred [degrees], it becomes perpetually visible this way down to the first clime. And when it reaches the beginning of Gemini until the end of the sign of Cancer, in Makka and Ḥijāz it was perpetually visible.
Another is the star Suhayl, which at this date in Kirmān and Fārs is rising and setting. When approximately three thousand years pass from the Hijra of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, it will become perpetually hidden and cease to rise and set. And when such a sign occurs for a fixed star, a comprehensive condition will appear among that people and in that place, and several matters will undergo change, and the saying of the Most High: «ويتفكرون في خلق السمواتِ والارض ربنا ما خلقت هذا باطلاً سُبْحَانَكَ فَقِنَا عَذَابَ النَّارِ»
Now then, they have divided the inhabited quarter into seven sections, and each section they call a clime. In the first and second climes there is no cold, and no one] has seen snow and ice, and in the sixth and seventh climes up to the limit of habitation, despite the long summer days, the air is neither hot nor pestilential. And if there is heat and cold in these four climes that we mentioned, it is relative to the climates of that place. And in the third, fifth, and fourth climes there are both hot lands and cold lands, and the form and appearance and capability and strength and manliness and valor and courage and management of livelihood and luxuries of the people were better and more than in these other three climes. Especially several cities that are in the middle of the longitude
1 From here onward one line has fallen out of the Russian manuscript and does not appear in the photograph.
2 The word "kas" was added here from the Russian manuscript
.
page_texts.43:
Chapter One
11
and around the سرة الأرض (Navel of the Earth), the peoples of these regions [were] of loftier ambition and fewer would place the yoke of servitude upon their necks, for the influence of planetary stars in the center of the inhabited quarter is greater and stronger. After that, in the western half in the third, fourth, and fifth climes, settlements and populations were proportionally greater than in other climes,
and the people of the first clime due to heat and burning, and the people of the seventh clime due to cold and rawness, are of low ambition and beast-like nature and lacking in prudence, especially those born in the furthest eastern regions.

Among the special properties of the earth, one is that every emanation that descends from the rotation and movement of the celestial spheres and stars by the command of God Most High—"يدبر الأمر من السماء الى الارض" (He directs the affair from heaven to earth)—terminates at the earth, for the body of the earth is the center of the universe and the lowest of the four elements. Thus, according to the receptivity of each location, something different takes form, and since celestial configurations and positions are infinite, various compositions are also without limit. Indeed, the earth is the world of generation and corruption.

And another property of the earth is that the four elements, which are simple, through the influence of the celestial spheres and stars by the command of God Most High, intermingle with each other on the surface of the earth. For if it were not so, no composition would take form and no temperaments would appear, and there is no pure earth, wind, water, or fire on the surface of the earth. [Rather,] whichever of the four elements one may conceive, particles of other elements are with it, for the absolutely simple does not have that form and nature. And if a form were required, it would be spherical, just as [if] a piece is thrown into the air, when it comes down it becomes round and spherical. For example, fire that

2- The manuscript does not have "زمین". 3- The word "بلکه" was added from the Russian manuscript.
4)
The word
