page_texts.44:
12
Haft Kishwar
flames on the surface of the earth, and its place is earthy particles, and its color is airy, and its tongue is fiery. When a piece of paper is held over the tip of the flame, the heat of that fire sets it in motion]. Furthermore, air that freezes and becomes harder and firmer than what is possible to freeze—if a little warmth did not remain in it, all would become ice of one hardness. And if the four elements did not mix with one another and did not break each other's temperament so that the fifth temperament would emerge, no composition would take
form.
And the belief of the ancient sages is that when God Most High created the celestial and terrestrial worlds, He entrusted the terrestrial beings to the celestial ones and left them to them, for God Most High is [transcendent and] the Cause of all causes. As He said: «وبنينا فوقكم سبعا شدادا وجعلنا سراجاً وهاجاً وآخر لنا من المعصرات ماء فجاجا لتخرج به حبا ونباتا وجنات الفافا».
As for what lies beyond, the truly pure simple element exists outside the surface of the earth at a complete distance, and every simple part of the elements, spheres, and stars that is farther from the surface of the earth is stronger in simplicity. Just as the sphere of fire, which is three degrees farther from the surface of the earth, has greater power of simplicity, for whatever reaches it is immediately burned. And it is also from this meaning that the fire on the surface of the earth, despite having a temperament mixed with other elements, whatever comes into contact with it quickly becomes hot or is burned, unlike water and air [for if] something is placed in water and air, over the course of time it becomes like them. And the water of the Encompassing Sea, which has descended from the surface of the earth, is purely simple, and no creature takes form in it. That is, simple bodies, the farther from the surface of the earth
1- This section was added from the Russian manuscript. 2- The original and Paris manuscript have «گشت»; corrected according to the Russian manuscript.
page_texts.45:
Chapter One
the farther away they are, the stronger their power in simplicity becomes. For example, the philosophers have determined through experience that when the planetary stars are at perigee, their influence becomes weak, whereas since the ray of starlight is effective on earth, they should have become stronger because they have come closer to the earth by the measure of the diameter of the eccentric sphere and epicycle, which is the world of compounds.
[But] as for the inhabited quarter, from where the equator is, where night and day are always equal, up to sixty-six and a half degrees, which is the full obliquity and the limit of habitation, from the northern side they have divided it into seven parts and call them the Seven Climes. They have given the first clime more width because most of it is sea, and likewise the width of the second clime is greater than the other five climes because it is predominantly uninhabited deserts and harsh cold regions. And the length of the first clime from east to west is more than the second clime, and the second clime more than the third clime, and so on until the seventh. Because of the Encompassing Sea, the distance of land decreases. And God knows best.
1 - The Russian and Paris manuscripts have "and is" added after the word "ghashtandī".
page_texts.46:
Southern
Second Section of the First Chapter
[On] the description of the southern horizons and the equator
We said before that beyond the equator there are sixteen [degrees] of latitude horizons. And at the equator, night and day are always twelve hours, and the year has eight seasons: two springs, two summers, two autumns, and two winters. The celestial sphere revolves in two layers, and the sun at the beginning of Aries and Libra passes through the zenith, and it is summer when the altitude of the sun is ninety degrees. At the beginning of Cancer, the sun's altitude is sixty-six and a half degrees to the north, and the shadow falls to the south. At the beginning of Capricorn, the altitude is the same, and the shadow is cast to the north. These two times are the beginning of the two winters, and four seasons fall in the middle of these seasons.
And in the vicinity of the equator, the birth of many animals occurs, and various flowers, aromatic plants, vegetation, and trees are abundant. There are always flowers, blossoms, and greenery because the climate of the equator is the most temperate. And what lies on the equator is mostly sea that has risen to the surface of the inhabited quarter.
.. Now, after this, the first place in the southern horizons in the east, which is the shore of the sea
page_texts.47:
Chapter One
15
the Encircling Sea, there is a great mountain that extends from the coast and rises around the land, approximately three hundred farsangs in length and two hundred farsangs in width. On the western side of that mountain, it is open and water has entered it, becoming a sea. From the mountains and the [many] heights that are in the midst of the water, islands have [appeared], and on most of [those] islands there are human forms and other animals and various types of plants. Among them are the two islands of Wāq Wāq, where there is a tree from which something resembling a human head emerges, and from it comes the sound of "wāq wāq."
Beyond that there is another large island, and in its midst it has tall mountains. Every vapor that rises from those regions makes the air of those mountains thick, and most of the time it rains. That island is called the Island of Clouds, and on that island and mountain ]2 there are various types of plants and animals. Beside this island, to the south, is the Island of Dajjāl, and they say Dajjāl is on this island and cannot come out. The Messenger (peace be upon him) was asked about Dajjāl, and he said that he is bound on that island. A merchant who was present there said: "I have seen that place."
Beyond that, it is one hundred and fifty farsangs of land to the coast of a sea and a gulf that has extended from the Encircling Sea onto the land. There is a city near the coast called Khumdān, which has a prosperous region. A wide and deep water channel comes from the north, from the second clime, approximately five hundred farsangs, passes east of Khumdān, and joins the sea. They call it the River of Khumdān, and from the regions of Chīn and Khutan they come by ship on this River of Khumdān.
.
1 - Manuscript "M" does not have the phrase "and from it comes the sound of wāq wāq." 2 - This word was added from the Russian manuscript.
.
page_texts.48:
16
The Seven Climes
After that there are several other islands, and among them is a long island in the middle of a gulf where there are walnut trees and many other plants and it is inhabited [by people].¹ And there is an [extremely] large and long island whose length is nine hundred and some farsangs and its width is one hundred or one hundred and fifty to two hundred farsangs, and they call it the Island of ʿAmal, and it has many cities and a prosperous region, and there is breeding and reproduction of various animals and [growth of] trees and aromatic plants and flowers and pastures and meadows and beneficial mountains and abundant [flowing] waters, and there is a sea that has come from the Encompassing Ocean onto the land. There is an eastern gulf of this island and a western gulf, and the distance of the western gulf is greater, extending to the region of a city called Khaṭāṭ, and there is a great mountain that has rested its head there, and on the western side of this gulf there is a region and city called Wārāṭa, and from those mountains that have rested their heads there, flowing waters come and join the sea of the inhabited quarter.
Then there is another island. In this Island of ʿAmal, the equator [passes through]; some of that island is north of the equator and some is southern, within the Island of ʿAmal, and they call it the Island of Namkūt, and the width and length of this island is approximately one hundred and thirty or one hundred and fifty farsangs, and it is prosperous and inhabited, and in this island there are two wondrous things: one is that a tree grows whose fruit has a form in the shape of a human, and when it grows large and the outlines of its limbs become visible, before vegetative nurturing it desires food, and something like a gourd with two nipples that give milk appears, and from there it sucks milk until it gains strength. After that it breaks its navel from the tree and becomes wild and goes to the forest, and in height
¹ This word was added from the Russian manuscript.
was added from the Russian manuscript.
Russian manuscript: "Jamkūt".
The word "flowing" from the manuscript
page_texts.49:
Chapter One
larger than one cubit and its lifespan does not exceed one year.
17
And there is another worm which they call makanat, approximately one cubit
in length in the old measurement, and when it is cut into several pieces it does not die but moves and coils up until it becomes whole again. And if water is extracted from that worm by means of a gourd and alembic, whoever has a broken bone, if it is applied there, it will heal.
Beyond that, from the island of ʿUmal, there are Khaṭāṭa and Warāṭa and Safālīya extending to a city called Tūhīya, and the length of that region is approximately five hundred farsangs and its width is two hundred and fifty farsangs. In these districts there are mountains and flowing waters and meadows and flourishing deserts and abundant beneficial trees and plants, and great rivers flow and join the sea of the inhabited quarter. The mountains and stones of this region contain much gems and gold, but the people of that region do not know smelting and silver refining. They go and gather much firewood at the foot of the mountain and set fire to it until the stone softens and the gems and gold melt and fall amid the fire, then they collect them from among the ashes. These people are all black and fond of amusement and merriment, and the reason for this is that the elevation of the star called Suhayl reaches forty degrees [there] and rises as high as the star Shiʿrā does in Iraq and Khorasan, and the effect of the rays of Suhayl is cheerfulness, and whoever gazes upon it frequently, grief and sorrow find less way to him. The people of the island of ʿUmal and the lands of Safālīya and Zanj and the regions that we shall mention, extending to the farthest west and the vicinity of the equator, are mostly fond of merriment, amusement, and joy. In those regions Suhayl is not hidden for more than one month in the year, and Banāt al-Naʿsh al-Kubrā and al-Ṣughrā have rising and setting, and the duration of their concealment
page_texts.50:
18
Haft Kishvar
was beneath the earth more than above, and the stars ʿAyyūq, Nasr Wāqiʿ, and Simāk Rāmiḥ, which in Iraq and Khurasan reach the meridian, have little elevation in those regions, except for Jawzā and other stars around it that pass through the zenith.
In these places camels are scarce because the light of Suhayl diminishes camels.
Sandalwood
and
After that is the land of Zanj, and its beginning, which they call Mansiyya, extends to the bank of the Nile as it goes to Muqdishū and joins the sea. On the bank of the Nile of Muqdishū is the end of the land of Barbar, along with several other cities. From the city of Mansiyya to Barbar and the bank of the Nile of Muqdishū is approximately three hundred farsangs, and its width from the coast of the Encompassing Sea to the coast of the Sea of the Inhabited Quarter is two hundred and fifty farsangs. Like the lands and mountains of Sufāla, it contains stones, and on the coasts of the sea of these cities there is abundant ebony and brazilwood, and at all times ambergris is found from the sea. There are various animals and birds, especially elephants, leopards, giraffes, rhinoceros beetles, civet cats, monkeys, and rhinoceroses. In most of these mountains there are beehives, and the plains and meadows of this land are never devoid of flowers and fragrant plants. Civet is obtained from the civet cat: they catch the cat and set up a stick, tying the cat to that stick, and several times each day they give it milk. The cat circles around the stick and rubs itself against it, and civet secretes from its body onto the stick, from which they collect it.
After that is the district of Qamar, with a city and several places around it which they call Karsha. On the coast of the Encompassing Sea, a mountain extends toward the east
m
1 - From manuscript m and the Russian manuscript we added the word "around." 2 - Manuscript "m"
river of Muqdishū instead of Nile of Muqdishū.
.
Russian manuscript: ebony and oud.
Russian manuscript: city.
- manuscript
page_texts.51:
Chapter One
19
to the middle of the lands of Sufāliya is approximately one thousand four hundred farsangs, and various animals and plants exist in this mountain, and many running waters come down and join the sea of the inhabited quarter. The western side of this mountain is Jibāl Qamar, and several wide and deep water channels come from these Jibāl Qamar, which they call the Nile of Egypt, and two large lakes have appeared from this water, the area of these two lakes being one hundred farsangs by one hundred farsangs. A great mountain and a territory which they call az Qulla is to the west of the lake, and the water of the Nile passes from these two lakes and comes to the equator and becomes a sea that extends westward, passing approximately three hundred and fifty farsangs, and several branches of the Nile water, which is fresh, flow into the salty sea water and go out, and they do not mix with each other until reaching the city of Alexandria and
... ...
it joins the Frankish Sea, and the verse «مرج البحرين بالتقيان بينهما برزخ لا یبه میان»
which the commentators do not know for certain, and which God Almighty mentioned in the Quran, refers to these two seas.

And in the sea of the Nile of Egypt there are several creatures that we have not heard of in any other sea: qirsh and nahang and faras al-baḥr. As for the qirsh, it is an extremely large creature, several gaz in length and width, shaped like a frog, and has spots on it like colored shields, and it attacks ships, and travelers and passengers on ships are frightened, and they carry bait for it, and when the qirsh comes, they know from the movement of the water, and they throw bait in the water so that it becomes occupied with it. The father of Quraysh, either because of the many children he had, or because he had a strong body and stature, they had made his name in the diminutive form Quraysh.
1- Manuscript «m» has raqalla instead of az qulla, and in the Russian manuscript it is «rafla» and in the Paris manuscript it is also «rafla». 2- This line was added from the Russian manuscript. 3- Russian manuscript: tā hama mīr wa Iskandarīya; Paris manuscript «tā bahīr wa Iskandarīya».
page_texts.52:
The Seven Climes
As for the nahang (whale), it is a creature that has no other opening in its body except its mouth, and eating, excreting waste, and giving birth are all done through its mouth. When it gives birth on dry land, it becomes a saqanqūr (skink), and when it gives birth in water, it is a nahang, like a fish, for when fish spawn on the shore and [the eggs] fall among reeds or on dry ground and seawater does not reach them and the sun shines upon them, they become māḫ. When the eggs are cast upon water, they become fish.
As for the faras al-baḥr (hippopotamus), it is an exceedingly large creature, approximately ten gaz in length. Its head and neck resemble a buffalo, and in thickness it is like a water buffalo, and it resembles a pig. It has six large tusks, each about one cubit, and its teeth are the size of hen's eggs. It has short and thick legs, and its feet resemble those of a camel with cloven hooves on both sides, and a short tail. It attacks ships and destroys any creature it finds. Once in Egypt, a thousand armed men joined together to kill one, but they could not. They said that in another land there was a people who could easily repel it. They summoned them, and a few individuals came and killed it, and people came to see it and gave thanks to God Almighty. The River Nile, which comes from the Jibāl al-Qamar (Mountains of the Moon) to where it empties into the Sea of the Franks, is approximately one thousand farsangs in length.

Anecdote
Once a group of travelers agreed that they wanted to know where the River Nile comes from. They set out along the bank of the Nile toward the south until they reached the Jibāl al-Qamar, which is the source. One of them climbed to the summit of the mountain to see what was on the other side of the mountain. He burst into laughter and threw himself to that side. Another went to see
page_texts.53:
Chapter One
21
what happened to him, he also did the same. After that, they said: let us tie a rope around one person, and let several people hold the end of the rope firmly, and send him to the top of the peak, so that if he also intends to go to that side, we can pull him back and ask him: what did you see? They did so, but he too broke the rope and went, and they could not
determine what the cause was. Some say that it is the Garden of Iram and they are drawn there, and some say it is an extremely beautiful place, and when they see it they want to throw themselves there. And a group says: "There is a creature there, extremely large, that draws any animal it sees to itself with its tail for food."
Nevertheless, the truth of this God Almighty knows.
Next, the reason why it is called the River Nīl is that some scholars say: "Beyond the equator at seven and a half degrees southern latitude, and nineteen degrees from the sign of Mīzān, which is the fall of the Sun, along the ṭarīqa al-muḥtaraqa it passes through the zenith, until three degrees into the sign of ʿAqrab, which is the fall of the Moon, and has passage through the zenith — due to the extreme heat and radiance of the sun, the earth has become black." And we have drawn two lines as an example, and from this line of the fall of the Sun which passes through the zenith to that other line which is the fall of the Moon is approximately one hundred and twenty farsangs in width.
And in this distance the earth has become burnt like ash, and the River Nīl passes through it, and when the water increases, it brings much black mud with it, and the water is black — for this reason they call it Nīl. However, this meaning has no truth, that because of the sun's rays and heat the earth becomes black, for in the first and second climes, especially in the western half, the heat and warmth of the sun is greater than on that side of the equator, and no earth
:
1 Original: nineteen; corrected from the Russian and Paris manuscripts.
.
Paris: Qamar; corrected from the Russian manuscript.
2 Original and
page_texts.54:
22
Haft Kishwar
black and b and has not been burnt, but in the regions of حبشه and بربر there is much black mud, and when the water of the river of مصر rises, it carries those black muds to مصر, and for this reason they call it نهرنیل, because it brings immeasurable black mud.

After that, to the east of رود نیل مصر at the equator, there is a great mountain, and all the water comes from it, and they call it نیل مقدشو, and there are several cities and another province on that shore of the sea that enters the inhabited quarter at the equator, and from those regions and mountains much water has gathered and a lake has appeared and flows toward the north and joins the sea of مصر.

And after that, to the west of نیل سیاه, there is a mountain that they call جبل لاهو, and north of this mountain, which is near the equator, are the districts of انکرازی, and they are an evil and savage people in their nature, and they wear no garments, and if they find a stranger, they seize him and kill him and eat him, and the length and width of their desert is one hundred or two hundred farsangs.

Further, there are several cities and fortresses and provinces and meadows, and there is a great mountain that they call جبل خنفسار, and another mountain is to the south of this mountain on the shore of the Encompassing Sea, which they call جبل سسفی, and in all those places there are people and various animals and plants and trees, and they call it the province of برشنه and روغنه, and the length and width of this province is two hundred or three hundred farsangs.

Another is the province of رفود منقولو. At the farthest west and the shore of the Encompassing Sea, there is a tall great mountain that they call جبل مقلوس. About

1 - Manuscript "م": انكزار. روسیه and پاریس manuscripts: انکرار. 2 - Manuscript "م": سیقی; روسیه manuscript: سیسقی; and پاریس manuscript: "شقی". 3 - Manuscript "م": another province منقولو است.
page_texts.55:
Chapter One
23
The length and breadth of that region is two hundred and fifty or three hundred farsangs, and there are various kinds of animals and plants, flowers and sweet basil, meadows and trees, and there are minerals and wondrous things such as magnetite, and gold and silver are abundant, and the stones of this mountain all contain gold. And in these southern regions that we have mentioned, all the people are black, and those who are in the western half are blacker because the climate of the western half is hotter than the eastern.
page_texts.56:
First Section of the Second Chapter
On the Description of the First Clime
On the shore of the Encompassing Sea, from the farthest east, the first settlement in this first clime is an inhabited island called the Island of Yāqūt (Ruby), for the ruby mine is there. To the north of this is another island [which has a silver mine, and
,
to the northern side of that is yet another island, and its account is lengthy: approximately one hundred and fifty farsangs in length and thirty farsangs in width is this island. Those people are idol worshippers, and there are many idol temples, and they possessed abundant blessings and wealth, and various kinds of
plants and animals were present.
And to the north of this is another island that has approximately forty farsangs in length and width, and there is an idol temple there] and a large idol has been placed there and adorned with jewels. Every idol worshipper who appears at this idol temple at the appointed time, they say has performed a great pilgrimage. And they say that this idol demands blood every year, and the people of this island every year obtain and seize a stranger and
1-2. This section was added from the Russian manuscript.
page_texts.57:
Chapter Two
25
at an appointed time, they place [him] in that idol-temple and confine [him] in that idol-temple at night. The next day that person will be dead. In these recent years, when the date of the Hijra of the Prophet (peace be upon him) had reached seven hundred, a Muslim traveler came to this island with the intention of sightseeing. They seized him and at night placed him in the idol-temple and cast him before the great idol. That Muslim recited the Quran all night long. When day came, they opened the idol-temple and found him alive. They displayed the utmost amazement, for they had never witnessed such a thing. They honored and revered him greatly, [saying] that our god did not kill him. They gave him much gold and jewels, and he became so established among them that whatever authority he exercised, they tolerated. And they say that at this time several other Muslims have gone there and are rulers over the people of that island.
There is another island that is a gold mine, and after it there is another island to the east of this island, which is on the shore of the Encompassing Sea. There is an exceedingly high mountain, and there is a fortress atop that mountain, exceedingly white and luminous, which they call the Luminous Fortress. When one ascends to the top of that fortress, they hear the sound of the celestial sphere grinding together, and at the end of night and beginning of day it is heard more often.
Question
At the end of the second clime, in the vicinity of Qannawj, the capital of India, there is a mountain that is seven farsangs in height. Due to its extreme height, at morning prayer the sun falls upon the peak of that mountain and at evening prayer it has not yet set. Similar to this mountain in height, in the south of Luristān on the road to Shūlistān, there is one they call Grīva-yi Mār. At night they lodge in the middle of the mountain and cross it in two days. How is it that on these high mountains they do not hear the sound of the celestial sphere?
page_texts.58:
26
Answer
Haft Kishwar
Not every mountain that is taller is closer to the celestial sphere, for on the surface of the earth there are many elevations and depressions, and furthermore [that] at all times dust and vapor rise from water and earth, and especially in any place where there are meadows, animals, and waters, vapor and dust become a veil for sounds. Never does [vapor] and dust not rise from mere water and earth, and when the sun comes above the earth upon the ground, vapor and dust ascend more. And since this Qalʿa-yi Muḍīʾa is on the shore of the Encompassing Sea and the water is pure and absolute, and there is no land or meadow in those regions, the path for sound is open and clear and one can hear.
For example, we have often seen and heard that if someone on the road falls behind the caravan at night for rest, and at dawn the roads on both sides become confused to him, he places his ear to the ground and [from one farsang away] hears the sound of the caravan's footsteps and knows which road he must take. And this meaning is because the dust and vapor that the sun raised during the previous day has mostly dissipated and scattered and settled, and the air has become clear—whereas during the day one cannot hear even a tenth of a farsang.
Now then, the proof of how on top of that mountain which is seven farsangs in height the sun shines on the mountain fortress at morning and evening prayers: if at the foot of that mountain there is a strong sea, there are valleys and chasms, and around it are tall mountains and very dense trees, from mid-morning until afternoon they mostly do not see the sun, and it becomes dark from the mountain's shadow, for night is the shadow of the earth, and winter days grow dark sooner. And when the sun reaches the horizon
1 These two words have been added from the Russian manuscript. 2 - Manuscript "M": if the foot of that mountain which is the Sea of Qirm, and in the Russian manuscript diyār qūmat, and the Paris manuscript: "Sea of
Qirmat."
page_texts.59:
Chapter Two
27
when it approaches the east and west it becomes extremely dark and appears like night. Thus they perform the morning and evening prayers in darkness due to the disappearance of the sun, and since the mountain is seven farsangs in height, it is possible that from the foot of the mountain to the summit there are several ridges, so that when at the beginning and end of the day the disc of the sun shines upon the mountain peak, it does not cast rays into the foot of the mountain and the valleys and chasms, and the reflection of light is not perceptible. Therefore at the beginning and end of the day there is extreme darkness, and God knows best.

Anecdote

Fīthāghūras the sage, to whom the science of ethics is attributed, and some also say he was a prophet and was king, commander, and ruler over his people, and was a leader and chief among the great ones of his time—on top of a high mountain where in that vicinity dust and mist rarely rose, he built a strong, elevated fortress from a compound reaching close to the frigid atmosphere, such that he could hear sounds from the celestial sphere. From those various sounds of the spheres that touch one another, he derived the instruments of musicians and singers, and determined each melody, instrument, and mode for which time it serves as treatment for the insane and epileptic. And when the people of the age spent their time in frivolity and jest and indulged excessively, the lawgiver declared it forbidden, and physicians abandoned those benefits with which they treated the sick. Also, every celestial emanation that is specific to a particular place is stronger, and when distributed to various places it becomes weaker.

One day, one of the students of Buqrāṭ the physician went to him to learn. He saw that Buqrāṭ was dancing and was amazed. He asked: "You always advise us

1- Original: guzārand. 2- Original: be lahw raghbat ṣarf mī kardand, the word ʿabath added from the Russian manuscript and the word awqāt added from the Paris manuscript.
page_texts.60:
28
Haft Kishvar
you used to advise that we should stay away from frivolity and play and from anything that had no beneficial final cause, and strive in knowledge and wisdom. What was the reason that when I entered you were dancing?
He said: For some time I have been thinking about making something for a feverish patient that would provide nourishment so that nature could resist during the crisis and strength would not collapse, and that would thin the thick matter that causes fever and open the obstruction so it would come out through perspiration. If I thought of something suitable for nourishment, it was not soothing and aperient, and if I thought of something that would thin the matter and open the obstruction, it did not provide nourishment. And at this moment when you entered, the answer came to my mind that all three
meanings are present in it, and from the utmost joy such happiness affected me that no restraint remained and I involuntarily jumped up. Just as there was a sage who wanted to draw a circle that would have a parallel circular surface with the center point exactly in the middle, equal from the center to the circumference on all sides, so that by the power of this circle he could obtain the knowledge of celestial cycles. However he drew it, it did not come out well. One day a design occurred to him: he tied one end of a stick together and sharpened the other end with a nail, placed it on a flat surface and rotated it—a parallel circular circle took shape with the center exactly in the middle, and every line he drew from any side of the circumference all passed through the center. When this observation occurred and he conceived from it the form of earth and heaven, such spirit and joy appeared in him that the animal spirit completely expanded from his heart to the extremities of his body and departed, and at that very moment he died at his work.
1 Original: مجموع. 2 Russian and Paris manuscripts: نيك. 3 Russian manuscript: علم ادوار افلاك.
page_texts.61:
Chapter Two
29
The point is that the experiments which the sages conducted had the aim of knowledge and wisdom and the benefit of people. The sages sewed a garment that was composed of several colored panels layered together, such that when they clothed a sick person with that garment or cast it upon him, they would diagnose his illness from his actions, movements, and speech.
Furthermore, they had made a drum and a bowl for a specific time, such that if someone was afflicted with colic, he would strike the drum and the colic wind would be released. And if that bowl was placed on the ground in a specific position in waterless deserts and wildernesses, it would condense the air and turn it into water that would collect in the bowl. Once such a drum and bowl were found in a treasury and brought before the king of the time, for they were made most delicately and pleasingly, but they did not know their use. The king struck the drum, and a wind separated from him with a sound. He was offended and embarrassed, so he tore the drum and broke the bowl. And when they later learned of their benefits, they felt regret, but it was of no use.
Most sages were completely serious, such that they would never display in assemblies and gatherings certain qualities that they share with animals, such as exposing the body naked, spitting, expelling other bodily wastes, lying down, sleeping, eating food and drink, raising one's voice loudly, striking someone with something, and so on—all their discourse was of wisdom, teaching, and learning.
Now, beyond the Luminous Fortress, there is another island to its north. On the eastern side of this island, which faces the Encompassing Sea, there are no mountains, and when the sun, moon, and stars rise from the sea, they first shine upon this island, for the other islands have high mountains before them. The people of this island are star-worshippers and
1 Russian manuscript: منفعت instead of منافع. 2 Paris manuscript: خواب بسیار.
کردن.
page_texts.62:
Haft Kishwar
A group says that two ʿAlawī brothers, at a time when the Sādāt were being persecuted, set out toward exile until they reached the farthest eastern settlement, which is this island. At the end of the first clime they arrived and built a dwelling, and each took a wife. When their children were still infants, the fathers passed away, and by this time their offspring have multiplied greatly. They know nothing of what Islam is, nor what Muṣṭafā, peace and blessings be upon him, and Murtaḍā, peace be upon him, have commanded. Surely this account has no truth and is a common legend.¹
Now then, to the west of these islands of the Far East, in the first clime as we mentioned, there is desert and many high mountains and streams of water that have neither width nor depth, and from the northern parts to the second clime extends the distance of these mountains and rivers. These streams come from the second clime, cross the equator, and join the sea. From the Islands of Idols to the bank of the Khamdān River, the breadth of these mountains and streams extends for a distance of three hundred farsangs, and there are humans and various animals and birds and trees and plants and flowers and aromatic herbs. Sandalwood and camphor and indigo plant and aloeswood and brazilwood are abundant, as well as peacocks and rukh and rhinoceros.
Among the wonders is that there is the salamander, which is a bird that with feathers dwells in the midst of fire, and its refuge is fire, and its feathers do not burn; rather, fire emerges from it and falls upon the firewood. Also, it breeds in the midst of fire. Some people hold that it does not breed and that it lives for a thousand years, and when its time of death comes, it gathers much firewood and sets fire to that wood and burns itself in it. After that, rain falls upon its ashes, and by the command of the Creator another salamander appears from those ashes—surely this has no truth.
¹ Original: ʿālam instead of ʿām.
page_texts.63:
Chapter Two
31
Another is the rhinoceros, which is a large animal that has a tall horn on its forehead. It kills the elephant and is the enemy of its own offspring, keeping the young in its belly for seven years. When its mother goes into the thicket, it puts its head out and eats whatever grass it can from the meadow or leaves from trees, and its hands and feet become strong. When it finds the opportunity that its mother is asleep, it comes out and flees to the thicket.

Next, the rukh is a very large animal and is the enemy of the elephant and rhinoceros. When it finds an opportunity, it lifts them up with its claws and carries them so high that from the heat of the sun, an oil comes out of their bodies, and it goes into their eyes and they become blind. After that, it brings them down and feeds them to its young.¹

Question
Where does the waste from the grass that the rhinoceros young eats in its mother's belly go?

Answer
If someone eats one man of food and does hard work, the next day eats one man and does no work, the waste from the day they worked would have been absorbed. Thus the waste of the rhinoceros young in its mother's belly is absorbed little by little. And since she can bear such a large offspring, she can also bear a little waste, especially when most of it has been absorbed.

For example, we have often seen in Baghdad and other cities that when a rubbish heap becomes full, they pour lime on it and burn it, and what remains becomes stone and clay.

¹ This description, with slight variation, is given under the name rukh in the Russian manuscript.
page_texts.64:
Haft Kishwar
The point is that any substance that requires gentle heat will dissolve.
But afterwards, when one passes these mountains and waters, there is a long plain extending to the edge of Khumdan, and there is a large city near the equator called Ṭayfūr. North of this city are several other cities [and provinces], and when one crosses from the Khumdan river [to this plain], there is a sea that has emerged onto the land, and the greatest width of the first clime extends to two thousand one hundred and sixty farsangs of sea.
Some people call this sea Baḥr Akhḍar, and because there are many cities, kingdoms, and provinces on the shores of this sea, some call it the Sea of India, others the Sea of Fars and Basra, and some call it the Sea of Oman. The Sea of Qulzum, which [they call Lisān al-Baḥr, is a gulf of this sea.
There are many large and small islands in this sea, and several islands at the beginning of this sea from the eastern side are extremely hot and mostly inhabited. On an island called Mahrāj, and on two or three other islands near Mahrāj island, there is abundant ʿūd, sandalwood, camphor, and other medicines and drugs, and on that island there is mostly ʿūd qamārī.
Beyond that is another island whose southern side faces the equator, approximately two hundred farsangs in length and one hundred farsangs in width, and that island has several cities and provinces. Many mountains with flowing waters, meadows, trees,
and plants.
On the western side of this island toward the south there is a plain that when one goes to the top of the mountain
1 Paris manuscript: naw'ī instead of nurmī. 2 The word "province" was added from the Russian manuscript.
This section was added from the Russian manuscript. 4- This section was added from the Russian manuscript and Paris manuscript.
page_texts.65:
Chapter Two
they go and see from afar, and no one can go there, and they do not know what is in that desert.
And there is another island to the north of this large island that has abundant mountains and forests, and the length and width of that island is one hundred and fifty farsangs or two hundred farsangs. On most of its mountains and in its forests, camphor, sandalwood, aloe-wood, and brazilwood trees have grown, and camphor and sandalwood were more abundant, and they had grown so densely and thickly intertwined that one cannot know which tree is the camphor tree except when the heat intensifies. They go to the tops of high mountains and observe which tree has a snake coiled around it from the intensity of the heat. Each person marks it and shoots an arrow, and when the weather cools, the snakes disperse. Each person seeks his own arrow, and when they break that tree, camphor comes out, and they call it kāfūr riyāḥī. And what they cannot extract, they boil in water and distill, and they call it kāfūr fanṣūrī.
After that there are several large and small islands, and among them one is larger, and a people of dark-skinned folk are on that island whom they call Makhālāt, and they are savage and brutal, and if they find a stranger they kill him. And I found an opportunity among them and threw myself into the sea, saying: since they will kill you, at least throw yourself into the sea, perhaps you will find deliverance. When I sacrificed myself, the Almighty God willed that I found a large piece of wood on the water and sat upon it, and I traveled for three days and nights until the wind cast me ashore.
After that island is Sūrī Sarandīb, and it is a famous island, and Sarandīb is the name of a mountain on this island. Adam the Chosen One, peace be upon him, to this
1. The original has 'mountain more'; corrected according to the Russian manuscript. 2. Original: taṣghīr.
page_texts.66:
34
Haft Kishwar
island and mountain, and they say that the length and breadth of this island is approximately one hundred and fifty farsangs or two hundred farsangs, and it is a royal seat with many minerals and mines. Especially rubies and cat's eye, and the ruby of سراندیب is better than other rubies, and there is perpetual verdure of flowers and aromatic plants, and it is extremely fresh. Indeed, poets attribute the سوری rose to this island, and there are abundant varieties of wondrous animal offspring. From this island of سراندیب to that other famous island called the island of سند and the island of سریره is approximately nine hundred farsangs of sea, and in this distance there are many islands, and in some humans are found, and in most islands there are plants and animals and also sandalwood and aloe trees and mountains of magnetite, and in some,
there is ambergris, and in several islands there are birds and animals, and some have mines but no humans, and no one finds a way there.
Once a ship at night due to contrary wind went off course, and the next day they found themselves on a shore where there was no one. They stayed there three days. They saw a spring from which something seeped, and whatever reached it turned to gold. A person brought some of it with him. When they came out from there and tested it, it was the spirit of elixir. Whatever they cast upon it turned to gold.
A merchant related that once in the sea an island appeared which from afar showed large white domes; they thought it was a building and people were on that island. When we came close, they were heaps of bird eggs that had been piled up and dried, and there was no human there at all.
And in some of these islands there is red sulfur, which is the spirit of elixir. And there is an island where a spring flows with sulfur, and in it there is a worm that the practitioners of the crafts say is the elixir.
page_texts.67:
Chapter Two
35
And on the road between Hamadān and Baghdād, to the south, a sulphur spring was observed that flowed out like a stream of milk and solidified.
,
After that
No one knows for certain what ambergris truly is, for all of it is found on the seashore. Some say it is sea foam, and others say it comes from the sea cow. My prevailing opinion is that ambergris is wax that has matured over time and become ambergris, for in these islands there are green mountains and abundant aromatic plants, and bees make honey in those mountains, and rain falls upon it, and the honey melts away leaving the wax, and after several years of maturing in the sun it becomes ambergris. That which is in the shade of the mountain becomes aswad [black], and that upon which the sun has shone becomes ambergris ashab [grey]. Then when much rain falls, the mountain torrents strike that wax which has become ambergris and carry it to the sea, and most people of insight collect it.
In the city of Tām, which is on the coast of the Indian Sea, a merchant gave a garment to a slave girl to wash, and she found something like a black stone and tied it to the garment. When she brought the garment to the master, it was fragrant with the scent of ambergris. The master asked, "Where did you wash this garment?"
The slave girl took him to that place where there were pieces of black ambergris; from this he became wealthy and brought it to Hurmūz, and in that year the price of ambergris fell to one dinar for two dāng because of its abundance.
After that there are several other cities on the coast of this sea which are at the end of the first clime, among the cities of Hindūstān, and various medicinal herbs and maritime goods are plentiful, and diverse birds such as peacocks and parrots, and animals beyond count such as elephants, giraffes, and rhinoceroses, and other creatures that belong to Hindūstān, and a bird which they call "rukh" is abundant and dwells on the islands, and the silk-worm that we mentioned on the island of Namakūt
page_texts.68:
36
Haft Kishvar
is also found in this island. After that, the island of Sind, the island of Sarīra, and the island of Suquṭrā are well-known islands, and in all places there are humans and other animals, and most of these islands have people who are sorcerers and of bad faith; some ports are trading houses for textiles. They cultivate much aloe, and in the warm regions they set up nurseries and plant aloe there, and Suquṭrī aloe is considered better, and it is like madder and has no branches or leaves, and it is stronger than madder. When it fully ripens, it produces manna that is extremely sweet; for this reason they named patience ṣabr, because after bitterness it yields sweetness.

These islands are attributed to the Sea of ʿUmān, and when the Indian Sea produces waves, it casts out white tutia.

As for tutia, it is of four types: one is that which the waves of the Indian Sea cast onto the shore, which is extremely white; the second is found in rivers; the third is that in the desert there is a place called Fayd where much is found, and they say it rains from the sky; and the fourth is mineral from the province of Kirmān, and mineral tutia is abundant.

After that, when one passes these islands and seas, there is the kingdom of Yemen, which has approximately two hundred farsangs in length and width, and Yemen is surrounded by sea on three sides, and the northern side is Ḥijāz and Makka; and Ṭāʾif and the city of Bilqīs, which they call Sabāʾ, is in Yemen; and there is much diamond and mines of carnelian and onyx; and there are two mountains in Yemen called Jabalā Ṭayy, and in the vicinity of those two mountains is the dwelling and residence of a people who were mostly noble and renowned, and Ḥātim Ṭāʾī was from that tribe, and the ʿĀdites and Musaylima the Liar were from Yemen.

1 - Russian manuscript: Suquṭra. Paris manuscript: Suquṭr.
page_texts.69:
Chapter Two
Anecdote
37
In the world there have been many great men of virtue and noble nature, at the height
.
But
of generosity, whose gifts were without hypocrisy or obligation, expecting no return,
yet no one has reached the level of Ḥātim Ṭāʾī. Once an enemy prevailed over Ḥātim and seized his kingdom, and Ḥātim fled and hid in a mountain. One day he saw an old man approaching. He asked him, "Where are you going?" He said, "I am going to Ḥātim, for I have three daughters and I need three thousand dinars to give them in marriage." Ḥātim became sad that this old man would go and not find him and return disappointed. He called the old man back and said, "I am Ḥātim who has fled, and they have proclaimed that whoever brings Ḥātim shall receive whatever he desires. Now seize me and go to the foot of such-and-such mountain where some tents are pitched, and say that you have captured Ḥātim. Take three thousand dinars and hand me over to them." The old man said, "I will not do this." Ḥātim insisted. The old man
.
agreed and took Ḥātim captive to the place he knew and cried out that he had captured Ḥātim.
When the king heard, he ordered that the old man's wish be fulfilled and that Ḥātim be killed.
.
The king's vizier said, "It is impossible that such a weak old man alone could capture and bind such a man, and over a journey of so many farsangs bring him thus." The king ordered that the old man be brought and his account
be inquired.
The old man related the affair as it had happened. When the king heard these words,
he descended from his throne and placed his head at Ḥātim's feet and said, "With someone like you who sacrifices his precious life for the sake of an old man whose desire was a trifling matter, it is not fitting that anyone else should sit in your place."
1- Original and Paris manuscript: gharaḍī; corrected according to the Russian manuscript.
.
page_texts.70:
38
Haft Kishvar
After that there is a city at the beginning of the kingdom of Yemen which they call «Najrān»
and in the Jāhiliyya they had built a Ka'ba which was their pilgrimage site, and they called that Ka'ba Dhū al-Khalīṣa, and Khalīṣa is the name of a tribe, and the army of Islam destroyed it, and the destruction of Najrān is proverbial among the Arabs. But in Ṣanʿāʾ of Yemen there is an extremely sturdy palace which they call Qaṣr Ghumdān, and they say that the first building constructed after the flood of Noah was Qaṣr Ghumdān, and the kings of Yemen held that palace in high regard.
After that, in the city of ʿĀd they erected a minaret of copper and made a human figure also of copper atop it, and during the four sacred months—which are Rajab, Dhū al-Qaʿda, Dhū al-Ḥijja, and Muḥarram—abundant water would flow down from it, such that they would drink from it and give it to livestock and collect it in pools and reservoirs, and when the month ended it would stop again, and this matter is famous among the Arabs and is a divine thing whose essence no one can fathom.
Now then, at the end of the kingdom of Yemen is ʿAdan, and an inlet extends from the sea to the shore of a city which they call Qulzum, and they call that inlet Lisān al-Baḥr, and from where that sea extends the distance is no more than forty farsangs, and it goes to about two hundred farsangs, and when one passes ʿAdan and Lisān al-Baḥr and Jabal Maʿād, there is the kingdom of Ḥabasha and Barbara. The length of these two kingdoms is about five hundred and fifty farsangs and three hundred farsangs in width up to the border of the kingdom of Egypt, and the Nile River and several other rivers pass through those two regions, and all the people of these two regions are black and Muslim and God-fearing.
And south of the cities of Ḥabasha and Barbara is the kingdom of Zanj, and there is a great city near the equator which lies between the Sea of Yemen and Marj al-Baḥrayn, and
page_texts.71:
Chapter Two
39
The people of Ḥabasha and Barbara and Zanj are all intermixed with one another, and there are various kinds of wild and domestic animals and varieties of textile goods, and there was much Maghribī gold.
Anecdote
A grandson of Imam Jaʿfar al-Ṣādiq, peace be upon him, who was the nephew of Ismāʿīl—the Ismāʿīlī Fidāʾīs are affiliated with him. One named ʿAbd al-Muʾmin proclaimed in the land of Barbara that "I am the Mahdī," and he was a learned and scholarly man. He composed a book that was neither the jurisprudence of the Sunnīs nor the jurisprudence of the Shīʿīs. However, it was better than Shīʿī jurisprudence and closer to Sunnī jurisprudence, and he summoned a people from that land and struck coins in his own name, and the ʿAbd al-Muʾminī gold has fame, and east of Ṭarābulīs, in the Maghrib, he founded a city and named it Mahdiyya, and we have written Mahdiyya in its proper place, and the call was accepted from the city of Mahdiyya to the farthest reaches of Barbara, a distance of nearly seven hundred farsangs, and they read his book and translate it into the Ḥabashī and Barbarī languages. There is a group among the Barbara among whom there is absolutely no immorality, corruption, debauchery, falsehood, dishonesty, or theft, and they do not speak any word by which they would become sinners, and they make no interference or meddling or questioning of God's dominion, and every year more than twelve thousand of them, men and women, come on pilgrimage with the Egyptian caravan, and most of them are on foot.
Once someone arrived in the land of Barbara and the life and ways of that people pleased him, so he said: "I want a woman from you whom I may take in marriage and live among you." They said: "Sit by the roadside for several days, for women who are without husbands pass by there. When one catches your eye, tell us so we may give her to you." After several days when he had taken the woman to his home, the man came home from the fields at midday and said: "Oh! How hot it is!" And his wife says: "What business do you have with God's dominion and decree"
page_texts.72:
Haft Kishwar
he sent [a message asking] whether it is hot or cold. He summoned the people and obtained a divorce from her, and that person departed from that land.
After that, when one passes beyond the borders of دنقله and حبشه and the believing districts and بربره, there is another territory with various peoples, and some of them are of wild nature,
without clothing or garments, all black, and there are many mountains, and good waters,
and abundant [rivers] come from there and join the sea of مرج البحرین, and some join the western sea, and another great river comes from جبل لاهو and the equator and flows into the western
sea.
And in the first clime on this side there is a great city, and some of them
are Muslims and there is a gold mine, and that city is called غانه.
After that is the coast of the western sea, and an island from whose shore much ambergris is found, and there are several other large islands. And to the south of this place there is a city called نوبه, a famous city in the western region, and south of نوبه are the districts of لم لم, and these people are all black and beast-like in nature, wild and malicious, and man-eaters, and neither men nor women wear any clothing, and the people of نوبه and that region do not go alone to the border of لم لم, and from نوبه to the border of لمالمه is about eighty farsangs.
After that is the coast of the Ocean, which is the beginning of the longitude of the inhabited quarter, and this is taken from there after the جزایر خالدات which in ancient times was inhabited and was the beginning of the settlement of the West, about two hundred and twenty farsangs of water has covered [it].
page_texts.73:
Chapter Two
On the Description of the Second Clime
The beginning of the inhabited lands in the far east of the second clime consists of the cities of Chīn and Māchīn. The length of that kingdom extends to five hundred and fifty farsangs and its width amounts to nearly three hundred farsangs. Qarāqurm, which is the capital of the Khāqān, lies on the border of Chīn, which is the beginning of the third clime. Its climate is temperate and various bounties and textiles are available there. Tin and silver are abundant, but gold is produced less than silver. The people of the province of Chīn are fair-featured and slightly dark-skinned. Most of them are idol worshippers and Muslims are few. They say that in Chīn there is an idol temple, and around that temple they have placed lodestone on all sides, and they have made an idol of iron and suspended it in the middle, standing upright, because when the attractive force of the lodestone is equal from all directions, it remains suspended. They say that in the idol temple of Sūmnāt as well, they had made an idol in the same manner, until the army of Islam destroyed it.

In the first and second climes, people were idol worshippers, star worshippers, and irreligious. Mānī the painter was from Fārs and came to the kingdom of Khitā, and from there came to Chīn and took up residence.
page_texts.74:
42
Haft Kishwar
He created [it] and was an unparalleled painter, and depicted all the forms and figures of the world on the pages of a book, and named it Artang, and claimed prophethood, saying that my miracle is that I can draw a circle with my finger on hand or foot such that when a compass is placed on it, there is no difference at all, and he would draw an alif on silk five gaz long, so straight that it did not deviate by even a single thin hair.
Now, in the vicinity of eastern China there are abundant mountains and waters, and various plants and animals, and after that one reaches Ma'bar and Quhistan, which has a length of three hundred farsangs and a width of one hundred and sixty farsangs, and the western side of this Quhistan is the border of Hindustan, and the southern side is the coast of the Sea of India. Several other mountains extend to the city of Zaytun, and Qannawj, the capital of India, is approximately five hundred and fifty farsangs in length. In that vicinity there is a mountain that is seven farsangs high, and there is a desert around which there are high mountains, and one cannot go there, and in that desert there are many diamonds. People go to the top of the mountain and place pieces of meat on catapults and throw them into that desert, and when they fall to the ground, diamonds stick to them. Vultures and other carrion-eating birds pick them up and carry them to the mountaintop, and when they eat, the diamonds fall off and are collected. The climate of this region is warmer than China.
Anecdote
Once a merchant from Khurasan saw someone in those regions cultivating and asked: What are you planting? He said: Iron. The merchant was amazed. The Hindu said: This is more wondrous than what they say that in your land stones fall from the sky and some turn to ice. Both were astonished at each other's words and marveled, and
page_texts.75:
Chapter Two
23
Each of them would say: "This exists and we see it, but what you say is impossible."
However, a rational proof regarding iron can be stated, for we have observed in the province of Fārs and several other provinces that they bring black clay from mines, place it in crucibles, melt it, and the essence of iron separates from it. If desert clay contains the essence of iron and water is added to it, and iron particles are scattered and placed in the clay, when the hot sun shines upon it and heat is generated and spreads, those iron particles attract the essence of iron to themselves according to the affinity of iron's nature—just as a snake-stone draws poison to itself from the pores and interior of the human body by affinity with venom—and those scattered particles grow larger. If iron particles are rubbed with powdered and dissolved lodestone, perhaps the attractive force would increase.
In this province there are many sorcerers, more women than men, and there are people who burn the dead. They teach this practice based on a philosophical doctrine, as the sages of India say that when the body is completely annihilated, the soul has no attachment remaining and becomes united [with the divine], but as long as the body exists, the soul remains attached to it.
Furthermore, in this city there are two or three olive trees that are under government administration, and they produce something with a tight skin. When broken by hand, something with the taste of wheat flour comes out, from which they make various foods and bring and sell it by the kharwār.
Afterwards, when one crosses the mountain waters, on the southern side, which is the beginning of the second clime, are the cities of India, and on the northern side, which was the end of the second clime, are the lands of India, Dībal, and parts of Makrān and Banpūl.
In the regions of Sind and Makrān there is a tree that produces something hollow
page_texts.76:
Haft Kishvar
And a small and thin worm is inside it, and it remains alive inside for one year. A group whom they call Kāwlīyān, who travel around the regions and practice medicine, collect these. When someone has a toothache, they say "this is a worm in his tooth." They perform an operation in such a way that no one is aware, and they show that worm to him saying "we extracted this from your tooth," and thus they deceive people.

After that, when one passes the waters of Sind, there is the Persian Gulf, and Mughān and Jīruft and Hurmūz and the warm regions of Kirmān and Fārs up to Khunj and Sīrāf and the coast of the Sea of Baṣra. On the coasts of this sea there are many ports, and no port is like the port of Hurmūz and Jarūn, which is the center of the world and the frontier of Kirmān and Fārs, and close to Iraq and Khurāsān and Ādharbāyjān and most of the inhabited settlements of the inhabited quarter.

After that, when one passes the Gulf of Baṣra, there is Qaṭīf and Baḥrayn and Laḥsā and Hajar and Yamāma and the Arabian desert and Makka and Madīna and the land of Ḥijāz up to the coast of the Sea of Qulzum, which they call Lisān al-Baḥr. The Arabian desert up to the foothills of Mount Ṭāʾif is called the Arabian Peninsula because it lies between two seas.

When the year of the Alexandrian calendar reached nine hundred, the sages said that the superior conjunction was shifting from the airy triplicity to the watery triplicity, and the first conjunction would occur in the sign of Scorpio, which is the house of the term and the house of the face and the triplicity of Mars, and pertains to the Arabian Peninsula. This indicates that a prophet would arise from the Arabian Peninsula whose proof would be the sword, and he would conquer the entire world, and that is the Master of the End Times.

In this sea of Qaṭīf and Baḥrayn there are varieties of pearls, and they are finer than those of other seas, because according to astrological reasoning, pearls belong to the sign of Cancer in the second clime, and Qaṭīf and Baḥrayn pass through the samt al-raʾs, and every sign and planet that passes through the samt
page_texts.77:
Chapter Two
25
the zenith of a people and place, its influence is stronger.

In ancient times, a tribe from this region worshipped Shiʿrā as a deity, which is in the constellation Cancer, and still a group of misguided people remain from that tribe.

Descriptions

In the bādiya of the Arabs, at a place called Fayd, tutty rains down, and they find something else resembling wheat and say that it also rains down. Most likely it is the seed of a plant that has the taste of wheat. There was much gum, taranjabīn, and gazangabīn. In that desert there were many ostriches, and they call the ostrich egg "bayḍat al-balad," because it lays its egg on the open desert, and the Arabs call the desert "balad." Whoever is the noblest and most excellent of a people, they say he is "bayḍat al-balad." When ʿAmr ibn ʿAbd Wudd was killed at the hand of Amīr al-Muʾminīn ʿAlī—peace and blessings upon him—his sister said two verses about his rank: if the killer of ʿAmr were not ʿAlī, I would weep at all times, and it is no shame that his killer is bayḍat al-balad. Those two verses are:

لو كان قاتل عمرو غير قاتل
لكن قاتله من لايعاب بـه

Verse

بكيته ما اقام روح في جسدي.
وكان يدعى قائماً بيضة البلد

Meaning he is the noblest of the people. Also, someone who is lowly and worthless is also called bayḍat al-balad, and this meaning is derived from the ostrich egg, because its eggs are many.

And it knows that at first when the chick is small, it cannot go to the desert to graze
page_texts.78:
26

Haft Kishvar
cannot go. It divides the egg into three parts: one part it hides in the earth, one part it places in the sun until it dries, and another part it places under its feathers. When it hatches chicks, first it breaks what has dried in the sun and gives it to the chicks, and afterward it brings out what it had hidden in the earth and gives it. After a few days have passed, [the chick] can go to the desert to graze. Therefore, people call both the honored and the lowly bayḍat al-balad.

There is another thing in the desert resembling a turnip with no branches or leaves; the Arabs call it kamāh, the Persians call it kahr, and the Khorasanians call it samārūgh. They fry and eat it, and eating it is very harmful to the brain. It appears on the surface of the desert, and they also call it bayḍat al-balad, and in the desert it was boundless.

However, approximately one hundred and fifty farsangs distant is the Sea of Qulzum, and on the shore of the Sea of Qulzum is the city of ʿAdhāb and Sudan. There are two significant mines, one of gold and one of emerald, and it is the end of the realm of Egypt and the beginning of the realm of Abyssinia. Beyond that is the Nile River, and beyond that the desert and mountains inhabited by nomads, and flowing waters. Most of those people are black, and the southern part of this region borders Barbar and Abyssinia. Beyond that are other waters and wide and deep streams extending to the city of Manūs, which is the farthest west, and two or three other inhabited islands. In these mountains and deserts there are many beneficial medicines and several plants that serve as antidotes and treatments for leprosy and vitiligo. Rare things are brought from this place, including a stone that when dropped into vinegar, jumps out, and they take it as a gift to kings. There is another stone that when water is dripped onto it, a fire ignites, and when olive oil is poured on it, the fire is extinguished.

1. This word was added from the Russian manuscript. 2. Apparently it is the metal 'sodium'.
page_texts.79:
Chapter Two

27

And there is another stone that is called ḥajar al-qamar, and it has spots on it, and in the increase and decrease of the moon, its spots increase and decrease, and the property of that stone is that when it is tied on an epileptic, he becomes well, and another stone that is the magnet of silver. It attracts silver to itself and has other properties besides this.

And there are streams of running water, and on its bank is sugarcane, and in ancient times there was no sugarcane in other climes and lands, and they did not know what sugarcane was, and they ordered the syrup of the sick from grape molasses, and in the time of Iskandar, sugarcane appeared in the world.

Tale

In Abyssinia, they had built a Kaʿba and held it dear and respected, and it was their pilgrimage, and this house was called Qalīs. A person from the tribes of Quraysh was jealous and took medicine and went into that house at night and fell into diarrhea and made everything impure, and he fled in the same night. The next day they knew that that person had come from Mecca. They made an agreement, and the Aṣḥāb al-Fīl came with an army, as is well known, to destroy the Kaʿba in return for the impurity. God Almighty commanded some birds to throw stones at them until they were destroyed, as it is stated in the Glorious Quran: 

stones

....

 أرسل عليهم طيراً أبابيل ترميهم بحجارة من سجيل )

After a few years, an army came from Abyssinia and fought in Yemen with Dhū'l-Yazan. They killed Dhū'l-Yazan, and Sayf, the son of Dhū'l-Yazan, went to Rome and asked the Caesar of Rome for an army. The Caesar did not grant it and said that the Abyssinians were of the same religion as me, that is, Christians, and I would not send an army to fight them.

¹- The original Caesar said that you are co-religionists of the Christians, I will not give you an army. Correction based on the Russian version
page_texts.80:
۲۸
هفت کشور
سیف به مداین آمد و از انوشیروان شکر خواست و او تقبل نمود و هفت سال او را موقوف گردانید روزی بر سر محفل آغاز تشنیع کرد که تو به عدل مشهور شده ای روا بود که مرا هفت سال و عده دهی به اتفاق ؟ وزرا و حاضران قبول کردند که جماعتی از ملوك و امرای اطراف که در بند بودند از بند بیرون آورند و لشکری از ایشان مرتب کنند و همراه سیف دوالیزن به جنگ حبشیان فرستند که اگر کشته شوند خود واجب القتل اند و اگر نصرتی و ظفری یابند ، ناموسی از بهر ما کرده اند . پس آن قوم محبوس را بیرون آوردند و قریب چهار هزار مرد جنگی همراه سیف ذوالیزن کرد و از محبوسان پادشاه زاده ای بود که از جوانی باز او را حبس نموده بودند و
آن جوان در حبس پیر شده و موی ابروی او در از گشته و به پیش چشم در آمده او را نخیر جان میخواندند و او را سرور لشکر کرد و چون به مقابله بایستاد ، می پرسید که پادشاه حبشه کدام است ؟ گفتند که تاج مرصع دارد و یاقوت پاره ای بر پیشانی بسته نخیر جان تیر میاندازد و بر پیشانی پادشاه می زند ، از اسب به زیر میافتد و هلاک میشود و لشکر حبشه شکسته میشوند و قتل بسیار میکنند و قلیس که حج حبشیان بود خراب می کنند
و نخیر جان را در حبشه بر تخت مینشانند و ملک و حاکم می شود . سیف ذوالیزن به مکه باز میگردد و به یمن می آید بعد از آن جماعتی از رؤسا و مشاهیر مکه اتفاق میکنند و به تهنیت سیف دوالیزن می آیند به یمن وسیف ذو البزن همه را رعایت کرد وزر بسیار داد . و مقدار همان به عبدالمطلب داد و او را بشارت ظهور مصطفی داد . مشاهیر گفتند چرا چندانکه به ما داده به تو تنها داده است عبدالمطلب گفت مرا بشارت دیگر داده که این عطای او نسبت به آن هیچ نیست .
۱- این قسمت از نسخه روسیه اضافه شد اصل و اهل مکه را رعایت کرد .
page_texts.81:
باب دوم
۲۹
بعد از آن چون به مکه آمدند ، جهودی غریب دانشمند به مکه
آمد و عبدالمطلب و عبدالله پسرش را دید که پیش هم استاده بودند . آن دانشمند به احتیاط هر چه تمامتر مشاهده ایشان می کرد تا غایتی که نظر در سوراخ بینی او انداخت ، عبد المطلب گفت چه می نگری ؟ » جهود گفت « من نشانه ای در شما میبینم فرزندی از شما پدید آید که پیغمبر باشد و همه عالم دین اوگزینند ، ترا دو دختر میباید خواست یکی از بهر خود و یکی از بهر عبدالله از قبیله ای که ایشان را بنی زمره میخوانند . » عبدالمطلب دو دختر خواست یکی از بهر خود و یکی از بهر عبدالله و از عبدالمطلب حمزه پدید آمد و از عبدالله مصطفى صلى الله عليه و سلم . و حمزه پیش از مصطفی به شش ماه به وجود آمد و همشیره بودند و مصطفی را عظیم دوست داشتی و به ارادت خویش مسلمان شد .
و در تاریخ دیگر چنان میآید که اول خرابی قلیس حبشه و بعد از آن لشکر اصحاب فیل به عزم خرابی مکه و آمدن اصحاب فیل به مکه تاریخی ساخته اند و پیش از تاریخ هجرت همه مکاتبات [ به تاریخ فیل ] مورخ گردانیدندی . [ واكثر حكما و منجمان قرانها به تاریخ فیل نهادند و آن زمان که اصحاب فیل به مکه آمده بودند ولادت مصطفی صلى الله عليه و آله وسلم شده بود و قرآن علویین در عقرب که دلیل نبوت مصطفی صلی الله علیه وسلم واقع گشته و آن قران را قران ملت می خوانند و قرآن ملت را تاریخی ساخته اند و تاریخ ملت و تاریخ فیل هر دو یکی است . و در کتب نجومی ذکر میکنند که تاریخ مبعث مصطفی صلى الله عليه و سلم در سنه اربعین بوده است از تاریخ فیل و هجرت مصطفی در سنه اثنی و خمسین بوده است و در زمان عمر در تاریخ هجری شروع کردند و تاریخ فیل را ترک کردند .
.
۳-۲-۱- این قسمتها از نسخه روسیه افزوده شد .

فصل ثالث

page_texts.83:
Chapter Two
51
A rope is tied to the edge of the shield, and it has two wide eyes in the middle of its back,
and its mouth is in the middle of its belly and in the lower half.
And there is another animal in the sea that has something long growing out of its head that has long teeth on both sides, and the Qalandars hold it in their hands, and that animal sometimes attacks the ship and strikes and breaks the ship, and if someone is in the water and rises, it strikes their waist and destroys them unless they swim and crawl out. And on the coast of Hormuz, we have seen a hundred thousand kinds, large and small, that were scattered, and there is another animal that is called Imarinus, whose birth, growth, pregnancy, giving birth, and death all happen in one night and day.
And we boarded a ship in Hormuz and saw an extremely white animal [that had gathered in great numbers] and their heads were like a wide hat, and their bodies were straight from the middle, so that the surroundings remained empty, and when they fell on the deck, they died immediately. My prevailing opinion is that this animal is perhaps the Imarinus.
For example, if someone has not seen a silkworm, and they say there is an egg from which a worm comes out in the spring, and it has no eyes, and it eats green leaves for forty days, and after that it becomes intoxicated and eats nothing, and a cocoon of silk forms around it, very hard and firm, and that worm is long, and after ten days it pierces that cocoon and comes out, a bird that has wings and feathers and eyes and a head and long hands and feet, and the male and female come out together and the female lays eggs and withholds itself and eats nothing for twenty-five days, and
page_texts.84:
52
Seven Countries
After that, they die. Of course, someone who has not observed it will say that this man is crazy, and it has been experienced many times that when it comes out of the cocoon, piercing it and letting the air out and the eyes and wings appearing, it happens in the twinkling of an eye. So if, in a moment, before it pierces the cocoon, they split the cocoon open, it is still the same worm.
Again, if someone has not seen a honey bee, they say that a bee has a poisonous sting and obtains something fatty from the plants of the mountains and deserts that hardens when it sees water and makes hexagonal containers from it, and after that it fills it with an extremely sweet syrup that melts when it sees water, and those bees have an emir who commands them, and their emir has a ruler, doorkeeper, deputy, chamberlain, executioner, cook, and chef for them. And if one of them commits a sin, he orders punishment, and they do not act impudently in the presence of the emir and do not sting, and wherever the emir goes, they all go with him, and if one goes before another emir, they kill him, saying why did you turn away from your emir, and if their emir dies, the emir's child is their emir, and they all have children every year. Of course, whoever has not observed it will say that this man is frantic and saying irrelevant things. The point is, whatever we have not seen is possible.
After that, when they pass through the lands of Samanjān, which is adjacent to the kingdom of Khotan, it is the land of the Tatars and Mongols, and there are two large lakes and several extended mountains with flowing water and a large city that is the capital of the Khaqan, and the lands of the Mongols are at the beginning of the third clime, and the lands of the Tatars are at the end, and there are two large mountains, and between those two mountains there is a barrier,
that
and a passage through which soldiers are stationed on both sides at the head of the valley.
After that are the last cities of the kingdom of China, Khata, and Tatar, and from the side of
page_texts.85:
Chapter Two
53
West, the end of the lands of Tatar was located, and in Khata there is a mountain and several valleys that contain strange things.
First, every year a stone rises from the top of one mountain and sits on the top of another mountain, and when six months pass, a stone comes from that side to this side as well.
And there is another green plant that, in the name of whoever is absent, is uprooted from the ground [and placed in a bag]; as long as that person is alive, it remains fresh, and the day he dies, it dries up, and there is also some of this plant in Māvarāʾal-Nahr.
And there are two other caves, each on one side, and there are many lizards in those caves, and at the beginning of each year they fight each other, and many of them are killed, and people go there and see where they have wounds, and from that they judge
the year in terms of abundance and scarcity, wetness and dryness, security and turmoil, wa ʿalā hādhā.
Furthermore, the ancient sages have built a mill between two pools and made a path from one pool to the other, and water comes from the pool and strikes the blades of the mill wheel and turns the mill, and it collects in that pool, and when the pool is empty and this pool is full, the water returns and continues to turn the mill, and instead of the amount of water that the air disperses, it comes and, like a continuous cycle, that water always comes and goes and turns the mill, and Abū ʿAlī Sīnā went from Māvarāʾal-Nahr at the direction of the king of the time to find out how that pool and mill were built, so that they could also build it in Māvarāʾal-Nahr for the comfort and convenience of the people.
[Abū ʿAlī Sīnā could not solve it]
Furthermore, when they pass this place, there are several mountains that are called Jabal Buhlar,
1- This part was added from the Russian version
2 Version "M": nashw.
3- This part was added from the Russian version.
page_texts.86:
54

Seven Kishvars

They call it and the first is the kingdom of Hind, and from the east is a distance of seven hundred farsangs, and it is the third clime and the length of the kingdom and the populated provinces, much cultivation is planted and many creatures and all kinds of domestic and wild animals and drugs and other goods are found. And at the end of the kingdom of Hind, which is the end of the third clime, is a city that is called

Qandahar, and at the beginning of the fourth clime is a city that is called Kashmir, and to the east of Qandahar and the environs of Kashmir is the province of Turkestan, and tribes and groups and sides are mixed together, and for this reason they are neither black nor white, and all are good-looking and beautiful.

Also, the southern side of this place is Ban Pul and the end of the lands of Hind, and some of the lands of Makran, and the north is Ghazna and Takinabad and Zabulistan. There is a tall mountain on the north side of Makran that is called Taftan, and on top of that mountain is a cave, and that place is Nushadir, and at all times a flame of fire comes ignited from that cave, and the steam of Nushadir sits and closes on the stones and earth around the cave, and it gathers, and that cave has become a divan and has been contracted, and the workers of that cave wear felt and cover their bodies in felt [and run lightly and have a spade of iron and strike at it and separate it. And if they throw a stone in that cave, it falls out of the cave's hole when it gets hot.

After that is Sistan, and Tabas, and Velayat-e Arba'a, and Kerman, and Sirjan. In Velayat-e Arba'a, Bardasir, Ardashir Babakan has built many structures.³ But this saying that in Bam there was a worm that gave forty *mann* of milky rice every day, and that worm was an apple that had grown so big, this is not reasonable.

¹ Apparently: Taftan.
² *Nuskha-ye* “M.” and Russia Bardasir.
²- This section has been added from the Russian version.
³ *Asl*: *chand* (several) *sibi bud* (it was an apple).
page_texts.87:
Chapter Two

55

It is not because any animal's *hayūlā* whose original nature is small will not grow large, and its creation and body are relative to the matter from which it came into being. For example, no sheep can become the size and shape of a camel, and a sparrow cannot become like a hen, and a worm whose substance of nature is a rotten apple will not reach this level, like other fruit worms and will die the same day, and when a worm comes into being from the moisture of fruit, it will never eat a green leaf or anything other than fruit, and it is impossible for an animal that comes from fruit to live for three months.

After that, there is an animal that they call *aknus*, and it is the size of a large cat and is red in color, as many as they are, they do not separate from each other and do not go alone, and in the area of Kerman and Khabis, which is the border of Zabulistan, they point out that they attack leopards and hyenas and wolves and other large animals and beasts together, and each one takes a position on the animal's body and makes a prey.

After that, once in the fortress of Kerman and the fortress of Sirjan, which is fifty years ago in this era from that date, they found a vessel that they had hidden in the ground, and there was something black in it, and from that compound they put a piece on the stone, it would break easily, and if they threw it on the ground, it would sink, and the wells of the fortress were sunk to that distance with the help of that compound. One of those compound medicines was for the blood of every horse. After that, when they destroyed it, they knew what its benefit was.

After that, there was an ancient city between Kerman and Zabulistan, which they called Sakza-ye, and water came from between two mountains and branched into two and the border of Khabis near the village of Saif, which they call “Deh Saif,” reaches and a lake

¹ *Nuskha-ye* “M.” and Russia Kanus.
² Russian version: *barkhun marast*.
*Asl*: *penhan be jay-e fana* (hidden instead of destroyed).
page_texts.88:
Seven Kishvars

appeared and many buildings were built and populated from it, and a branch went to the north of Yazd and Maybod and many places were populated from it, it passed from the foothills of a hill that is called *zāj* and went to near Nain.
