And a group called that water Rud-e Sakza and some Kaseh Rud, and before the Nishapuri earthquake, for quite a while there was a severe earthquake and from both sides of this mountain from which the water came, the stones broke and the valley was filled and the water stopped and the city of Sakza, which was populated by that water, was destroyed and other villages and buildings that were on the edge of those two branches of water were completely destroyed and became uninhabited and the lake on the border of Khabis and Deh Saif dried up and this time they call that place Shahr-e Lut, while Shahr-e Lut is in Syria, and the course of that other branch that went to Yazd was covered with sand, and in the north of Yazd there are still several hills that are called Rang-e Sakza.

Once Esfandiyar, son of Garshasp, stayed for a few days in the foothills of *Zāj* Mountain and on the edge of Kaseh Rud and founded a city and named it Esfandiyar, and this is a small village and they call it Esfanjud and some of it is covered with sand and the length and width of those colors and hills is about three or four *farsangs* and they call it Rig-e Dir. They say that one of the disciples of Jesus had arrived in that area and built a monastery and the Girans of that province destroyed it and its name remained.

After that, the middle of the world is Ma'mura-ye 'Alam, which they call Qubbat al-Arḍ and Sitrat al-Arḍ, and some of the cities of Iraq and Khorasan, those that are northern

and a few southern places that are Fars and Basra.

¹ Russian version: Zaraj Kuh instead of *zāj*. ² *Asl*: *tafiqa* ³- Russian version: Zaraj. *Asl* Esfajud correction from the Russian version and the National Library version.
page_texts.89:
Chapter Two
Hikayat
57
When Ardashīr Bābakān conquered Fārs, he ordered many structures and strong fortresses to be built. Ardashīr was extremely wise, perfect, prudent, and brave. One time, he fled, and an army came after him to capture him. They asked a Zoroastrian Bāzyār about Ardashīr's whereabouts, asking when he had passed by and how many people were with him, as they were going to capture him. Bāzyār said, "You cannot capture him, because he is a world-conquering king." They all became despondent and asked Bāzyār for his reason. He said, "I heard from a Hīrbad that any rider who gallops his horse in the desert, and a deer runs before him, sometimes bowing its head and dragging its antlers on the ground, that rider is a world-conquering king." As he was galloping his horse, he saw a deer running before him in this manner. So, the army turned back and left.
After Ardashīr conquered Fārs, the soldiers demanded their wages. He wanted to distribute them but could not avoid giving them to the soldiers, so he became very thoughtful and sad and promised the soldiers.
One day, he was leaning against the صفه‌ها (suffahs/platforms) when he saw a black snake going into a hole above the roof of the suffah. He told the people to bring the snake out and kill it, and to break the wall. They found a great treasure and distributed it among the soldiers. On the same day, a tailor who was the tailor of the nobles of that region said that several boxes of jewels and precious clothes had been placed before me.
And they say that Ardashīr Bābakān invented backgammon. The statement in the Shāhnāma by Firdawsī that Buzurjmihr invented backgammon in response to chess is incorrect. Perhaps they wanted to send something in exchange for chess, so they sent backgammon. That is, we also have a game. And this ḥadīth is evidence that backgammon
page_texts.90:
58
Seven Countries
Ardashīr made it, as he said: «من لعب بالنرد شير كمن غمس بده بلحم الخنزير ) .
However, in Iṣṭakhr of Fārs, there is a place called Kinārah, where several very tall stone columns have been built, each column consisting of three pieces of stone. They are very delicate and pleasing, carved, smoothed, and polished, and other shapes and forms have also been carved from stone. The common people call it Chihil Minār (Forty Minarets) and say that Jamshīd built it, intending to build a palace on top of it. In Arabic histories, there is mention of the palace of Ardashīr in Fārs, and it is famous, but we have not identified anything except this Chihil Minār, which they call the palace of Ardashīr. [And there is another mountain where many designs and images have been made, and stone has been carved, and it is called Kūh-i Naghasht, meaning things have been written on it.]
The water that irrigates the area of Kalbār, whatever is excess, gathers in the east of a mountain called Surkh Kunbān, forming a lake that is twelve farsangs in length and width, and it is called Daryā-yi Khair. That place is salty ground, and it has turned the fresh water salty.
The great city of Fārs, which is Shīrāz, was built in the time of Islam, several years before Baghdad, and its name was Shīr Sāz, where livestock would descend.
And on the southern side of Fārs, there is a desert near the village of Khabr, and
P
The tomb of Jāmāsp Ḥakīm is there, and despite the fact that Jāmāsp Ḥakīm was of the Zoroastrian religion,
¹- This part was added from the Russian version.
Today it is also known by this name.
Original: ḥayr.
- Russian version: Kirbāl. Original: khayr.. Paris version: jabr.
page_texts.91:
Chapter Two
59
had, and the Magians and Zoroastrians leave the dead to the wind, Jāmāsp has been placed in the ground, and his tomb has been built from pieces of iron stone. Now it is ruined and collapsed, and anyone who takes a piece of iron from there cannot find their way back and cannot bring it with them unless they put it back in its place. Any ruler or official who passes by on horseback in that vicinity will be dismissed and lose their position or die.
One day, Shaykh Jamāl Baṣrī, who was Īdar Chāgh, when Sulṭān Ghāzān, who was the ruler in Fārs, was passing by the tomb of Jāmāsp on horseback, the nobles said, "Let us turn the road or dismount." He did not listen or pay attention and said, «هذا من فنارات العجم » and passed by. In that same year, he was dismissed and died.
d
Afterwards, there are two places in the province of Fārs that are called Buwān, and it is said that God Almighty created four paradises in the world: Ghūṭah of Damascus, Nahr al-Uballah of Basra, Shiʿb Buwān of Fārs, and Sughd of Samarqand. Due to its extreme purity and freshness, it is called the paradise of the world. However, of these two Buwāns in the province of Fārs, one is between Yazd and Shīrāz, and to the east of Abrqūh, which is called Buwān-i Kirmān, and the other Buwān is on the side of Nawbandjān, which is one of the four paradises of the world.
After that, a plague fell in Khūzistān, and many men and women
said
died, and the rest had their brains scrambled and became mad. According to the rule «الجنون فنون, the requirement of their madness was that they would not wear any clothes, saying, "We are so lighter and we can do things easier and better and we do not need to buy clothes." There was a sage among them who ate and drank suitable foods and protected
¹- Original: ghāzī.
² Russian version: fishārāt.
Original:
موضعي.
page_texts.92:
Seven Countries
and treated his heart and brain and wore clothes according to his custom. The people of that region unanimously said that this ḥakīm is crazy, meaning he wears clothes unlike us.
Ḥajjāj bin Yūsuf appointed Kaylī and sent him to govern Isfahan, saying, "You are going to a city where 'its soil is kohl, its flies are bees, and its grass is saffron.'" Similarly, about Hamadan, they have said that the land is saffron, the walls are honey, and the air is oil, meaning walnuts and almonds.
After that, there is a place in Lorestan where a branch of the Zardeh Khānān water, which goes to Shushtar, separates and comes to Isfahan, and they call it Zendeh Rūd. And there is a spring of water that if locusts appear in a city or place, someone who has never committed immorality or sin takes some water from the spring and does not put it on the ground at all, and hangs it on a tripod in the houses, and a bird appears, and some say that it comes with the water, and that bird is called zurzūr in Arabic, and sār in Persian, and some call it kāsīneh karū. It pecks at the locusts with its beak and throws them away, and it also pecks at old women. And whenever this bird sees pain or harm, it eats olives and gets well.
But then, when a ḥakīm saw in Rome that a zurzūr had fallen, it was making a moaning sound. The ḥakīm saw that other birds of its kind were coming and bringing three olives, one in its beak and two in its claws, and putting them in front of it. That ḥakīm built a high place in Rome and constructed a bird-shaped figure out of copper and a device in it so that when the wind came and hit it, it would make a sound like
page_texts.93:
Chapter Two
A moaning sound would come from that talisman bird, and he had built it in such a way that if he put some olives there, it would slip and fall into a hole, and he had built a reservoir under it, and all the birds of its kind would come from that vicinity and each would bring three olives and put them in front of it, and they would fall into that reservoir hole. After the death of the ḥakīm, it became a dīvān, and thirty thousand *man* of olives were contracted for each year.
But then, in the west of Shushtar, there is a place called Dar Pol, and it is a large village, and they have built a *qanṭarah* that is three hundred and fifty *gaz*. There are many such large *qanṭarahs* in the world. But they say that they have melted lead and put stones in the middle of it and erected the columns of the *qanṭarah*.
And on the south side in Dar Pol is the tomb of Dāniyāl the Prophet, who was the originator of *raml*, and he appeared during the caliphate of ʿUmar, and his tomb is made of glass. Wherever his burial place was, there would be a lot of rain. One night, the people of Dez Pol came to Shushtar and took his tomb and buried it in this place, which was beside a flowing water. The water increased and fell on the grave and passed over it, and now four columns have been erected on four sides of Dāniyāl's grave and covered, and another grave has been built opposite his tomb, and many fish gather there and no one catches them and they do not run away from people. And from Dez Pol to the tomb of Dāniyāl [the Prophet], peace be upon him, is seven *farsang*.
And after that, there is a city located on the shore of a gulf that stretches from the Sea of Oman. But then, when they pass this place, there is Baghdad, Madāʾin, Kufa, Hīt, Anbār, and the desert of Babylon where the well of Hārūt and Mārūt is located, and
in the south of Kufa, Najaf and the people of Bādiyat Ḥijāz.
page_texts.94:
62
Seven Countries
And the Tāq Kisrā, which is in Madāʾin, is made of brick and plaster, and it is eighty *gaz* long and sixty *gaz* wide, and the front of the arch is broken and cracked on both sides to the ground. Madāʾin was a large city, and the army of Islam destroyed it, and from the arch to the Shaṭṭ Dijla is about three hundred steps, and there was a bridge there. One of the Akāsireh died and his son was placed on the throne. One day, the sound of a conflict came from the bridge. The son asked, "What is this conflict?" They said, "A group of people from both sides with goods and animals have met in the middle of the bridge and cannot pass each other." The prince said, "Build another bridge next to it and specify that whoever comes from that side should pass from this bridge and from this side to that side, so that no people should pass each other." The commanders and ministers were very happy and showed joy and scattered trays of gold, saying that the judgment he had made had not occurred to any sane person and no one had thought of it.
And after that, when the army of Islam came and destroyed Madāʾin and Yazdegerd fled, they found much of the wisdom of the Greeks, and ʿUmar said, "These books are of no use to us, and the book of the Quran is enough for us." They destroyed all of them and
burned them.
But then, they founded Baghdad, and there was a large garden that they had designed, and it would not be good without adding that garden, and the owner would not sell or give that garden, and they did not want to take it from him by force, and several days passed. After that, they satisfied the owner of the garden, and he gave the garden, and it was said on the tongue of the workers and a group of non-Arabs who had come from around that "*Bāgh dādeh*" and became famous by this name.
And it is mentioned in history that they had built an arch on the head of the Dijla water, which was a *qanṭarah*
page_texts.95:
Chapter Two
63
There was a bridge, and people would cross that bridge, and this was before the construction of Baghdad. The city of Hilla was built before Baghdad, and the water of the Euphrates, which comes from the direction of Rome, passes through Hilla, and a branch of it has been brought to Baghdad, and they cultivate with it, and they call it the Nahr ‘Īsā, and another branch has been taken by the Sahib al-Diwan to Kufa. And from Hilla to Kufa was ten leagues, and in between there is a Dami which they call Biʾr Mallāja, and Dhūʾl-Kifl, peace be upon him, is placed in Biʾr Mallāja, and from Kufa to Najaf, which is the edge of the desert wilderness, is one and a half leagues.

Tale
When the religion of the Prophet, may God bless him and grant him peace, gained strength, and many mosques, pulpits, and minarets were built, and the name of Muṣṭafā was mentioned on top of the minarets, the commanders and world conquerors of the surrounding areas and some learned, eloquent people envied that this fortune and happiness that Muḥammad, peace be upon him, had been given, why was it not given to us, and they conspired and agreed with each other and wanted to destroy and eliminate the religion of Islam. They never found any opportunity. And among them, a group from the city of Sabaʾ, which is in Yemen, conspired during the caliphate of Shāh Wilāyat that we should go to Kufa and oppose, and make the killing of ‘Uthmān a pretext, and say that ‘Alī is God, and the Commander of the Believers will like it and strengthen us, and when a force gathers against us, a power will appear to us and we will overthrow this religion.

So they came to Kufa and founded this meaning and misled a people
and deceived them.

The Commander of the Believers, peace be upon him, was informed. He ordered them to be killed.

¹ Russian version: baʿd instead of pīsh.
page_texts.96:
Seven Countries
and burned them, and a group of simple-hearted people did not know that this was a trick they had done and said that if we had any doubt that ‘Alī is God, now there is no doubt that God kills and burns people.

The point is that God Almighty has created three people as a place of trial for creatures: Ādam, Nūḥ, and ‘Alī. From the existence of Ādam, the infidelity and disobedience of Iblīs became apparent, and from Nūḥ, after a thousand years of invitation, they knew that that people did not have the capacity for faith, and from the existence of ‘Alī, those who were infidels and hypocrites and Muslims were distinguished from each other. And a group called him God.

And some gave him the title of the Seal of the Saints, and some cursed him, and the most correct saying is that the burial place of all three is in Najaf, and from Najaf to Madīnat Rasūl, may God bless him and grant him peace, is one hundred and eight leagues, and from Najaf to Mecca is two hundred leagues, and it is called the Arabian Peninsula, and this area is half within the third clime and the other half within the second clime, and there is little cultivation.

After Babylon is the district of Hīt and Anbār, and whoever goes to the well of Babylon knows something of magic and trickery, but it is harmful to the Muslim religion, and from Hīt and Anbār to the well of Babylon is a bad and unsafe and deadly road, and there is no path or road.

But afterwards, in the time of ignorance, they wrote a script in which a letter was two or three madds?

And a person from Hīt and Anbār reduced that old script and brought it in a way that is now called Kufic, and several people from the Quraysh of Mecca and from the side

Original: “the capacity to invite"
¹- The word imtiḥān (test) was added from the Paris version.
Correction from the text of the Russian and National Library and Paris versions. ³ Paris and Russian versions: muddat (period) was.
page_texts.97:
Chapter Derm
*A
Others came and learned and became famous, and after that Ibn Muqla wrote in this way
which is famous today and they call it the script of the pious. After that, when they pass this aforementioned place, it is the coast of the Sea of Qulzum, which they call Lisān al-Baḥr, and the coast of the Sea of Frang and Rome and the land of Egypt, lies between these two coasts. Qulzum is a city, and Alexandria and Damiata and Qayshara⁴ are in the middle of the coast of the Sea of Frang, and Ṭūr Mūsā, peace be upon him, is on the coast of the Sea of Qulzum, and the country that lies between these two seas is very prosperous and has many creatures and all kinds of blessings and all kinds of medicines and goods and fruits.

And in the districts of Syria there is a plant that they call Sirāj Quṭrub, which gives light at night, and whoever pulls that plant out of its roots will die immediately, and that plant has many properties, and when they approach that plant at night, it gives no light, and during the day, it cannot be distinguished either. They take some ash and throw it from afar on top of that plant that gives light, and they make a dog hungry and come during the day and empty the surroundings of that plant and tie a stone to its roots and throw bread in front of the stone so that the stone does not reach it, and it tries to pick up the bread. The plant pulls out from the roots
P
and the stone dies at that moment. And some say that it is yabrūḥ al-ṣanam
that when they pull it out, they die, and the root of burūḥ al-ṣanam looks like a human being
but Sirāj Quṭrub is something else, and perhaps burūḥ al-ṣanam also has that property.

And there is another plant in the province of Syria that turns silver into gold when rubbed against it
,

¹- Original: “mashhūra maẕkūr (famous, mentioned),” and none of the versions have the word mashhūra (famous). In the “M” version and the Russian version: “they do not see” instead of “does not give.”
² Perhaps Caesarea
⁴- also read Pīrūj.
page_texts.98:
66
Seven Countries
It becomes. The alchemist cultivates it and makes elixir.
And in the kingdom of Fars, Kerman and Syria, there is a plant with large, wide leaves that fall on the ground, and one grows straight up like an arrow from the middle. When that one branch is pulled from the ground, it has two seeds, one above and one below, connected together. The upper seed gives strength for sexual potency, and if an impotent man eats it, his virility will appear, and the one seed from below is the opposite.
It is well-known that in Damascus, there is running water in the houses, and there is a mosque that is very well-built, and twelve thousand prophets are buried in the mihrab of the Damascus mosque. And a city lies between Baʿlabak, Palestine, Damascus and Asqalan, and it is called Tiberias, and water comes and a lake appears, and it is called the Sea of Tiberias.
Furthermore, the kingdom of Egypt and Syria has many provinces and many strange and wonderful things. Some of them God Almighty has created, and some the wise men have made, all by the command and decree of God Almighty.
And between Syria and Hejaz is a city that is called Tīmāʾ, and it has a very strong fortress made of colorful stones, and the Arabs call it Ḥiṣn Ablaq, and Solomon built it, and many poems have been said in its description
And it has become a proverb.
After that, the Lighthouse of Alexandria, something very strange was built. And one of the wonders of the world is the Lighthouse of Alexandria, and its base was made of glass, and a shape was made very large and placed in the sea and water,
like a crab made of
copper,
and on its back they built the foundation of the lighthouse from glass, and from the side of the lighthouse to the edge of the land, they built aqueducts of glass, and the height of that lighthouse is four hundred and fifty gaz.
page_texts.99:
Chapter Two
67
They had made it thick and strong, so that three hundred and sixty-five aqueducts were built from the sides of the lighthouse from bottom to top, and on top of the lighthouse there was a large, bright mirror that showed everyone there the hem of their clothes and their number, and they could see it in that mirror. It is nearly three hundred and twenty farsangs to Qusṭanṭīnīyah, and when an army from Rome and France set out to fight, to wage war against the Muslims, when they started moving, the people of Alexandria knew about it and were busy preparing, repelling, and answering the army. The Franks wanted to devise a trick and destroy that mirror. One of the caliphs who had gone to Alexandria says that he was a caliph from the Āl ʿAbbās.
The Franks sent a spy in the guise of a dervish to stay in the houses of the Lighthouse of Alexandria, and he told the caliph that there was a treasure of Alexander under this lighthouse. He ordered it to be destroyed to the bottom of the sea and water. They found a crab-like shape made of copper, but there was no treasure. When they sought that person, he had fled. They realized that he was a spy from the Franks and had played a trick. Then the caliph ordered the master builders to be brought, so they rebuilt the lighthouse, and in the end they built two-sixths of what it was originally from plaster and brick.
But after that, ten farsangs from Egypt there is a town called ʿAyn al-Shams [and a garden of about three hundred and thirty towns that was seven qafīz in that ʿAyn al-Shams, and in that place the balsam oil tree has grown, and they take that tree and plant it in other places, it grows, but it does not give oil, and that is one specific place.
And opium and other beneficial medicines are found in the mountains of Egypt, as well as skinks, magnets, gold and silver, and abundant fruits, including the fruit of a tree.
1- This part was added from the Russian version.
page_texts.100:
68
Seven Countries
Which, when they put it in the food, they become very fat, as it is said that the women of Egypt become three hundred man and four hundred man to the extent that they cannot move around and need maids, and they die from obesity, and some husbands cannot have intercourse with them, and on both sides of the house wall there is a platform, and on it there are two rings, and a rope is tied on it, and they pull up the wife's two legs, each to one side, and after that they do the deed.
After that, there are the pyramids, and those are the large domes that the ancient sages built, and the distance of those places where the domes have been erected is ten farsangs, and what is smaller is much larger compared to the domes that were built in the world, and some of them have been destroyed, and all of it is made of stone. And in the time of Yusuf the Prophet, peace be upon him, they put the food in there for safekeeping.
Among them are three large domes, and two domes are larger than the third, and they are made of stone, and each piece of stone is ten gaz long and eight gaz wide. And those
two larger domes are Harmanīn. And each of these Harman is four hundred gaz long and four hundred gaz wide and four hundred gaz thick in height, and they are built square, and the tops of those two domes are brought together in a circular fashion, and they have been placed so delicately and cleanly that better than that cannot be imagined and cannot be found anywhere. And around those two domes, many writings have been written in an unknown script, very pleasant and delightful and on a high place, and in one is the burial place of ʿĀd [and] Thamūd, and the other is the burial place of Hermes al-Harāmisah, who is Shīṯ and Idrīs the Prophet, peace be upon them, and in the middle of those two domes several places have been dug and several buildings have been built, and the third dome is a quarter of those two domes, meaning three hundred
is not.
1- Original: simt. Corrected from the Paris and Russian versions, and the meaning of the phrase is clear.
page_texts.101:
Chapter Two

69

Goz in three hundred _goz_, and they have made it in such a way that it has a red color, and they say that a group that built this dome said that destroying it is more difficult than building it.

In any case, we built it, let them destroy it. Meaning they cannot.

And they say there was a Muslim king in Egypt, and a sheikh invited him to destroy the pyramids, and he was outraged that he could destroy these domes. He summoned all the well-diggers and laborers, and most of the people of Egypt agreed, and they spent a lot of money and spent some time destroying the smaller dome, but they could not destroy a little of it, so that it does not appear at all from a distance, and when they get close, that destruction seems to be something scratched. He asked the master builder, “Can what you have dug from this smaller dome be repaired with a thousand dinars?”

He said, "A thousand dinars will be spent on one stone, and it will not be so delicate and pleasing."

And in that vicinity there are several enduring pyramids that are very far away, so that as far as they go down, they do not reach the bottom, and they say that the stones from which the domes are made were taken out from there.

And also in this area there is a single piece of stone in the middle of the desert that is ten _goz_ by ten _goz_, and its height is eight _goz_, and a place two _goz_ by two _goz_ has been dug in the middle of the stone, and around that stone on all four sides every shape and form and industry with tools and instruments of every foreman and equipment that is in the world has been depicted, and their purpose was that if a storm comes to the world and the world is destroyed, the sciences and industries will not be lost from the hands of the people, but they should look at those images and patterns and infer and know that the equipment and shapes were in the world, and earn. And they say that if someone wants to subdue a type of human or animal, he must stay there for a year, because every year there is a time when those images move
page_texts.102:
Y.

_Haft Kishvar_

they do or it seems so in the eyes of the beholders, when he puts a piece of wax in that desired image, it takes shape and keeps it with him, it becomes subdued to him. A _khwāja_ from Abarqūh related that once a dervish came and my father went to see him, after that he wanted to give him a feast, the dervish did not allow it, he went into the house and immediately came back and brought all kinds of food and sweets and put it down, he was surprised. After a few days, he asked about the dervish. They said that he had died and had ordered that such-and-such sealed bag should be given to such-and-such _khwāja_. When they gave me that bag, I opened it in the house, I found a piece of wax that had an image on it. Immediately I saw a terrible blackness that had appeared. He said, "What is the service?" I was afraid and that wax fell from my hand, in that moment he picked it up and disappeared. After that I knew what the benefit was. I regretted very much that that dervish had subdued the spiritual beings.

But after that, a pond has been built in Egypt and a way has been made to the water of the Nile and several figures have been drawn so that when the water is increased or decreased, it is known from that figure, and the high and low prices of Egypt depend on the water, and there may be days when the price changes two or three times, and all the time they ask about the state of the water of the Nile in Egypt, whether it is increasing or decreasing. If there is abundance in Egypt and its surroundings, it is very good, and if there is scarcity, it is difficult, and the reason is that there are no _kārīz_ and springs of water in Egypt, and they can cultivate and sow only when the water of the Nile has decreased, and the increase and beginning of the tides of the Nile are in the summer, when other days it decreases and the desert of Egypt is all colors, and when the water of the Nile increases from the deserts of the equator and Abyssinia and Berber, a few black mud comes with the water and settles on that sand, and when in the autumn season the water decreases and those places of black mud are settled on the sand, they sow seeds and
page_texts.103:
Chapter Two

71

the income arrives at the end of the spring season when the tides have not yet started. And if in a year the water of the Nile increases a little, they cannot sow much seed and famine appears and this place cannot be called a homeland. Because in other areas water comes from _kārīz_ and springs all the time and in that season they can sow a little that is enough to keep them alive.

And this is not the case in Egypt.

The Story of the Famine of Egypt

When the conjunction of the upper planets around the year _tisʿīn va ḫams māʾa_ transferred from the earthy triplicity to the airy triplicity, it was the first conjunction that occurred in the sign of Libra. All seven planets made a conjunction together. Astronomers said that a storm of wind would arise that would destroy all the buildings of the inhabited quarter. When such a rumor of conjunction spread in the world, people became frightened and built places in the basements and went to streams and wells and took valuables and necessities. When the conjunction occurred,

there was no wind and the air did not move at all, they were surprised, because the sign of Libra has the image of a human being, it should have been judged that a strong wind would come. Although Libra is an airy sign, so that many people would be destroyed, although it has the image of a human being. _Khwāja Naṣīr al-Dīn Ṭūsī_ says that I wanted to say what sign would appear in the world from the effect of this, I went back in reverse, it was a sign of Chingiz Khan, who had more than ten thousand people killed by him and his followers. And another sign occurred in the Maghrib, which was the famine in Egypt and its surroundings, which had never been imagined or heard of.

A few years before the rise of Chingiz Khan in the year _sabʿ va tisʿīn va_
page_texts.104:
72
haft kishvar
In the year 797 AH, the water of the Nile decreased, and islands and hills appeared from within the water, and the water became foul and covered with algae, and famine arose, more severe than that in the time of Yūsuf (peace be upon him). At the beginning of the famine, all animals, halal and haram, were eaten, and after that people ate relatives and children, and after that they turned against each other and killed and ate anyone they could find. And an epidemic also appeared with the famine, so that several thousand people died every day, and after that they resorted to eating carrion, and it reached a point where they would bring the dead out of the grave and eat them, and wherever a bone fell, they would pick it up and eat it, and many of those people went on their way around and did not reach their destination and died on the way. Little was what we said in total compared to what was destroyed in the province of Egypt, no one was there, and all the abandoned properties of those people had no intruder or occupant, and in all places they lay dead and stinking, and a person who had come from a distant place to observe reported that wherever I went, I heard no sound and saw no one, just as *wa-liman al-mulk al-yawm lillāh al-wāḥid al-qahhār* and all that desert became a haunt of wild beasts, and that famine reached the kingdom of Syria and Alexandria, and many people died, and the famine and epidemic became such that they died by seeing and breathing in and hearing each other's breath and breath, and it is said in history that some thought they were healthy, and in one industry and craft, which took two hours, several people stood in place of each other and died one after another, and this epidemic and famine reached all the provinces and cities of Egypt and Syria, and the city of Quds was the worst compared to the bad cities.

And if all the people of the world that Chingiz Khan and his followers killed were to be, there would be no place for people in the world at this time. Historians

1 - Russian version: *wa khamsāyah*.
page_texts.105:
Chapter Two
73
It is said that it is an exaggeration that if there is procreation until the end of the world and no one dies, there will not be as many people as there were at that time and died.

And after that famine and epidemic in Syria, a severe earthquake occurred, close to the earthquake of Lot. It is said in history that such an earthquake occurred in Syria and its surroundings that the sea water split and a ship came to the bottom of the sea to the ground and then returned and brought the ship up and moved a place from one place to another and two mountains that were in the middle of it joined together.

A person narrated that in the year 773 AH, a severe earthquake occurred in Kerman and its surroundings, and it was more severe in Khabis, and many positions, gardens and trees fell to another location, and in Dhu al-Qa'dah of the year 741 AH, another earthquake occurred in Kerman, and it was narrated that two mountains came close to each other.

Question
How was it that in the state of an earthquake, a place would go to another place and a mountain would approach another mountain?

Answer
The earth has many cavities and is porous and the pores are open, and because the vapor that causes the earthquake is born and wants to come out, it pierces a place from the earth [and splits it, and that place that was open, of course, from one side, the parts of the earth do not bind together and become strong, and that amount of earth

1- This part was added from the Russian version.
page_texts.106:
72
Haft Kishvar
that has been split, the earth comes close to another earth and the mountain to another mountain. For example, if a carpenter makes a door from wet wood and fastens the boards firmly together, when it dries, the middle of the board will open. That is because the parts of the water have gone into vapor and the parts of the wood have taken its place and sat together.

Another example is that if a hard stone is thrown to the ground, of course a pit will appear and the amount of the stone's volume will be emptied of clay. However, that clay has not gone anywhere, but the parts of the clay have sat together and accepted compression.

But after that, in the area of Egypt there is a city called Kisum and a place called Hisn Mansur. And in the middle of it comes a large water and a bridge is built on it, which is called Qantara Sanja, and that bridge is a single arch.

It is two hundred paces away and it is made of marble stone and each piece of stone is ten gaz long and five gaz wide and on the sides of this arch, two other small arches are built that are large compared to the arch of this time and the purpose of these arches is that if there is a lot of water and the river comes to an end, some water will pass from both sides of the bridge and break its impact, and it has been said that one of the amazing things that has been built in the world is Qantara Sanja.

And after that, in the middle of the west and north of the country of Egypt, there is the country of Greece and there was a high mountain in the extreme north of Greece on the seashore and they said that this mountain is the veil of the north wind and it must be removed from the road. And they made a medicine from the same composition that we said, that in the fortress of Kerman and Sir Rajan, they found a container that they hit the mountain and the stone with, it became weak and they dug it out, they cut the mountain completely and removed it from the road. And after a few years, the tides of the sea appeared more than usual and fell in the country of Greece and became the sea.
page_texts.107:
Chapter Two
75
And in a history, it is mentioned that Alexander wanted to draw a gulf from the sea to a location, and for that reason, Greece was flooded.
And the air of Greece is such that whoever passes through that air will recall everything that has happened to them in their entire life.
Ptolemy the Wise, in his dying state, specified a mountain, saying, "Bury me on top of that mountain, and come on such-and-such day of such-and-such year, for I shall come alive." They wrote down the date, and some people did not believe this statement, and some said, "Ptolemy was a wise and virtuous man; his words cannot be meaningless." They agreed, and on the day he had promised, they went to Ptolemy's grave, and the journey was a distance, taking several days, and in that state, a flood occurred, and people perished, but those who had gone to Ptolemy's grave were saved, and they said, "His coming to life was this, that he wanted to save people from drowning."
After that, in the west of the land of Egypt, two things are said to exist. One, which the people of the world unanimously speak of, is the ʿAnqā-yi Maghrib, which the common Persian speakers call «Sīmurgh», and it is a proverb that no one has ever seen it. The other, which the Jews say, is that they believe there is a city that is five hundred farsangs from Egypt, and two tribes of the Children of Israel are in that city, and every week for six days, sand revolves around that city, and no one can come or go, and on Saturday it stops, and anyone who wants to come and go outside or inside the city cannot. And this is an impossible statement, for if there were such a city, travelers would have reported it, since merchants come and go to the farthest reaches of the east and west at all times.
Let us say another reason that will be a silent answer to the Jews, so that they have
page_texts.108:
76
Seven Countries
no objection or answer remains, for in the religion of Moses, peace be upon him, on Saturday, earning and seeking profit, work, action, and trade are forbidden. If a Jew works on Saturday or seeks worldly gain, he is certainly not a Jew, for with them, working on Saturday is a grave sin. So, a city from which Jews cannot come out except on Saturday—several thousand people and several animals are in that city, and they have essential provisions and necessities—from where do they obtain it, and how do they live? Thus, it became clear that the Jews are lying about it, and no such city exists, and their purpose is to say that our religion is right. Just as the Christians have the same idea, and the Christians' proof is the church, and we will mention it in the Fourth Clime.
However, after that, to the west of Alexandria, was the land of Greece, and a tall mountain in the north of Greece on the shore of the Frankish Sea, and they said that this mountain should be removed from the path because it is a barrier to the north wind, and when the north wind passes over the sea, no dust or foul vapor will be with it, and the air would be purer, and the sick would recover faster from inhaling the north breeze because the seashore is inside the kingdom of Egypt, and Upper Cairo and Lower Cairo, which are dependencies of Egypt, are also located in that area, and several provinces on the seashore are populated and have many people, and there are two other places on the coast, one of which is called Atu and the other is Tangier, and it is a province that has a distance on the seashore and is the end of the buildings of the Third Clime from the west, and Atu and Tangier have become proverbial. And this saying that the common people say, that go to Tun and Tangier, «Atu wa Tanjah» should be said, because Tun is a city
from the cities of Khorasan, and this is a famous verse, which is:
1- This part has been taken from the Russian version.
page_texts.109:
Chapter Two
To Tun and to Tangier, to black water,
To a place where no plant ever grows.
YY
Whereas in Tun and Tangier there is no black water, and green and
fresh plants grow abundantly, and there are various flowers, basil, fruits, and delicate blessings. And from it, they extract pearls with shells that have blackness in the middle, and they do not like it, and it has no fame or value, and Allah knows best.
Wallahu aʿlam.
page_texts.110:
Chapter Four
Regarding the Fourth Clime
First, a location from the beginning of the eastern construction in the fourth clime, some of the cities of the *moʿarrafān*¹ that we mentioned in the third clime. After that are the lands of the Yellow Robed, between whom and the Tatar there is always war and fighting. On the northern side, which was the end of the fourth clime, from the farthest east, is a mountain that is connected to the Barrier of Yajuj. And the city of the Yellow Robed is located around large mountains, and after that is a lake that they call Ghaghan, and another temple that is the pilgrimage site of the Christians, and this *bast* is called the Smaller Idol, and the Larger Idol, which is their great pilgrimage site, is in the farthest east in the first clime, which we mentioned, and they come from Farang and its surroundings to this temple that we mentioned and perform pilgrimage, and it is nearly one thousand and seven hundred *farsangs*, and around the temple there are many mountains and streams of water, including a very large river that goes to the city of Yajuj and joins the surrounding sea.
.
¹ Russian version: *moʿarrabān*. Paris version: *maʿrūfān*. ² Russian and Paris versions: *moʿāmala* instead of *moqātala*
page_texts.111:
Chapter Two
79
After that is the end of the Tatar territory and the beginning of the Khitai territory, and to the north of this location
is a mountain that surrounds a body of water, and that is called the Sea of Demons, and that mountain is the source of the Yajuj River. And another sea to the south of the Sea
of Demons is inside the lands of the Tatar, and in this area there are many musk deer, and Tatar musk is famous.
But after that, the Khitai lands are two hundred and fifty *farsangs* in length and width, and in it there are a lot of musk, silk, and precious goods, and Khitai musk is better than Tibetan
and Tatar musk, and the sign of Khitai musk is that it weighs about fifteen *mithqals* and has no hair on it, and Tibetan and Tatar musk is small, and the Tibetan and Tatar navel is better than the Chinese, and what is the navel of the Chinese has a lot of hair on it, and in the land of Khitai there is bad faith and metempsychosis and
trickery and deceit are abundant, and they throw the corpses of the dead into the water so that fish and animals may eat them, and some believe that if someone dies in a house, everything in
that house should be given to the washer, and most of the strangers are washers, and in the cities of Khitai, there are thieves and elegists and hypocrites and *mard andāz* and *nār* and many conjurers, and several people agree with each other and one or two of them are intermediaries and brokers and they take the property of a stranger who has arrived there by way of business. And one of their conjuring tricks is that two people have two boxes full of ants, one black and one red, and these two are fighting each other, and each of them has a small drum, and in a place where
there is a viewing spot for people and a crowd of onlookers, they come and put the boxes next to each other and each one beats the drum once, the ants come out from both sides and line up facing each other and stand still, then they beat the drum once more, and that is the war drum. Then the ants attack each other from both sides and wound each other with their teeth and become mixed together like a mountain. After that, when they want
page_texts.112:
80
Seven Countries
to separate from each other, they beat the same drum, the ants release each other
and go back to the box, and in this way they take something from the people.
And most of the cities of Khitai are cold, and a lot of lightning flashes, and sometimes
a stone falls from the lightning. As Abu ʿAli took that stone and put it in a crucible
to see what comes out of it, everything went out in vapor and nothing remained,
and a person narrated that he had seen in Qazvin that a stone came to the ground from the middle
of the lightning, and in the era of Abu ʿAli Sīnā, a stone of three hundred *mans* came down from the air,
and they found in a history that after Abuʿali Sīnā, a few years later, a stone of fifty *mans* fell from
the sky to the ground.
And a person narrated that he had seen in the hot region of Fars that a villager
with firewood was passing by when a round stone came to the ground from the air in front of him, which was about
thirty *mans*. We asked him that it must be apparent that all of its parts
were seated together. He said, yes, that is so, and the reason is that
every vapor that rises from the earth has earthly parts with it, and
in the heavenly effects they say that they have seen chaff with hail, and when earthly parts
.
become dense together, they suddenly become heavy and come to the ground.
And there are several animals that take on the form of creation and composition
for one hour, and God Almighty creates it for one hour. His saying: *ʾiḏā ʾaradnā šayʾan ʾan yaqūla lahū kun fayakūn* and one of them is a lizard and a snake and a fly.
¹ - The (M) version does not have the phrase "in Qazvin." Russian version: in Qazvin. Paris version: In the hot region of Pars, a villager with firewood was passing by when a solitary stone came to the ground from the air, which was about thirty *mans*. Apparently, there is an omission, because later the discussion will be about the hot region of Pars.
page_texts.113:
Chapter Two

81

And if from a meadow covered with animal dung, mixed with mud and become rotten, a vapor rises in the spring season, then immediately the earthly elements will take the form of snakes and frogs and rain down, and they will be extremely small. As in the Chagh of Sultan Abu Saʿīd in Sultāniyya and the surrounding areas of Buzgh, it had rained, so that the entire surface of the earth was seen as frogs, and flies also appear in less than an hour. And if someone in the spring season, when the air is extremely temperate, is careful when the tray is full of ripe foods, steam rises from it and if he puts it down, it immediately takes the form of a fly in the air, and if they remove the tray late, it will come and sit on the food. *kull shayʾ yarjiʿu ila aṣlihi* and the sign of that is that some flies are extremely small and transparent. It is also possible for small stones to rain from the air, and the reason for this is that much of the earth turns into stone water.

Between Kermān and Bam is a place called Rāyīn. One day I was passing by and found streams of stone next to each other. I asked, "What are these stone streams for?" They said, "We have passed water through these streams and they have turned to stone and the streams have become narrow and we have diverted the water to another path, and every few days we have to cut a new stream to let the water pass, because the water turns to stone in a short time."

For example, if an earthquake occurs on land that has this property, a vapor will rise, and if there is hail or rain on the way at that moment, as the vapor and rain meet, they will turn to stone and they say that stone has rained. And Abū ʿAlī Sīnā says that

When God's wrath and torment come upon a people, He gives the elements of the earth so much strength that all animals and plants turn to stone.

1- The Russian version: Abū Saʿīd.
2 Russian version: Nāṣiḥ.
.
2- Original: burdam.
Original: bādīya.
page_texts.114:
82

The Seven Countries

After that, in the mountains of Khitāy, there is a stone called *ḥajar al-maṭar*, and some are white, some are earth-colored, some are red and piebald, and some people say that it is in their stomachs and is born from there, and when it wants wind and rain and cold and snow and hail to come in a season of the year, they cut that stone and put it there, and this sign appears to the extent that they say that if they want cold and snow and rain on one side and sunshine and good weather on the other side, and each stone is specific to an order of specific signs, and a group believes that they are all one stone, the difference appears in the situation.

But after that in.

Salt is scarce in Khitāy, and the place where salt is found is a month's journey from Khitāy, and there are mostly wells on the way, and several large mountains in the middle of the Khitāy salt desert, that if there were no mountains, the salt route would be shorter, and there is a place like a ladder, step by step, and from the bottom to the top of the mountain, ropes are tied, and pedestrians tie several *man* of salt on their backs and take hold of it and go to the top of the mountain, and from there it is very close to Khitāy, and sometimes the rope breaks or the top of the rope is released, they fall down and perish.

After that is Delhi, which is the most important city in India, and it is located at the beginning of the fourth clime, and the north of Delhi, which is the end of the fourth clime, is the lands of Turkestan, and a very large mountain stretches between the fourth clime, which is a distance of one hundred *farsangs*, and a lake in the middle of that mountain from the springs that have appeared from all sides, and in the vicinity there were many people and livestock, and most are good-looking and savage, and some of them know less gold and silver.

1- This part was added from the Russian version.
page_texts.115:
Chapter Two

recognize.

83

It is mentioned in a history that a sage was in India, a year or two before Noah's flood, he told the people that all seven planets would be in conjunction at the end of the Pisces constellation, and by the command of God Almighty, it seems that so much rain will fall that nothing will remain! No building will remain and all the buildings on earth will be destroyed, and I will teach you a lesson to be saved. He ordered them to prepare many gourds and dry them well, then they found a flat desert and said that these gourds should be placed side by side and wood should be placed around them and fastened with rope, and everyone should make a place for themselves and connect them together and make them into one piece. If what I am saying is so, you will be saved before taking action, and if it does not happen, the gourd, wood, and rope will not go anywhere, and about twelve *farsangs* by twelve *farsangs* of gourds were placed side by side and made into one piece, and each marked their place. When the rain began, the beginning of the rain was on Tuesday until Friday, not a single moment of rest. The creatures of that side each moved to their place and took precious goods and *mā yaḥtāj* and several months' worth of food with them, and when the water overcame, it rose and came to the surface of the water, and they had no news of Prophet Noah, peace be upon him, who had built a ship because Noah's invitation had not reached them. After that, when the water subsided and those people reached the land, no building remained and they did not know what place it was and where they had been before, and they founded a city and that is Delhi, and they say that in their language Delhi means to descend to a place.

Question

If someone says that Noah the Prophet prayed "*Rabbi lā taḏar ʿalā al-arḍ min al-ghāfirīn dayyāra* and God Almighty promised that We will drown them in water and

1- In the (M) version, *zarr* recognize.
page_texts.116:
AY
haft kishvar
Al-Ghāfir ibn Dhiyāra, and God Almighty promised that we will drown them with water, and Nūḥ ʿalayhi al-salām built the ark, how can a wise man know that the flood was from the influence of the stars in the water sign?

Answer

The answer is that God Almighty has made everything the cause of something else. Just as prayer, fasting, Hajj, and Zakāt are obligatory for Muslims, the cycle and movement of the sun and moon are also the cause of the times of those obligations. The ages and years pass through it, and through the light of the moon and sun, the time of every opportunity appears, and they perform.

After that, we have seen many times in Baghdad that they close the door frame. And they tie inflated waterskins to all four sides of those woods, and they put ten to fifteen thousand ratl on it, and people sit on it and throw it on the water of the Tigris, and they bring a gourd from a distant place to Baghdad that can hold ten man of water. If they throw it on the water, it can carry thirty man of load, and [a waterskin that can hold thirty man of water], if they inflate it and throw it on the water, it can carry one hundred man, and the reason for this is that air is more subtle than water and its center is at a higher level.

But after that, in the beginning of the fourth clime is Kashmir, and in the middle of the clime is the end of the cities of Turkestan, and since Kashmir is located between India and Turkestan, its people are neither black nor white, and they are very beautiful because the people of that province intermarry and mix with each other, and a group around Kashmir
page_texts.117:
bāb dūm
85

are those whose women's vaginas appear circular. And they say that in the region of

Habasha there are people like this.

And in the year arbaʿīn wa sabʿimāya, a person in Kermān narrated that this year in this place I saw a strange woman begging, and just as we described, and her appearance, form, and face showed that she was from the province of Kashmir.

And after that is Bāb al-Barāmika, and that is a province that in ancient times had the religion of

Majūs and were a prosperous people, possessing generosity, honor, and reputation, and the elders of that province agreed and built a Kaaba in Balkh to be equivalent to the House of Kaaba, which they perform Hajj and pilgrimage to, and they endowed abundant property and estates to that house, and it was built very elaborately, and whoever among them was considered reliable in origin, lineage, status, and wealth would be the ruler and trustee of that house, and they named it Barmak, and this is a name that is attributed to that house, just as the great and chief of the

people are called Mihtar and Sarwar, in their language Barmak has the same meaning.

One day, ʿAbd al-Malik Marwān was saying that he wanted a vizier from the ʿAjam who was honorable, reputable, and sufficiently wise to be his vizier, because the Arabs do not know the way of vizierate and managing the kingdom. They said, "Bari, this Barmak is good." They sent a messenger to bring Barmak with as much honor and respect as possible. Wherever they arrived, they would welcome him and bring gifts. When he came and saw ʿAbd al-Malik, there was a stone on his arm that would move if someone had poison, and this stone is in the mountains on the west side, and Barmak had poison.

Immediately, ʿAbd al-Malik said, "Imprison this Majūs and put him in chains." Barmak was surprised as to what that was and what this was. When he found out the situation that
page_texts.118:
86
haft kishvar
why he was imprisoned, he said, "I have poison for myself because we are people of honor and reputation, and we cannot endure dishonor and hardship, and we have poison for that reason, that if a misfortune befalls us, we can free ourselves from death before dishonor and torment." ʿAbd al-Malik liked it and brought him out of prison and gave him access and he was the son of Barmak. From the time of ʿAbd al-Malik Marwān to the beginning of the caliphate of Āl-ʿAbbās, time passed and Khālid became Muslim, and Yaḥyā son of Khālid and other descendants of

Khālid
many

Barmak became viziers and were considered trustworthy and were famous for their intelligence, allusions, and generosity.

After that is Badakhshān, in ancient times there was no laʿl and it has not been mentioned in any book. They say an earthquake occurred in Badakhshān and all the mountains broke apart and the mine of laʿl appeared. First it was red, then yellow, green, and

violet.

But after that is the land of Mā Warāʾ al-Nahr in the beginning of the fourth clime, which is the southern side. Some of it is Kabul and Zabul, and at the end of the fourth clime, which was northern, is Farghāna. And just as the cows of Ṭūs were famous, so too are the cows of Farghāna. Once, the Qāḍī of Ṭūs was going to Farghāna. A great man said a couplet for the sake of the Qāḍī and the last hemistich of it is: ʿA cow is this one that goes from this house to that house. And in Mā Warāʾ al-Nahr, they have said that a scribe's son and a harpist's daughter are needed. There are many scholars and learned men, and Abū ʿAlī Sīnā was from Mā Warāʾ al-Nahr.

There is a city that they call Nakhshab, and a fuller was from the village of Nakhshab, who was named Muqannaʿ, and he knew and performed many illusions, talismans, and tricks. Among them, he had built a well from which the shapes of the sun and moon would appear. He said, "I am God," and he wanted to mislead a group, they intended to
page_texts.119:
Chapter Two
AY
.
They wanted to kill him, and they were thinking about his trickery and deceit, that they should go to him at night, lest he might have done some magic trick. Ultimately, matters became difficult for him, and he knew that they would capture and kill him. He frightened them by saying that he would go to heaven, return, and give them an answer. Maqannaʿ's intention was that since they would not see him, fear and apprehension would remain in the people's hearts. He lit a furnace full of fire and heated it intensely, and he killed the slave and the maid he had and buried them under the ground. A little maid escaped from him and hid. Maqannaʿ threw himself into the furnace and burned. After a day or two passed, they did not see Maqannaʿ, and they had no news of him. They investigated and searched for him. The little maid came and said that he had burned himself. When they sought his bones from among the ashes and found them, they knew that he had burned himself.

But there is another city called Ṣaghāniyān, and there was a scholar in that city who knew the Arabic language well and was known as Ṣaghānī. He wrote a book on language and began with «Alif» and wrote seven hundred names for *asad*. When he reached the letter «Bāʾ,» several volumes had been produced, and he died with the word «bukm». And it became a proverb that Ṣaghānī died with the word *bukm*.

After that is the kingdom of Khurasan, and it is said that the kingdom of Khurasan is the breast of the prophets and the highest place in the inhabited quarter; Khurasan is *qubbat al-arḍ* and *sutrat al-arḍ* [that is farther from the surrounding seas on all sides, and Khurasan and *qubbat al-arḍ*] were the center of the inhabited world, and most of the cities of Khurasan are very populous and have abundant blessings, and in ancient times it was the seat of kings, and many scholars, sages, sheikhs, elders, and sultans have been from Khurasan. And the city of Ṭūs, which²

1- Original: Ṣanʿān.
page_texts.120:
MA
Seven Countries
The shrine of Imam ʿAlī Mūsā Riḍā, peace be upon him, is there. They say that by the blessing [of the pure soul of that Hazrat, in Ṭūs, no hen eats filth].¹ Tūn and Qāʾin are in the first part of the fourth clime, and most of the tribes of that province and some of the cities of Qūhistān are loyal to the fortress of Alamūt, and they consider Amīr al-Muʾminīn ʿAlī, peace be upon him, to be God, and they deny prayer and fasting.

Once, a merchant saw a *bāzyārī* who had a red and pure face and thought that the appearance of his face was due to the effect of prayer, fasting, and prostration in obedience. He said to him, "Have you done much prayer and obedience that you have such a pure face?" He replied, "What is prayer and obedience? *Tawallā* and *tabarrā* are necessary, meaning *tawallā* to Amīr al-Muʾminīn, peace be upon him, and *tabarrā* from others."

After that, the end of the kingdom of Khurasan is Dāmghān and Jurjān, whose northern side was Jīlān and Māzandarān, and on its southern side was ʿIrāq-i ʿAjam. And in the mountains of Dāmghān, there are two things that are famous: one is a plant that they call «Kūza Tad,» and in the books of simple medicines, they call it *jūz māthil*, and it is a poison that if someone makes an extraneous movement while digging it, with good or bad words, and then gives it to someone to eat, that person will make the same movement and say the same words.

And the other is that there is a well that they call «Ganda Āb,» that if they throw something impure into it, immediately clouds, wind, rain, and lightning will appear.

Once, a king with a large army descended near Dāmghān, unaware of the state of that
page_texts.121:
Chapter Two
89
well, and he had an enemy who he did not see the strength to fight and resist, so he sent a spy to throw something impure into that well and ambushed his army. When the rain and lightning started, everyone got wet and became preoccupied with themselves. He drove his army forward, struck them, destroyed and defeated them all, and was victorious.

But there is a village in Jurjān that is a distance from ten springs from which they drink water, and there is a worm there that, when they step on it, the water in the jug becomes black and rotten. And when a group goes to fetch water, they put someone ahead on the way back to keep the worms away.
.
Once, a great man from Khurasan came to Damascus on a pilgrimage to Hejaz and told a story about the worm in a gathering. Those present taunted him, saying that he was exaggerating and speaking impossibly. Then he stayed in Damascus and sent a reporter to prepare a *maḥḍar* and bring it, stating that it was so.

After that is Tabrīz and the kingdom of Azerbaijan and Armenia, and the southern side.
Kurdistan and the western border of Rūm and Mughān. And Zardusht the wise was from Azerbaijan and studied sciences in Antioch of Rūm and knew astronomy well and accompanied Yūnus the Prophet, peace be upon him, for some time, and because he observed the method of prophecy and guidance of people from Yūnus, he liked it; he desired prophecy, returned and came to Azerbaijan and stayed in Mount Sabalān, which is a famous mountain, for fifteen years. He composed *Zand* and *Pāzand* and began to preach. First, he came to Ardabīl and invited those people; they did not accept. He cursed them and said, "O God, send countless plagues so that they all perish," and from there,

1 - Paris and Russia version: *ghaybat*
2 Russian version: *pānzdah*.
page_texts.122:
Seven Countries
Traveled, and after a few days, snowy and cold weather began,” and it snowed continuously for three days and nights, and the houses were filled with snow, and everyone died from the cold, and from Ardabil, he turned to Khorasan and looked to see where he should go to declare his mission. He came to Balkh, and they accepted his invitation, and it was the time of Luhrāsp; he went to him and invited him. Some say that he descended from the roof of Luhrāsp.
Luhrāsp said, “Who are you?” He said, “I am a prophet, and I come from God to invite you to God.” Luhrāsp asked him for a miracle. One was that he had a peerless horse, and all four of its hands and feet were sunken into its body and had fallen. He said, “I want this horse to be healed by your miracle.” Zoroaster gestured four times, and the horse became well and stood up. Then Luhrāsp accepted his religion and made it famous, and Gurshāsf and Isfandiyār and Bahman all strengthened and promoted the religion of Zoroaster, and Iran and some of the Turks, Indians, and Arabs adopted his religion. They presented the Zend and Pāzend. He made five things obligatory for them: agriculture, generosity, honesty, non-violence, and reverence for the king, and he prescribed prayer for them three times a day and made the sun their qibla, and at sunrise, sunset, and noon, he taught them some words to recite in prayer, and the words are: Ashm wahu wa hishtam astī ushnā astī ushnā ahmāʾī hītāshāʾī wa hishtāʾī ashm ـ bitā ahū vīrbawā tā ratūsh āshāt chīt hachā wa nigih ush duzdāmunihū shīwatini nāma anghih ush mazdāʾī khushtarīhā ahurāʾī āʾīm dar gū biyuddat wa istārm. They said to Zoroaster, “How is it that this speech does not resemble anyone's speech?” He said, “Just as God does not resemble anyone, his speech also does not resemble anyone's speech.” And he declared the menstruating woman impure, and any Magian woman who menstruates, whatever she has covered and whatever she has touched, should be thrown into the desert. They leave the dead to the wind so that each of their elements may return to its center. And they build a dakhma,
1 This word was added from the Russian version...
page_texts.123:
Chapter Two
91
Where they place the dead, they spread pieces of iron, and they place narrow dakhmas next to each other in all the land so that no vegetation grows, and if a plant comes out of the dakhma, they abandon the dakhma and say that the earth is asking for protection, and they do not place the dead on the soil because they say that the soil will become impure, and any income that comes from the land will be impure, and they do not eat food and drink from earthenware vessels, and since non-violence is obligatory in their religion, they do not slaughter any animal, and they eat from the slaughtered animal of someone who is not of their religion.
The Magians say that Zoroaster is Ibrāhīm Khalīl, and this fire that we burn is the fire that did not burn Ibrāhīm. But they are lying, for Zoroaster is not Ibrāhīm Khalīl, and other Magians say that God and Iblīs are two brothers. For a thousand years, the world revolves around God, and for a thousand years, it revolves around Iblīs. Surely, Zoroaster did not say this, for it is far from wisdom. And also, Zoroaster said that paradise and hell and resurrection and recompense and punishment exist, and Ahriman and Surūsh exist, and Surūsh comes to me from God, and you must not be deceived by Ahriman and strive for goodness. Therefore, Zoroaster did not say this.
And at the beginning of the Abbasid caliphate, the Āl ʿAbbās saw a person in Khorasan who had gone on top of a tall dome that had no way in from any side. People were amazed at how he had gone up. They asked him, “Who are you?” He said, “I am Bihzād the Magian, and I come from God to invite people to the religion of Zoroaster.” They brought him down from there, and in a short time, a thousand men gathered around him. Abū Muslim led an army against him and destroyed him.
After that, the northern part of the fourth clime is the kingdom of Rome up to the coast and the southern side, which is the beginning of the fourth clime, is the beginning of the land of Arabia and the land of Syria, and Mount Jūdī, where the Ark of Noah, peace be upon him, came to rest, is in Mosul, and there is a city between Mā Mardīn and ʿAkkah that they call Harrān; the buildings were all made of marble stone, extremely strong, and Hulagu destroyed it and said that if the people of this city rebel, no one can answer them.
1 - In the “m” version, after “spread,” the phrase “and they place a dakhma in one half next to each other” appears, and this part was added from the Russian version.
page_texts.124:
92
Seven Countries
the southern side, which is the beginning of the fourth clime, is the beginning of the land of Arabia and the land of Syria, and Mount Jūdī, where the Ark of Noah, peace be upon him, came to rest, is in Mosul, and there is a city between Mā Mardīn and ʿAkkah that they call Harrān; the buildings were all made of marble stone, extremely strong, and Hulagu destroyed it and said that if the people of this city rebel, no one can answer them.
And in the city of Harrān there is a place that they call Ruhā, and they have built a church that is one of the wonders, and they call it Kanīsat al-Ruhā, and they have built four columns of marble stone that are a thousand gaz in between the columns, and they have erected four arches on top of it and brought them together, and other arches are closed, like the arch of Qanṭarah Sanjah, which we mentioned in the third clime in the land of Egypt, in relation to these arches it is very small, and that church is nicely decorated and ornamented, and many lamps are hanging, and on the night of the twenty-fifth of the month of Nisan, they directly see a fire appear, and those lamps are lit. The Christians say that it is proof for us that the religion of ʿĪsā is the truth, and a group of ignorant common people who do not know that this is a trick and is also made by the Christians are deceived, and we will tell a clear proof of what that situation is, and what the Christians say, that Khidī sends a fire from the sky and the lamps are lit, is a lie. Because the situation is that the twenty-fifth of the month of Nisan was the birthday of Barkhiyān Muʿammar, and he was one of the disciples of ʿĪsā, peace be upon him, and he selected a separate Gospel from the Gospel of ʿĪsā, and on that day the Christians celebrate a holiday, and the twenty-fifth of the month of Nisan is the month of Urdībihisht in the Jalāli calendar, and the sun was at fifteen degrees of Taurus, and as God Almighty says:
1
a - Russian version: Barkhiyābīn Muʿammirān. Paris version: Barkhiyā the Prophet 2 Russian and Paris versions: was fifteen degrees.
page_texts.125:
باب دوم
٩٣
درب المشرق والمغرب. So, whenever they make a piece of crystal stone round, so that it has a circular surface parallel [to the sun], when the sun shines on it, no ray can penetrate it, and the air that is tangent to the surface of the crystal will immediately catch fire. Whatever is around that crystal will catch fire, and people observe this meaning very often. That clever¹ people hold a white-surfaced bowl in front of the sun and rub some tallow in the middle of the bowl, and it catches fire, even though it is not as hard as crystal. And if a piece of stone is made in this way in the west, and the degree of the sun on that day is made right to that degree, so that when the sun sets, the center of the crystal and the sun are right, and a thin string or a piece of silk that is not visible is greased with naphtha oil so that if a wind comes, it will not put it out, because other oils do not have that strength, and one end of it is connected to the crystal and the other end to the lamps, so that it includes everything. And when the fire appears on the surface of the crystal, the thin string will immediately catch fire and all the lamps will be lit, and no one's hand will be in between, and they will say that the fire has come down from the sky, and the crystal stone must be installed on a height so that if someone happens to see the fire, they will see it coming from above to the ground and away from the lamps. So that if sometimes there is a cloud at sunset and the sun does not shine in the window, they can secretly set fire to that
page_texts.126:
۹۴
The Seven Countries
There is a stone that they call Zait stone, which, when water is poured on it, a flame of fire leaps from it, and when oil is poured, it subsides, and we mentioned this
stone in the description of the third clime.
And Khwāja Naṣīr al-Dīn Ṭūsī has stated in the *Tansūq Nāma-yi Īlkhānī* that
a piece of this stone should be installed in a place, and a string or a piece of silk
should be attached to this stone in the manner we said, and the other end should reach all the lamps, and someone should sprinkle water on it in the manner of sweeping, and fire will be ignited from it, and it will catch on that string, and the lamps will be lit, and since the string is thin, it will not be visible from a distance, and they will see the flame of fire coming and connecting to the wick of the lamps, and there is no doubt that someone who has a water skin and sweeps will be surprised if he has not imagined fire, and while the surprise is in that church
and those skills of how they have built arches on top of those four columns with such a distant distance and built a church.
.
After that is the Sea of Frang and the island of Cyprus, about one hundred and ten *farsangs* in length and sixty *farsangs* in width of that island, and they are all Christians, and if someone
goes there who is not of their religion, they will torture and order hard labor and
imprison them at night. And there is a very large church there and countless blessings
have gathered people there, and [from] several merchants who trade around the world
with full capital, it has been heard that it is from the property of the church
and unmarried men and girls, in accordance with ʿĪsā, live celibate and in the church obedience
and they have made images of ʿĪsā and Maryam and placed them on high.
They do
And in Cyprus there is plenty of silver, mercury, diamonds, *dahnaj*, and tin and
there is alum [black] mine that is better than the Kirmani alum.
¹- This word was added from the Russian and Paris version.
page_texts.127:
باب دوم
۹۵
And on the coast of the Sea of Cyprus, on the northern side, there is a city that they call Mā Qad wa Niyā,
and it also has [of] these items that we mentioned, especially diamonds, and the diamond of Mā Qaydūnī is famous, and since the air of Frang and the island of Cyprus are close to
the air of Greece, its people are of subtle nature and intelligent and can make perpetual motion[and] wonderful things. For many of the wise claim that they can
make perpetual motion but cannot.
.
A person narrated that a Frankish merchant used to come to Tabrīz every year for trade,
and I became friends with him so that he would not do any business without my advice.
One day I said, 'I want to see your country, and I am afraid that they will torture the Muslims
and imprison them at night, and if they want to leave, they will not let them.' The Frankish
said, 'Come with me; it is my responsibility to bring you back to Tabrīz.' He says that I went
and saw many wonders. Among them, I saw a wheel that had wooden blades
on top of a well of water, and they had made it so that those blades would rise and fall back
together and draw water from the well, and if they wanted the water not to come, they would put a large stone on top of those blades so that they would not rise, and when they wanted to draw water from the well again, they would remove the stone, and the wheel would move without a mover
and bring water out of the well.
And the Franks and Christians have monks who rule that land and the wealth
of the church is under their control and command, and they live celibate, and from childhood, several people attend
to him so that he does not become exposed to a woman or desire or lust, and they train
him celibate in relation to ʿĪsā ʿalayhi al-salām.
And the Franks strive greatly in the pursuit of knowledge and release farts in gatherings.
¹- This part was added from the Russian version.
page_texts.128:
96
Seven Countries

And they do not consider it a defect if hiding wind in the stomach causes colic. But the way of the Hindus is worse, and there is a people who curse sneezing and vice versa for farting. And in Frank there is a white stone that resembles talc, and when they hold it in front of their eyes, things appear larger, and they make many for those whose eyesight is weak and who read fine script, because things and lines appear larger. That is because when sight penetrates it, it becomes thick, and it certainly appears larger than it is. Just as a barley grain or a grape that is thrown into a glass full of water appears larger than it is.

After that, there is the sea that continues to the west to the encircling sea, and several islands in between. And when it is about one hundred and fifty leagues from the encircling sea, the width of the sea becomes less, and there are many cities on the northern and southern sides that are coasts. Among them is a city on the southern coast that is called Andalus, and in the west of [Andalus] there is a desert and wilderness that is called Vādī Naml, and there are some large ants that eat people. And in Andalus, they have made a statue of a horse and a man out of copper, and they have mounted the man on the horse, and with the wisdom of a talisman, they have made that statue of a man move his hand as if he is calling someone, meaning come, and he moves his hand back, meaning do not go, it is Vādī Naml, they will eat you. And it is said that one of the things that the wise men have made is that it moves all the time without a motivator and guides people.

But then in the north of this sea coast, near the west, there is a mountain and a city that was called the Cold City in ancient times, and it is called that now, and the cave of Aṣḥāb al-Kahf is in that mountain. Arisṭāṭālīs the Wise has written a book on natural science.

1 and 2 These two words were added from the Russian version.
page_texts.129:
Chapter Two
97
He has composed and said that time is movement, and whoever is unaware of movement is also unaware of time, just as several people slept for years in the cave of the Cold Mountain, and when they woke up, they thought that only an hour or two had passed. And Aṣḥāb al-Kahf were nearly a thousand years before Arisṭāṭālīs, and when Aṣḥāb al-Kahf came out from before Daqyānūs, it was a four-day journey to the Cold Mountain, and Daqyānūs was the king of the West, and Arisṭāṭālīs is called the First Teacher because the first sciences were dead; before him, they were taught orally. When Aflāṭūn heard that Arisṭāṭālīs had compiled the sciences and put them in writing, he was offended and said, "He has taken away the honor of the sciences." They said, "How?" He said, "When science is compiled, everyone can enter without a master, and science and teacher are always despised."

One day, Iskandar says to Arisṭālīs, "Make a composition for me that will never be abrogated and that the people of religions will need." He made logic and named it the science of thought-measuring. But then there is a large city that is called Salb, and a sea with two islands, and the position of Qalṭiyānūs was in those areas, and in this vicinity there is much land and mountains, and useful medicines and plants can be obtained.
page_texts.130:
Chapter Five
On the Mention of the Fifth Clime

The first place in the far east of the fifth clime is the impossible lands of Yaʾjūj and Maʾjūj, and several large mountains in the middle of the mountain's opening where Iskandar built a dam, and from the beginning of the fourth clime to the seventh clime, this mountain stretches to the point where the end of construction is on the northern side, and likewise that mountain goes to the coast of a sea where there is a large island that is called Ġāzinyā, it is about two thousand and seven hundred leagues, and that mountain is named Qāf. It is said because Mount Qāf has risen around the world, which is three sides of the quarter of habitation of the encircling sea, and one northern side that is land without plants or animals and uninhabited, and there is no sea. This mountain stretches so that one end is connected to Mount Qāf to the dam of Iskandar and the mountain of Yaʾjūj, which is in the far east, and the other end is on the coast of the sea of

West.

1- Original: ʿārnyā Correction based on the Russian and Paris versions.
page_texts.131:
Chapter Two

99

However, after that, the regions of Yaʾjūj and Maʾjūj are extensive, stretching from the fourth to the seventh clime.
