Three sides are mountains and the Barrier of Iskandar, and one eastern side is the surrounding sea. From there is the Sea of Devils, and a large stream of water comes and falls into a narrow mountain valley with a steep descent, goes to the city of Yaʾjūj, and joins the surrounding sea. The regions of Yaʾjūj and Maʾjūj lie in a hollow, with the south side being hot and the north side being cold. Another river enters the mountains of Yaʾjūj and also joins the surrounding sea.

Once, one of the Abbasid caliphs, who was called Wāṯiq, appointed two men. One went and observed the Barrier of Iskandar, and one went to the far west and saw the Cave of the Companions and brought news to Wāṯiq, and they recounted what they had learned. The one who had come to see the Barrier of Iskandar said that near the barrier there is a hard stony ground and a very difficult path."

The distance from Baghdad to the Barrier of Iskandar is greater than to the Cave of the Companions. And they say that the Barrier of Iskandar is red in color, and it must indeed be so, as God Almighty says that Ḏū al-Qarnayn said, «اتوني زبر الحديد حتى إذا ساوى بين الصدفين» [Bring me blocks of iron, till when he had filled up the space between the two mountain-sides].

And when iron sees moisture and rain, it rusts, and the color of rust is red. Alchemists obtain rust from iron, and that rust is red, and they call it *zaʿfarān al-ḥadīd*, which turns yellow when applied to silver.

After that, there is a city called Kashīna, and in that vicinity are Turks, Mongols, Zard Qabā, Natar, and the like, and they worship idols, and most of that people have
page_texts.132:
Seven Countries

have no religion or creed, and they eat the meat of dogs and other wild animals, and they strangle sheep to death and do not slaughter them.

After that, there are many mountains and two lakes. Whenever a cloud appears over those mountains, it is red in color, and this is due to the earthly elements that have risen with the vapor.

After that is the end of the land of Khitai, and a desert and a mountain where ermine, squirrel, sable, musk deer, and others are abundant.

After that, there are several long mountains, and the beginning of the land of Turkestan, and Khānbāligh, and a city that Afrāsiyāb built, and there is a mountain in that vicinity where there is a mine of *dahanj*, and it absolutely resembles ruby. But Frankish *dahanj* is better, and they make vessels from it and cherish it. After that are Qaraqorum, Bish Baligh, Albaligh, Khotan and Kashghar, and most of this place is cold.

After that, the beginning of the fifth clime, which is the southern side, there are several cities from Transoxiana, and the northern side, which is the end of the fifth clime, is Taraz, Shash, Uzgand, and Aylaq.

After that, the Sea of Khwarazm and the rivers Jihun and Sayhun that go to Khwarazm, and Gurganj and Kat were Khwarazm.

After that, the Sea of Abeskun, which they call Khazar, cuts a distance of about fifty *farsakhs* in the sea, and Qarabagh, Mughan, Arran, Shemakha, Basarda, Tbilisi, and Rudkar, and the Aras River, which comes from the region of Georgia and goes to the Sea of Abeskun.

After that, there is a mountain and a thicket and trees, and they call it Mount Alborz, and in that vicinity there are people who are called Seksar, and
page_texts.133:
Chapter Two

1.1

The faces of their women are beautiful, and if they find a stranger, they seize him and put him inside, and they throw sweet apples to him from above, and inevitably, since there is nothing else, they eat it, and when a few days pass, they become fat, they kill and eat them, and if their women have the opportunity, they release them, and they say that in that mountain and thicket there are many strange animals.

And there are other people who have very thin legs, and they call it *duwāl pā*, and there are other groups who have tails like monkeys, thin ones that have grown from their rear, and the people of that province often fight with the Seksar.

After that, there are several very large mountains that are the source of the Tigris and Euphrates.

And after that, the kingdom of Qūniya, ʿAmūriya, and Greater Rūmiya, and after that Constantinople, Macedonia, and the gulf that extends from the Sea of Rum, and the city of Athens, which is *madīnat al-ḥukamā* [the city of the wise].
.
When the religion of Islam gained strength and the Muslims were victorious in battle and it became known that the army of Islam, every wound they inflict is effective and no wound from sword, arrow, ax has any effect on them, a complete fear and dread fell upon the people of Rum, and all that was gold and silver, they made it all into buried treasure and wrote treasure maps and went to Constantinople, which is a very large city and has abundant blessings and is farther from the land of the Arabs, on the seashore, and those treasure maps were kept safe and collected in a box, and most of the owners of property and treasures disappeared and scattered, or died, or endowed the Monastery of Constantinople, and now whoever serves that monastery for a year, after a year his reward is to open the box and
page_texts.134:
The Seven Climes

The treasure map is brought out, and they see how much there is and where it is; they give it to that person, and this matter is well-known.

And in Rome, they find a great deal of human mummia, which is a dead person placed in a grave in the middle of honey. And in the cities and provinces of Egypt, there are also many from the tombs of the ancients. And these days, some Muslims in Egypt and Baghdad make wills that we should be buried in honey so that we become mummia, so that people may be comfortable who are sick; it is better than decaying and rotting in the soil, and worms falling into our bodies and rotting us.

After that, from Constantinople to the island of Cyprus is one hundred farsangs of land and thirty farsangs of sea.

After that, when they pass this place, there is a sea and a large island. After that, there is another sea that they call the Sea of ​​Alexander, and that sea was cut by Alexander, and it was a populated province with many people, and he conquered the people of that province and appointed someone to govern. When Alexander was absent, they killed the ruler and became rebels. He returned again and conquered. And they still rebelled and drove out the ruler. The third time, too, in this way, after he knew that they would not obey, he told the sages to be careful whether the surface of this land is higher or the surface of the sea. They said that in the state of *mudūd*, the surface of the sea is higher, and in the state of *jazr*, there are several provinces and mountains in the middle of this sea. And they took precautions, and the vicinity of the city that they call Istanbul was closer to the sea, and water was taking over that province of rebels, and he ordered seven thousand mountains with a width of seven hundred *gaz* to be cut and brought to a small amount up to the edge.
page_texts.135:
Chapter Two
103
Water, and at the time of *jazr*, which is from the late morning, there were many people at work until they opened the whole road and went from there and descended to the height. At the end of the day, which was the beginning of the increase in sea water, water fell in that province, and when it was day, it was all sea, and all the people and other animals perished, and several sides that were on the height of the city went in, and they saw that a town remained, still appearing as a long island, and several mountains and hills that were in the middle were all uninhabited islands, and the length of that province that was flooded and became a sea is nearly one hundred and seventy *farsangs*, and sixty *farsangs* wide.

After that] it is nearly one hundred *farsangs* of sea with several islands. After that, there are the provinces of Qusanṭuniyya, Ṭarṭūna, Ṭulayṭula, and Qulabra up to the seashore, which has several populated and inhabited islands. Qusanṭuniyya is different from Qusṭanṭiniyya, and this is the name of an ancient city and province in the Greek language, and most of this province has the religion of Jesus the Prophet and live with wise qualities, and in several places there are Muslims, and in some they cannot be, such as Cyprus, which we mentioned, that they give hardship and trouble.

And in these provinces, most of the medicines and beneficial plants are abundant, and silver, mercury, and brass are abundant, and the weather is pleasant, and there are various types of plants, animals, and strange fruits, and there is a plant that, when rubbed on silver, turns it into gold, and for two months they cultivate that plant, it becomes the spirit of elixir, and when that plant is eaten by cows and sheep, it gives a lot of milk, and in the land of Sham and Azerbaijan, too, this plant has been found, and when the spring season ends, it is the end of the plant.¹

¹- Original: Because the spring season this plant.
page_texts.136:
Sixth Section

Concerning the Sixth Clime

The first place of the sixth clime is in the farthest east, the middle] of the regions of Yaʾjūj and Maʾjūj and the Barrier of Alexander, and the beginning of Mount Qāf, and the area of the length of Madīnat Yaʾjūj and Maʾjūj is nearly four hundred *farsangs* on the coast of the surrounding sea in the fourth and fifth climes, instead of the regions of Yaʾjūj, it becomes narrower towards the north up to the foothills of Qāf and the end of the seventh clime, and after that there are mountains and a very dense and large and small rocky area.

But after that, there is a desert, and the first of the lands of Qipchaq was cold, and sable, squirrel, ermine, and other animals whose skins they wear are abundant, and that people mostly eat the meat of animals, and in the summer they live in herds, and the sheep are tailless, and in these areas there are people who have a tail of four fingers joined together growing from their anus, and despite their good looks, they are beastly and savage, and they have little hair on their bodies.

¹- The word "*wasaṭ*" [middle] has been taken from the "M" manuscript and the Russian version.
page_texts.137:
Chapter Two
105
However, after that is a long mountain, and to the north of this mountain is a good land
in a pit, extremely swampy and rotten, such that a person perishes from the stench and infection of that land, and merchants avoid that land.
After that are many mountains, and the source of the long Āʾīl River and the Sayḥūn was there.
The long Āʾīl River flows for nearly seven hundred farsangs and passes through the region of Bulgar and joins the Khwārazm Sea. The Sayḥūn River also travels about the same distance and
joins the Khwārazm Sea in the fifth clime.
And after that is the province of Tibet, and it is nomadic and has a great distance,
such that at times merchants would stay among their livestock for nearly a month.
There is another province near the province of Tibet on the west side, which they
call Zāgh, and navel musk is abundant in Tibet, and after the musk of Khitāʾī, the musk of Tibet is good, and the navel is no more than four or five mithqāls and has little hair.
After that is Jabal Aṣfarān and the Khwārazm Sea, an extremely cold province, and there is always snow on this mountain, and around this mountain, it is so cold
that few people settle and do not establish a residence, but it is not without cold-weather animals, and the people who settle there spend six months of autumn and winter in warm houses.
Like bathhouses, they have opened under the houses and always burn fire, and from
the sides of the houses, they open holes so that the heat of the fire enters the house
and warms the house, and there are many sheep in that area, and all the time dīg-i bark
(Russian version: dīg-i pukhta barkar, with a fathah on the bāʾ and kāf) in the dialect of the foothills of Alborz means a large pot.
page_texts.138:
106
Seven countries
have put it on the fire. If someone goes from one house to another, they give them hot soup and āsh to drink, and after that, they go out so that the cold does not affect them, and when they come out of the
house, they do not stop until they reach another house that is warm.
After that is Sarman Rāʾī, which a group calls Sarāy-i Barkān.
And the northern side of Sarman Rāʾī is Bulgar and Rūs, and most of the people of that province are Muslims. And Bulgar is at the end of the sixth clime, and when the sun is in the sign of Gemini and
Cancer, the evening twilight and the true dawn are connected, and earlier than sunset, the morning twilight rises, according to this verse: « ان الصلوةَ كَانَتْ عَلَى المُؤْمِنِينَ كتاباً موقوتا » [Q. 4:103] prayer is not obligatory for them as a spoil, because they do not have the time for the last evening prayer, and when the time of  حتى تيبين لكم الخيط الأبيض من الاسود من الفجر comes, they will not find it, and there was also discussion about fasting in Ramaḍān. In this area, which is the end of the sixth clime, [the night] is eight hours, and during these eight hours, the twilight and dawn are separated from each other, and when the day returns and it becomes winter, the length of the day is also
eight hours, and the kings of Bulgar give sermons and mint coins in the name of Alexander,
and
they say that we are from the lineage of Alexander, and this is not so, except that they are from a tribe that goes back to Filīqus, the father of Alexander. Because Alexander never had intercourse with a woman to the extent that the wise men said that Dārāb has a sixteen-year-old daughter, of extreme beauty; let us choose her so that you may have intercourse with her once, and God may give you
a son to take your place, Alexander did not agree and said, I do not allow my body to rub against the body of a woman.
1 In the original, " بزرگان corrected from the version of the National Library and the Russian version 2- Original:
تصحیح corrected from the version of the National Library and Russia.
Because
page_texts.139:
Chapter Two
107
Also, in the area of Bulgar and Rūs, there are people who buy human skulls with curly black hair for a high price and hang them in their houses, considering them sacred
and boasting about them, saying that so-and-so has a black flag, and anyone who does not have that head in their house is not considered important, unless they do not have
hair on their head.
After that is the Khazar Sea, and in the middle of it is an island that
they call Barkān; indeed, Sarman Rāʾī, which is famous as Sarāy-i Barkān, is that. And Sarman Rāʾī was at the beginning of the clime of Bulgar and at the end of the sixth clime, and there are many Bactrian camels, and in the middle of both climes, it was more numerous and better, and in the end of that region where
Bulgar is located, from east to west, the altitude of the sun at noon in winter is seventeen degrees
or eighteen degrees, like the afternoon in Iraq and Kermān, and when the dragon's tail node is in
the sign of Virgo and Libra, in any month that the moon is in Sagittarius and Capricorn, its maximum altitude
is twelve degrees, whatever season of the year it may be.
After that, when they pass through Khazar, there is a desert and several cities that
they call Harqala and Harīna, and that province was nomadic and the end of the kingdom of Rūm
and Frank.
After that, a gulf extends from the sea and comes to the seventh clime on the northern side, and there is another city that is nearly seven hundred farsangs from the far west and the seashore and an island that
they call ʿUbūr al-Faras and Wasaṭ Baḥr Nīṭus, and there are several mountains in the south of this province, and in this distance, there are many cities and
provinces, and its people are intelligent and wise, and none of
them are Muslims, and they have different religions and beliefs, and some are such that they do not know religion or
nation, and the cold regions are moderate, and the air in this area is better than the air in Bulgar and
page_texts.140:
108
Seven Countries
Russia was more pleasant, and a mountain from the vicinity and coast of the sea extends to the east at the beginning of the sixth clime, which is nearly three hundred leagues, and it is called the Kūh-i Shār, and it is extremely beneficial, and there are many medicines and animals.
page_texts.141:
Chapter Seven
Regarding the Seventh Clime
In the seventh clime, buildings and settlements are fewer compared to other climes, and there are many uninhabited mountains and deserts, and the animals are extremely large and harmful, some of which can cause death just by seeing and looking at them. And at the end of the seventh clime, it is mostly at the foot of the Kūh-i Qāf in the eastern half.
After that, the first place from the farthest east in the seventh clime is the end of the districts of Yaʾjūj and Maʾjūj, and the beginning of the Kūh-i Qāf, which is connected to the barrier of Iskandar.
Furthermore, there is a mountain in the south of the seventh clime, extending nearly three hundred and fifty leagues, and on the northern side of this mountain is a very deep place, and there are savage people there who have human faces and do not come up from those areas, and no one goes there, and they have little cultivation and agriculture, and it is extremely cold, and from the beginning of autumn to the end of winter they do not see the sun because there are several mountains that are extremely tall and raised in their south, which cast a shadow of several leagues in the shortness of the day.
page_texts.142:
110
Head
Seven Countries
In winter, it casts a shadow of several leagues, and at the end of autumn and the beginning of winter, the darkness is greater, and the night is extremely long, and the day in winter is no more than five or six hours. And the closer one gets to the Kūh-i Qāf, the greater the difference between day and night and the more severe the cold becomes. And at the end of the seventh clime, which is the foot of the Kūh-i Qāf and the end of buildings, when the sun is in the first degree of Capricorn, it is all night, and when it is in the first degree of Cancer, it is all day, and that people, because the sun shines less on them and they do not see the body and rays of the sun for several months each year, [have weak eyesight because the rays of luminous bodies weaken the light of sight. And that people cannot make pots and bowls from clay, either because of the extreme cold or because they do not know how.
And a group of merchants goes to trade with these people and takes brassware and cotton, and that people have woolen goods such as qāqum, sanjāb, samūr, fanak, and ʿalā hādhā, and during the day the merchants place their goods on top of a mound, and they come at night and place something in return for each item of the merchants, and a mutual agreement is reached in absentia, and the transaction is finalized.
After that is the province and districts of a people who are called Iḥtisāj, and they are also a type of Qipchaq, and savage in nature and lacking intelligence, like animals, and in the north of this place are many mountains, and a strong stream of water comes from both sides of the mountain and a lake appears, and in the middle of it are savage and evil people, if they see a stranger not in their shape and form, they seize and burn them, and most of the food of that people is the hunted meat of wild animals.
After that is the city of Ṭayfūr, and we mentioned Ṭayfūr in the first clime.
1 - Russian version: Iḥtishāj. Paris version: Iḥtiyāj.
page_texts.143:
Chapter Two
١١١
It often happens that two countries or two cities or two places have the same name, just as Ṭarābulis of Syria and Ṭarābulis of the Maghreb, and another Barbarah of Zanj and Barbarah which is in the middle of Abyssinia.

After that, there is a city and a province and a people in those districts who know nothing.

After that, there is a lake and flowing water and several deadly deserts and man-eating and misshapen animals.

And after that, there is a high mountain, and water comes from that mountain, and a lake has appeared in the foothills of that mountain, and that lake is called ʿUnfawān, and because of the extreme cold it is frozen all the time, and the north of this lake is the foothills of the Qāf mountains; there is no habitation or people, and if there is, it is very little, and there are some animals whose sight causes destruction, and some deadly animals that people die from looking at them.

When Iskandar reached the seventh clime, wherever he dismounted, he sent some horsemen to the sides and directions to bring him news and information, and he sent a group to the Qāf mountains, but they did not return [and the second time he sent another group, they did not return, and the third time as well. Arisṭāṭālīs says that there must be an animal on this side whose sight causes destruction. Iskandar said, How can we know and what is the cure? He said, Order a large, bright and polished mirror to be made, and have several people hold the mirror in front of them and carry it, and follow the horsemen from behind the mirror until they reach the dead men and horses; when that animal's gaze falls on the mirror and
page_texts.144:
۱۱۲
Seven Countries
sees its own image, it will die. They did so, and it was so.

Question
How is it that an animal has been seeing itself all this time and has not died?

Answer
Poison is in the snake's mouth; when it hunts and eats something, it certainly contaminates its mouth with poison, and then swallows it; nevertheless, the snake does not die, and its meat is not poisonous; they eat it and make tablets. Because snake venom is in the snake's mouth and the snake's temperament is natural, and anything that is natural is not harmful or deadly, and this animal has all its limbs natural. Also, this cause of destruction is on the head and eyes of that animal. Perhaps if someone sees the back of it, they will not die.

Question
Then it must be that if there are two such animals, if they see each other,
they will both perish.

Answer
That other animal is either its child or of its kind. For example, if an infant is given a needle dipped in poison, it will not be so deadly, and if a little more of that poison is added every few days, when it grows up, the poison will become natural to it, and if it eats a mithqal of that poison, it will not die, and if it completely abandons it, a disease will appear. This animal has seen it from the first day or it was born from it, so seeing that
page_texts.145:
Chapter Two
۱۱۳
animal from the first day, whose gaze is deadly like its own, is natural to both of them. Unlike seeing itself in the mirror in a way that it has never seen before, that form and appearance seems contrary to the rule, it is unnatural, and since the characteristic of that animal is that seeing it causes destruction, whenever it sees its own head and eyes in a strange form, it dies.

Tale
Abū ʿAlī Miskūyah Iṣfahānī has mentioned in Nuzhat-nāmah-i ʿAlāʾī that in this region of the seventh clime, which is near the Qāf mountains and is a desert and uninhabited, there is an animal of extreme size, more than what comes to the imagination of man, and it is called Ṣinājjah, and there are several other vipers of extreme size, whose sight causes destruction, and this viper weighs two thousand manns, and in relation to the Ṣinājjah, it is a small worm, and the viper is really afraid of the Ṣinājjah, and the viper knows what its characteristic is, and when the Ṣinājjah intends to attack the viper and sees it, the viper dies, and if it finds it, it destroys and eats it, and the viper is always fleeing from the Ṣinājjah, and sometimes it suddenly passes in front of the Ṣinājjah, and when the Ṣinājjah, while unaware of the viper, its gaze falls on it, it immediately dies. And this has the same form that we said that anything that appears contrary is harmful and deadly. And since the Ṣinājjah dies in that state when it is unaware of the viper, it is prey for animals for a while, and since it is cold, it remains in that valley for days and does not crumble.

 طلبد,
After that, at the end of the seventh clime, it belongs to Gemini and Cancer.
The day was twenty-two hours and twenty-three hours, and the end of the seventh clime is twenty-four
page_texts.146:
114
Seven Countries
Hours pass, and when the sun reaches the meridian circle, its ultimate altitude
is at
Twenty-four degrees and twenty-five degrees, and the mountains have much shadow, and the beginning and end of the day are longer, and when the day returns and the sun comes to Sagittarius or Capricorn, this amount of twenty-three hours or twenty-four hours is all night, and for a while no one sees the sun, and if there is sun, no one can observe the solar disk because the mountains and hills on the south side are a barrier, and the shadow
Stretches several leagues, and for this reason that place is called ẓulumāt.
And Iskandar traveled around the world for the water of life, and they said that in ẓulumāt is the water of life, and for this reason he came to ẓulumāt, and this is a metaphor that there is no water of life in the world, and no one lives forever. Qāla Allāh taʿālā (وَمَا جَعَلْنَا هُم
جدا لا يأكلون الطعام وما كادوا خالدين).
However,] There are many mountains in the foothills of Mount Qāf, and a large body of water comes from those mountains, and it is called Nahr Ṭanā Barsā, and it joins a sea that is the Gulf of the Maghrib Sea, and the southern part of this river, which is the middle of the seventh clime,
is the end of the lands of Qipchaq and there are several cold cities.
Near Mount Arsānīyā is a place where they trade in absentia,
just as we mentioned before that there are Nūmī who are invisible to people
and they are the same in this place.
And there is a valley in a pit and in the foothills of a mountain from Bulgar to nearly two hundred leagues to the north, and when the sun is in Sagittarius and Capricorn, they have four or five hours of daylight. When the sun is in Gemini
page_texts.147:
Chapter Two
115
And when Cancer arrives, they have twenty hours of daylight, and in the lands of Qipchaq it is also
It takes shape with a little difference in relation to the northern and southern positions.
After that, a cold place is called the end of the lands of Russia, a gulf from another gulf that also stretches from the seventh clime, and in the middle of that gulf there are long islands that are one hundred and fifty leagues wide and it is called Jazīrat al-Biʾr, and in it there are several wells and pits and hollow ground, including a well in which when a stone is thrown, it sinks a little and then returns and falls out and no one knows its secret, and my prevailing opinion is that vapor has made its way to that well when there was an earthquake, and in cold places where there is a lot of sea water and moisture, vapor rises from the well more and more strongly, and like a spring of water vapor comes all the time and the stone falls out from where there is continuous vapor. For example, we see that children place a grain of grape on the head of a piece of open-ended reed and blow air into it, the grain of grape is carried into the air from the head of the reed and comes back, and the harder they blow into it, the higher and higher it goes.
and several cities that are Bartās and Bazaq
After that, there is another well in which the aṣḥāb ṣināʿāt say that there is sulfur aḥmar, which is the spirit of elixir, and when they project it on bodies, it turns into gold, and no one can bring that sulfur because it is suffocating and has a strange vapor, but it can be brought out with wisdom in such a way that they make two long sleeves from the top to the bottom of the well so that wind can come out from its sides, and two people put two blacksmith's bellows on it and blow air into that sleeve so that fresh air goes down and
Foul air comes out, and whoever has gone to that well inhales the air
that has gone to the sleeve.
page_texts.148:
116
Seven Countries
After that, north of this island, which is the foothills of Mount Qāf, there is a people
whose faces resemble those of dogs and are located between the two seas of Nahr Ṭanā Barsā and Mount Qāf, and those areas are called the Muḥālāt Kalābiyya and it is cold, but these places are less so in relation to the eastern sides.
After that, in the south of this large and small gulf, which is the beginning of the seventh clime
and the end of the sixth clime, they say that there is a well that no matter how much rope they put into that well, it does not reach the bottom of the well.
After that, when they pass through this gulf, on the south side, which is the beginning of the seventh clime, is the land of Bāshqirdā, which is nearly three hundred leagues long and one hundred and fifty
leagues wide, and on the north side, which is the end of the seventh clime, is the sea and
a large island that is called Jazīrat Ghārnibā, and that island is populated
and there are many creatures, plants and animals, and one hundred and thirty leagues is the length and width
of this island, and they say that on this island there is a tree that is extremely large
and rooted and old, that when the sun is in Aries, whoever asks it any question,
they will hear the correct answer from it.
And they say that when the sun was in Aries, Iskandar with
a large army boarded a ship and went to this island and asked several questions of this tree. One question was what has become of the state of my life, the answer came little, he knew that his life was coming to an end. And the other question was whether Iskandar
will see his mother again or not? The answer came no.
Deprivation befell Iskandar that he would not see his mother and the kingdom of Rome. When
page_texts.149:
Chapter Two

117

As Alexander's life drew to a close, he sent several letters of testament and messages to his mother, one of which was that when news of my condition reaches you, announce it so that anyone who has suffered a calamity or event may not come to inquire after you. This is so that his mother knows that this state and affliction that has befallen her is not exclusive to her, and this calamity has befallen all the people of the world. [However, after that, on the southern side of this island of Ghazniya, which is north of the island and the lands of Ba Shafarad, is the land of Saqlaniya, with sea, mountains, water, and streams flowing on all sides.]¹

After passing the island of Ghazniya, on the western side are two other islands, each fifty farsangs in length and thirty farsangs in width. Men inhabit one island, and women inhabit the other, with about thirty-five farsangs of sea between them. They have specific times when the men board ships and go to the island of women, spending two or three days in pleasure and enjoyment, and then return to their own island, striving for construction and agriculture. If a woman bears a son after he is four years old, they send him to the island of men, and if they bear a daughter, they leave her there. Some say that all the women are unmarried and accustomed to it.

On this island, there is a tree that sprouts branches and leaves in the spring, and any woman who eats a few leaves from it becomes pregnant. If she bears a son, they send him to the island of men, and if it is a daughter, they leave her with them. It is said that these women have a queen who is also a woman, and she commands all of them to earn their necessities and means of livelihood.
page_texts.150:
118

The Seven Domains

she commands.

Alexander wanted to observe this island and the women. Everywhere, he went as a messenger, saying, "Alexander has sent me." The purpose was that he boarded a ship and went to the island of women, saying, "Alexander has sent me." The queen of the women had a picture of Alexander embroidered on a garment and said, "You are Alexander," and brought the picture and placed it before him, saying, "I can kill you, but it is not customary to kill a world-conquering king. Return safely, and do not make any mistake with us, lest we become enemies of men." It is said that these women are very beautiful and shapely.

After passing this island of men and women and Ghazniya, there is another long island, about one hundred and thirty farsangs in length and thirty farsangs in width. Due to its size, this island is called Umm al-Jazāʾir (Mother of Islands). To the north of this are several other islands, large and small, called Jazāʾir Bāqir. All the other islands are inhabited, with plants, animals, flowing water, meadows, mountains, and deserts. Because there is no dry land around the islands, the cold is relatively milder, and the people are good-looking.

.

After that, to the south of these islands, which are in the middle of the seventh clime, there are two large islands, one of which is at the beginning of the clime and the other in the south, with the southern one being larger and more populated, about one hundred and ten farsangs in length and width. These islands that we have mentioned all lie in a sea and gulf that, at the end of the seventh clime, from the far west of the encircling sea, stretches for thirty farsangs.
page_texts.151:
Chapter Two

119

has stretched and comes to an end at the foot of the Qāf mountain.

After passing this sea and these islands, there is a prosperous country and province with many cities and countless people, mountains, deserts, flowing water, and abundant meadows. From the beginning of the seventh clime to the end of the seventh clime, which is the limit of civilization, from the west and the coast of the encircling sea, all the cities, towns, villages, and places of settlement for livestock and desert-dwelling people are connected. That entire province is called the land of Burtāniyā. The first place is called the kingdom of Burtāniyā, and a middle place and a last place, accordingly, and relative to that, it has a tropical and climate. They have much silver and mercury, but less gold. It is about three hundred farsangs wide and four hundred farsangs long, and the names of the other cities have been given in the Arabic language and are now known in the Greek language, and this is called the kingdom of Burtāniyā. Between these two kingdoms of Burtāniyā, a gulf has stretched from the encircling sea, about one hundred and fifty farsangs long and fifteen farsangs wide,

cold climate.

However, as we have made clear, construction and settlement are more abundant in the far west of the seven climes than in the far east. The people there are entirely flawed, imperfect, misshapen, monstrous, and evil, and they are fewer in the far west. We will explain this in two ways: First, in the far east and the islands of Dardī Akhḍar, which have entered the first clime, and in the other six climes, there is no sea that causes purity, humidity of air, and moderation. The air and cold winds in the far east are more and harsher than in the far west, relative to each clime separately. For this reason, dullness of nature and bestial characteristics are more prevalent in the way of the far east than what people are in the far west.
page_texts.152:
120

The Seven Climes

Another reason is that the planets have a full effect in the inhabited quarter [of the Earth], and in the far east, when the planets rise from the sea, they shine on the earth at a time that is the locus for receiving the planets' beneficence, which before that was the encompassing sea, and pure, simple water that has no capacity. قال الله تعالى يدبر الأمر من السماء إلى الأرض (God Almighty Says: 'He directs the affair from the heaven to the earth'). Every degree that rises from the earth, the sun rises, and other planets appear as well. Beneficence becomes synonymous and increases [and when it reaches the middle of the inhabited quarter, abundant beneficence is gathered, and when the sun and stars reach the west and set, they leave behind and hide all the beneficences, and for these two reasons, people in the middle of the world and the western half are more intelligent, discerning, and affluent, and construction and prosperity are greater, and defective and flawed people are fewer.

After that, the end of the seventh clime from the north, as we said, is such that when the sun is in the first of Cancer, it is all day, and when it is in the first of Capricorn, it is all night.

But after that, we have drawn five lines outside the seven climes, where there is no construction, animals, or plants. The first line is a place where there is a full day for one month of the year, and a full night for one month, and the rest are both day and night together, and the
page_texts.153:
باب دوم

121

and day together. And on the fifth and last of these lines is the North Pole, with six months of
day and six months of night.

والله اعلم بالصواب
page_texts.155:
Corrections and Annotations

11/5- مسطح کرهی is incorrect; the correct term is سطح کرهی. Dārā
9/16 وارطه apparently is the same word as وراطه on p. 6, line 17. Diyā
17/2- کرم مکنت and on p. 35, line 23 کرم نکت, and in the Russian version «انکت» and in the Paris version مکت are given. What is the correct form?
The word is unknown.

The word «بربر» (Berber) appears in later pages as بر بره. It is possible that کیه letters have fallen off the end. Kā
1/20 - بجز باباء متصل صحيح ا است. Mā
2/38 ذو الخليصه was recorded with a yāʾ in all versions, and apparently this is incorrect. ذو الخلصه without a bāʾ was a temple downstream from Mecca that ʿAmr b. Luḥayy erected, and he hung necklaces around the idol's neck, including a necklace made of ostrich eggs (أقرب الموارد).
7044 We do not know of a place called Mūghān on the southern coasts of Iran; perhaps this word is the modern-day Minūjān, which was originally in the form Manūghān.
3/45 The hair-worshippers are the same as the Ṣāʾīn, the remnants of whom are still in Ahwaz and Khorramshahr today.
15/45- لو كان قاتل عمرو غير قاتله. is correct. These two verses have been seen in various forms. For example, in the Muntahā al-ʾĀmāl, it is in this order:

لو كان قاتل عمرو غير قاتله
بكيته ابدأ ما كنت في الأبد

لكن قائله من لا نظير له
وكان يدعى اباه بيضته البلد

(Muntahā al-ʾĀmāl by Shaykh ʿAbbās Qummī, in Ghazwaʾ al-Khandaq)
3/56- زاج is apparently the village of Zārch on the road from Ardakān to Yazd, near to the city of Yazd, and it still exists today.

5.label: text
5.text: In the Name of Him Who Has No Name

5.label: text
5.text: The book that passes before the eyes of the esteemed reader is a book on geography along with the wonders of the world, which was written in the year 748 AH by an unknown author for Amīr Mubāriz al-Dīn Muḥammad (713-759), from the Āl-e Muẓaffar dynasty. Several copies of this book are available. The author first learned of a copy in the Tabrīz Library, which is a relatively old copy. He requested a photograph of it from Dr. Yaḥyá Māhyār Nawābī, who at that time was the head of the Faculty of Literature at the University of Tabrīz. The burden of this effort fell upon Dr. Kāẓim, who at that time was engaged in teaching in the Geography Department of the Faculty of Literature of Tabrīz. He prepared a photograph of the copy and brought it to Tehran himself and handed it over to the author. Gratitude for this is obligatory upon this servant. From this copy, the original text was prepared and compared with copies from the National Library of Tehran, Paris, and Russia, which were old, and it was prepared for publication.

5.label: text
5.text: The compared text was reviewed by the head of the Bonyād-e Farhang-e Īrān - Mr. Dr.

5.label: text
5.text: Khanlarī. He gave permission for it to be published in the series of books of Bonyād-e Farhang-e Īrān.

5.label: text
5.text: I have great thanks and gratitude for his attention.

5.label: text
5.text: The work of comparing the copies and comparing the printed forms with the corrected text was done with the help of

6.label: text
6.text: My son, Mākān Sotūdeh, completed it. The author is also grateful to him. I am thankful and grateful to other friends and staff of the Foundation who have assisted in the printing of this book in some way.

6.label: text
6.text: I am thankful and grateful to other friends and staff of the Foundation who have assisted in the printing of this book in some way.

7.label: text
7.text: Storey, when describing the manuscripts of this book, initially called it “ Ṣuwar al-aqālīm ” and put a question mark in front of this name, which shows that he himself had doubts and uncertainties in this naming. Blochet, in his description of the Āṣafīyah manuscript, has named this book, quoting from that

7.label: text
7.text: catalogue, “ Majmūʿah-i rubʿ-i maskūn-i Aflāṭūn ”. In the Īvānūf catalogue, this book is called صور الاقالیم ». In the publication of the Central Library of Tehran University, this book is known as “ Seven Countries ”

7.label: text
7.text: At the end of the India Office copy, the scribe has named this book “ Ṣuwar al-aqālīm ”

7.label: text
7.text: Publication of the Central Library of Tehran University, vol. 2, p. 122 . ۶ Film no. 1878 and photo no. 5103, Central Library of

8.label: text
8.text: In the Tabrīz copy, the name of this book is “Haft Kishwar”.

8.label: text
8.text: In the Paris copy, this book is called “ Ṣuwar ” al-aqālīm » or « ʿAjāʾib al-Buldān », and in its introduction in the film of the Central Library of the University, it is written . نسخه صور الاقاليم متعلق به پاریس تصنیف افلاطون حکیم » .

8.label: text
8.text: In the Leningrad Library catalogue, it is known as صور الاقاليم سبعه » and in

8.label: text
8.text: the first page of this copy, it is called “Haft Iqlīm”. In the catalogue of handwritten books of the National Library, this book is introduced as “a book on geography” and is given number 626, but on the back of the first page of the book, in old handwriting, this book is called “Misāḥat-i Iskandar”, and on a paper that has been glued to the page, this book is called “Juġrāfīyā” and its author is considered to be “Aflāṭūn”. With the various names that the owners of the copies, scribes, and cataloguers have given to this book, we could not find its original name, so we chose the two names “Haft Kishwar” and “Ṣuwar al-aqālīm” for this book.

8.label: text
8.text: The present book is a book on geography in which the wonders of the world are also described. The division of the inhabited quarter, which they knew until that time, into seven climes, took place in two ways: either the climes were circular, meaning that the land of Iran was in a circle in the center and six other climes around it, so that each of these circles was tangent to the other and tangent to the central circle. Then they showed the seven climes in the length of the world. That is, they would come up a few degrees from the equator and draw a line across the world; this was the first clime. The other climes were also located in proportion to the equator along the length of the world, up to the seventh clime, which is the inhabited area below the North Pole. Film no. 3108, Central Library of Tehran University.

8.label: text
8.text: Storey, vol. 2, p. 131. 9 Film no. 758, Central Library of

8.label: text
8.text: ¹¹- Handwritten books of the National Library of Tehran, Jā .

9.label: text
9.text: north reaches. The seven climes in this manuscript are such that the author begins with the east of the first clime and proceeds to describe it westward. Then he describes the second and third climes and the other climes. The Persian geographical book, Ḥudūd al-ʿĀlam min al-Mashriq ilā al-Maghrib, which was written in the year 372, exactly 376 years before this book, has the same classification.

9.label: text
9.text: The difference between these two books is that Ḥudūd al-ʿĀlam is a book whose author has not stepped outside the bounds of geographical topics. Whereas the author of the book

9.label: text
9.text: Haft Kishvar, when he comes to the major cities of each

9.label: text
9.text: country, writes a description of the wonders and rarities,

9.label: text
9.text: some of which he has seen and most of which he has heard.

9.label: text
9.text: Most of these wonders are outside the normal course of nature, and today they cannot be accepted and believed, such as a spring from which elixir is secreted, or masses of bird eggs that have become large white domes, or the manner of ostrich egg-laying, or amber wax from honey bees, or a baby rhinoceros emerging from its mother's womb and eating grass, or a whale which is an animal that has one hole in its body, and that is its mouth, or fish eggs becoming locusts on land and fish in water, or a woman conceiving from a tree, or a crowd of musicians who bring ants out of a box with the sound of drums and set them to fight, or a description of the excessive obesity of Egyptian women¹¹, or a worm that, when kicked, makes a jug of water big¹², or hearing the sound of the spheres that comes from the rubbing of the spheres against each other¹³, or continuous circular motion¹⁴, and the like.

9.label: text
9.text: ʾAyn-i Kitāb, p. 117 ¹¹- ʾAyn-i Kitāb, p. 68 ¹³ ʾAyn-i Kitāb, p. 25

9.label: text
9.text: ¹² - ʾAyn-i Kitāb, p. 89 ¹⁴ - ʾAyn-i Kitāb, p. 53 955

10.label: text
10.text: In contrast to these incredible wonders, he gives a description of other wonders and topics that are very accurate and scientific and lack nothing of today's knowledge. Such as the description he gives about silkworms¹⁵ and honey mines¹⁶, or the statement he makes about the connection between the evening twilight and the true dawn¹⁷, or the description he writes about the twenty-three-hour and twenty-four-hour days¹⁸, or the explanation he gives about the six months of night and six months of day at the pole¹⁹, or the guess he makes about the existence of the American continent²⁰, or the news he gives us about the author's eyeglasses²¹ which is apparently the oldest

10.label: text
10.text: Kraczkowski wrote the following description of this book in his book Arabic Geographical Literature²²:

10.label: text
10.text: Persian geographical writings increased in the fourteenth century (eighth Hijri). For example, someone named Muḥammad ibn Yaḥyā²³ wrote a book that was called Ṣuwar al-Aqālīm al-Sabʿa in several cases, but it did not always have this name²⁴. This

10.label: text
10.text: تألیفات جغرافیائی فارسی در قرن چهاردهم ( هشتم هجری ) رو به ازدیاد رفت . مثلا کسی به نام محمد بن یحیی ۲۳ کتابی نوشت که در چند مورد به نام « صورا قالیم سبعه » خوانده شده اما همیشه دارای این نام نبوده است ۲۴. این

10.label: text
10.text: ²⁰ ʾAyn-i Kitāb p. Abū Rayḥān also believed in the existence of a continent on the other side of the world

10.label: text
10.text: ²²- The original name of the book is Istoria Arabskoi Geog Craficheskoi Literatury. The writer used the Arabic translation of it under the name Tārīkh al-Adab al-Jughrāfī al-ʿArabī.

10.label: text
10.text: ²³ Kraczkowski, quoting Kramers, considers the author of this book to be Muḥammad ibn Yaḥyā, while the name of the author does not appear in any of the existing copies. Apparently, for the first time, the name of this author with his book under the name Ṣuwar al-Aqālīm appeared in Ḥāfiẓ Abrū's geographical book, and he writes that this author completed his book in India. Therefore, the author of the Haft Kishvar should not be the Ṣuwar al-Aqālīmī, which was written and completed in Kermān for Amīr Mubāriz al-Dīn Muḥammad. Huart, l' Afrique P. I, quoted from Tārīkh al-Adab al-Jughrāfī al-ʿArabī

11.label: text
11.text: Introduction

11.label: text
11.text: Fifteen

11.label: text
11.text: The book was completed by its author in the city of Kermān²⁵ and presented to Amīr Mubāriz al-Dīn Muḥammad (713-759), who was one of the Muẓaffarid amirs. A copy of this global geographical book is among the manuscripts of the Soviet Union. The chapters of this book, according to the description of the Russian orientalist Zalman²⁷ and from the article of the French orientalist Huart, are as follows:

11.label: text
11.text: The first chapter is about the generalities of geography, and the second chapter is divided into seven sections according to the arrangement of the seven climes. Rieu's judgment about the contents of this book, which has pointed to its brevity and disruptiveness and considered it full of myths, superstitions and children's tales, is harsh and hasty.²⁸ This book is full of fresh material about northern Iran, and "Dorn" has come across this point, and it has a great deal of valuable information about Africa, the source of which is Arabic geographical books, the originals of which have not reached us."

11.label: text
11.text: Some of the vocabulary of this book has an old recording and is worthy of investigation and study.

11.label: text
11.text: بعضی از مفردات این کتاب ضبطی قدیمی دارد و قابل بررسی و مطالعه

11.label: text
11.text: Among them are:

11.label: text
11.text: 12/18 - ḫirʿitābī: Zebra.

11.label: text
11.text: 13/18 - manj: Honey bee.

11.label: text
11.text: 10/29 - hamshīrah: Two people who are breastfed at the same time.

11.text: 918/46- There is something like a turnip that the Arabs call kamʾah and the Persians kahar and the Khorasanians samārūgh. Apparently, it is the same thing that is called donbalān in Tehran today.

11.text: تهران « دنبلان » می خوانند .

11.label: text
11.text: Huart, L, Afrigue P. 2. _YA

12.label: text
12.text: 18/51 - The word "morgh" (مرغ) in the past, besides meaning bird, was also used to mean butterfly. In 1360, that morgh is called "zurzūr" (زرزور) in Arabic, "sār" (سار) in Persian, and some call it "Kāsīneh Kord" (کاسینه کرد).

12.label: text
12.text: 18/67 - Three hundred and thirty *qaṣabeh* (قصبه) equals seven *qafīz* (قفيز). 12/69 *Pāyāb* (پایاب) means a hole that is made with a slope in the ground to access water or minerals.

12.label: text
12.text: This book is a small volume, and reading it is not without benefits. Its contents are not uniform, and there are many correct and incorrect points in it. However, it is an engaging book and indicative of the general understanding and beliefs of the time it was written.

12.label: text
12.text: Map and Table of the Book

12.label: text
12.text: The *Haft Kishvar* (هفت کشور) book apparently came with a map that has not reached us. The author says in the introduction of the book: "This humble servant, who has long been devoted to serving and supporting *Mobārez al-Donyā wa al-Dīn Mohammad* (مبارز الدنيا والدين محمد), and has been regarded by that gentleman with consideration and mercy, desired to draw a plan of the inhabited quarter for his library and to bring together in a composition a summary of what is known about the world.”²²

12.label: text
12.text: Again, in the first chapter of the same book, he writes: "And we have divided the seven *aqālīm* (اقالیم) and what lies south of the equator in latitude and longitude into two-degree sections, and we have drawn a table and written the names of some famous cities that we knew, so that it may be known what relation each city has to another, and in what condition it is, and in which clime it falls. And there are many cities that we do not know, for it has become known that there are nearly four thousand cities in the areas and surroundings of Khitā and Khotan (ختا وختن), and only a few of their names have reached us.”²³

12.label: text
12.text: In this map, apparently, the names of cities that were in Arabic before the author's time and were called in Greek in his time have been recorded. He writes in

13.label: text
13.text: this regard: "And the names of other cities have been established in Arabic and are now known in the language of the Greeks."²⁴

13.label: text
13.text:
In addition to this map, this book also had a table in which the author had drawn the summer and winter paths of the sun and moon with different lines. The author writes about this: "And we have drawn two lines for example, and from this line of the sun's descent, which passes towards the zenith, to that other line, which is the moon's descent, is about one hundred and twenty *farsangs* in width."²⁵

It is in this table that the difference in the hours of day and night, from the equator, where these two are equal, to the last point of the pole, which is six months of night and six months of day, has been shown by the author with different lines. It is likely that this table was combined with the map. It is a great pity that this map and table do not appear in the existing copies.

13.label: text
13.text: We do not have enough information about the author of this book, but it is clear that he spent some time in Kerman and has long been devoted to serving and supporting *Amir Mobārez al-Dīn Mohammad* (امیر مبارزالدین محمد) (713-759 AH).⁶² This sultan is from the *Āl-e Moẓaffar* (آل مظفر) dynasty, which conquered Kerman in 741 AH and Fars in 754 AH, and his son *Shāh Shojāʿ* (شاه شجاع) deposed him in Isfahan in 760 AH. The author wrote this book in his name in 748 AH. The author traveled to Hormuz and conducted studies on the coast of Hormuz. He mentions a mollusk from which China takes its ink, calling it a fish, and writes: “On the coast of Hormuz, it was observed that an animal had caught a creature that was like a wide shield and had a thin and long tail, like a rope tied to the edge of a shield, and had two wide eyes in the middle of its back, and its mouth was in the middle of its stomach and in the lower half.”²⁷

13.label: text
13.text: ²⁵ Ibid., p. 21 ²⁷ Ibid., pp. 50, 519

14.label: text
14.text: And about the sawfish, he writes: "There is another creature in the sea that has something long growing from its head that has long teeth on both sides, and the *qalandars* (قلندران) hold it in their hands, and that creature sometimes attacks ships and strikes the ship and breaks it,

14.label: text
14.text:
breaks it, and if someone is in the water and rises up, it strikes their waist and kills them."²⁸

On the same coast of Hormuz, the author saw and studied many creatures. In this regard, he writes, "And on the coast of Hormuz, we saw a hundred thousand species, large and small, that had been shed."²⁹

14.label: text
14.text:
The author sat on a ship from the coast of Hormuz and saw other creatures. About this trip, he writes, "And we boarded a ship in Hormuz and saw a creature that was extremely white and had gathered in large numbers, and their heads were like wide hats, and their bodies grew from the middle, so that the surroundings were empty, and when they fell on the board, they died immediately."³⁰

The author also traveled to the province of Fars and other provinces. He writes: "For we observed in the province of Fars and several other provinces that black clay is brought from the mine and placed in a crucible and melted, and the essence of iron is separated from it."³¹

We see the author once on the road between Hamadan and Baghdad. He writes about this:

14.label: text
14.text: writes: "And on the road between Hamadan and Baghdad, on the south side, a spring of sulfur was witnessed that came out like a stream of milk and solidified."²

14.label: text
14.text: Apparently, the author traveled to Baghdad by the same route and spent some time there.

14.label: text
14.text:
About this trip, he writes, "We have seen a lot in Baghdad and other cities that when a dump is filled, they pour lime into it and burn it, and what remains becomes stone and clay."³³

The author is a man of books and study and knowledgeable in astronomy. The explanation he gives about the stars *abadi al-khafī* (ابدی الخفی) and *abadi al-ẓohūr* (ابدی الظهور), and the calculation he made about the rising and setting of the star *Suhail* (سهیل) in Kerman and Fars, is sufficient evidence of his astronomical knowledge.

14.label: text
14.text: ²⁸, ²⁹, and ³⁰ Ibid., p. 51 ³¹- Ibid., p. 43 ³²- Ibid., p. 35

15.label: text
15.text: The author also has information about the science of Tafsir. He has written this explanation and interpretation about one of the famous verses of كلام الله مجید. Several branches of the Nile's water, which is sweet, flow into the sea, strike the sea, and go out, and do not mix with each other until they join the city of Alexandria and the sea of ​​France, and the verse « مرج البحرين يلتقيان بينهما بررخ لایبقیان » which the commentators do not know for sure, and God Almighty has mentioned in the Quran that these are two seas.

15.label: text
15.text: The copies of this book that are available are as follows:

15.label: text
15.text: The copies that have been used in correcting the text are as follows:

15.label: text
15.text: 1. A copy of the National Library of Tabriz, which was apparently written in the early tenth century. In 97 pages, 21 lines in Badanastaliq script, on the top of the first page, the scribe has written the name of the book as follows: « هذا کتاب هفت کشوره . The author considered this copy as the original.

15.label: text
15.text: 2. A copy of the National Library of Paris, numbered 858.7 - Persan 118 R, the introduction of which is بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم الحمد لله رب العالمين والعاقبة للمتقين and the end of which is تمام شد کتاب صور الاقاليم فى شهر شوال بالخير والاقبال شهور سنة احدى وسبعين والف كاتبه العبد الاقل زین العابدین دامغانی

A merchant had no capital left, so he went to Syria and bought a chicken for sixty dīnārs and brought it and sold it for eight hundred dīnārs, and this famine lasted for three years, and the one hundred and eleven thousand people who were shrouded at the beginning of the famine were nothing compared to what they killed and ate, and this total was nothing compared to what they threw into the water, and this sentence was nothing compared to what died on the roads. All of this was insignificant compared to what died in the houses, and this total with what in the province

And in Mahdiya and its surroundings, there are people who follow the religion of ʿAbd al-Muʾmin, whom we mentioned earlier who claimed that I am the Mahdi, and they read the book of jurisprudence of ʿAbd al-Muʾmin, and still the siksa of ʿAbd al-Muʾmin is valid in some sides and parts of that province, and in the mountains of that area there is a silver mine, and there is a lot of ببق and tin, and there is a mine that resembles yaqoot, and a group calls it بنفس and sells it at the price of yaqoot to no one. 35.label: text
35.text: الحمد لله رب العالمين والعاقبة للمتقين والصلوة والسلام على سيد المرسلين محمد و آله و اصحابه اجمعين . قال الله تبارك و تعالى سخريهم آياتنا في الافاق وفي أنفسهم حتى يتبين لهم أنه الحق .

35.label: text
35.text: To proceed: It is mentioned in histories that when Iskandar Faylafūs Rūmī reached the age of sixteen, by the command of God, glory be to Him, the ambition of world conquest spread in his heart. He sent to Aflāṭūn Ḥakīm, saying: I want you to draw for [me] a plan of the inhabited quarter of the world and the shapes and forms of the climes of the world, and inform me of some conditions and qualities of the horizons and regions of the world, so that I may become aware and gain knowledge, and so that you may befriend me and come to me, for indeed there is need for your presence.

35.label: text
35.text: Aflāṭūn drew a plan of the inhabited quarter of the world and sent Arisṭāṭālīs, who was the most learned of his students, in his place, and he became Iskandar's minister and began world conquest. This history was seven hundred and seventy years in the lunar calendar before the Hijra of the Messenger, may God bless him and his family and grant them peace. In a few years, he conquered most of the world, and

36.label: text
36.text: What could not be achieved by armies, he conquered through wisdom.

36.label: text
36.text: Since this humble servant, out of sincere devotion in servitude and loyalty to His Highness of celestial eminence, the Lord, امیر اعظم, مالك رقاب الامم, مولى ملوك طوايف

36.label: text
36.text: العرب والعجم, the Prince, Shāhzāda Shahryār Ghāzī, قهرمان الماء والطين, ظل الله في الارضين, المخصوص به عنایت رب العالمین, مبارز الحق والدنيا والدين, Muḥammad لازال مظفراً منصوراً على اعدائه و خلد الله ملکه, has long since

36.label: text
36.text: bound his life [to this service], and through the nurturing attention and mercy of that presence, this servant has been favored: he wished that for the library of that Presence, a map of the inhabited quarter be drawn, and whatever is known of the conditions of the world, a summary be expressed in prose; and if any statement appears wondrous, it be supported with an appropriate and reasonable account, [and] a few words from histories be cited as evidence according to the principle "العلام يجر العلام" so that it not be dismissed as conjecture, exaggeration, or impossibility, and that it be presented for review. تم بالخير ان شاء الله تعالى.

36.label: text
36.text: And this treatise has been arranged in two chapters:

36.label: text
36.text: Chapter One consists of two sections: Section One on the description of the earth and the measure of its dimensions and knowledge of the longitude and latitude of lands and the properties of places. Section Two on the description of the

36.label: text
36.text: southern horizons and the equator وما يتعلق به وينسب اليه

36.label: text
36.text: Chapter Two comprises seven sections: Section One on the description of the First Clime و

36.label: text
36.text: ما ينسب اليه. Section Two on the description of the Second Clime. Section Three on the description of the Third Clime.

36.label: text
36.text: Section Four on the description of the Fourth Clime. Section Five on the description of the Fifth Clime. Section Six on the description of the Sixth Clime. Section Seven on the description of the Seventh Clime and the limit of habitation in the inhabited quarter from the northern side, and some places where the difference between day and night is great

36.label: text
36.text: and the uninhabited region beneath the celestial equator pole

36.label: text
36.text: 1 This phrase was added here from the Russian manuscript.

37.label: text
37.text: On the Description of the Earth and Its Measurement

37.label: text
37.text: God, exalted and glorified, created the earth spherical and covered approximately three-quarters of the earth, leaving one quarter exposed, and this quarter is called the inhabited quarter. The water of the Encompassing Ocean surrounds those other three quarters, and several seas that have entered upon the land are within the inhabited quarter, and deadly deserts and salt marshes and cold regions

37.label: text
37.text: that have no habitation [also] are included within the inhabited quarter.

37.label: text
37.text: And the sphere of the earth is so large that it has been calculated by geometrical measurement that a mountain half a farsang in height, in proportion to the sphere of the earth, is an amount like the side of a barley grain that is divided into thirty-five parts, and if one part of it is placed on the surface of a sphere whose diameter is one girih, it is absolutely imperceptible that the sphere has lost its roundness.

37.label: text
37.text: Arshimīdis the sage measured the earth so that the measurement and size of the earth would become known, for without it the divisions of the celestial spheres and the size of the bodies of the sun and moon and other stars cannot be measured, and nothing can be known of them, and he found that

38.label: text
38.text: Each celestial degree amounts to twenty-two farsangs and one-seventh of a farsang, where one farsang equals three miles, one mile equals four thousand gaz, one gaz equals twenty-four fingers, and one finger equals six medium barley grains placed side by side. The scholars of Islam, in the time of the Caliph al-Maʾmūn, at his direction, in the desert of Sinjār—which is a plain with no mountains, rises, or depressions—faced the North Pole and measured the altitude of the star called al-Jadī with an instrument, and surveyed the earth, finding one celestial degree to be twenty-two farsangs and one-ninth of a farsang, which has a small difference from the measurement that the sage Archimedes made. Since each part of the earth corresponds to a part of the celestial sphere, and the celestial sphere is three hundred and sixty degrees, the earth must also be taken as three hundred and sixty degrees. When we multiplied by twenty-two farsangs and a fraction, it came to eight thousand farsangs, and this is the circumference of the terrestrial sphere. The diameter of the earth is two thousand five hundred and forty-five farsangs, and the total surface of the terrestrial sphere is twenty thousand thousand and three hundred and sixty square farsangs. The surface of the inhabited quarter from the equator to beneath the North Pole is five thousand thousand and ninety farsangs. The area of the Seven Climes with their seas, valleys, mountains, and deserts up to the complete obliquity, which is the limit of the world's habitation, is three thousand thousand seven hundred and fifty-six thousand four hundred and twenty farsangs. That which is outside the Seven Climes to the north, where there is no habitation, vegetation, or animal life, is one thousand thousand three hundred and thirty-three thousand five hundred and eighty farsangs. Since the length of the inhabited quarter is half of the terrestrial sphere, from the farthest east to the farthest west it is four thousand farsangs

38.label: text
38.text: 1 - In the original with "degree," the word "each" was added from the Russian manuscript. 2 Original: wādī. Corrected from the Russian manuscript.

39.label: text
39.text: Since in the inhabited quarter they observe that from the northern direction the pole of

39.label: text
39.text: the celestial equator is elevated, they call the inhabited quarter the northern horizons. And from the other side of the equator where the southern pole is visible [and] the northern pole is setting, they have found land and settlements to the extent of sixteen degrees, and that is outside the seven climes. The southern latitude of those places amounts to three hundred and fifty-six farsangs, and its length from east to west amounts to approximately four thousand farsangs.

39.label: text
39.text: The origin of the longitude of cities is taken from the beginning of the western settlements, which they call the Fortunate Islands (Jazīra Khālidāt), and in ancient times it was inhabited and now it is submerged. The sages of India take the beginning of longitude from the farthest east, a place they call Kangdiz. And the beginning of latitude is agreed upon from the equator, where day and night are always equal, and [around] ² the celestial sphere is biaxial, and in the oblique horizons, both northern and southern, the celestial sphere becomes like a shoulder-belt, and under the pole [it becomes millstone-like, and at the equator both poles are on the northern and southern horizon]. And we have divided the seven climes and whatever has southern latitude beyond the equator by two degrees of longitude and latitude, and we have drawn tables and written the names of some famous cities whose names we knew, so that it becomes known what relation each city has with another city and in what situation it is and in which clime it falls. And many of the cities are such that even we have not known them, for it has become known that approximately four thousand cities are in the regions and surroundings of Khitā and Khotan, and little of their names has reached us. And also each city has several towns, villages, and farmlands, and dependencies and annexes, the knowledge of which is not possible for anyone, except the dependencies of a city or places of a kingdom that can be known, which in relation to the inhabited quarter

39.label: text
39.text: 1- Original: zamīn ʿimārat. Corrected from the Russian manuscript. Added from the Russian manuscript.

39.label: text
39.text: The word "dawr" was added from the Russian manuscript. This section was added from the Russian manuscript.

40.label: text
40.text: it would be. By estimation we have determined that daily approximately five hundred and fifty thousand people must come into existence from non-existence and pass from existence into non-existence. If in a region of the inhabited quarter a plague or famine or massacre occurs and people perish without limit, when distributed across the entire world, it would be small. And also the celestial decree by the command of God Almighty is such that if in one region plague or massacre occurs, in another region there would be abundance and security, and never would any calamity be universal such that it reaches all the people of the world

40.label: text
40.text: except the Flood, which would be the Day of Resurrection.¹

40.label: text
40.text: The sages say that since the celestial equator circle with the circle of the ecliptic—which are two great circles of the starless sphere and the sphere of fixed stars—diverge from each other by twenty-three and a half degrees, from this proportion that some of the earth has emerged from the surrounding ocean and become exposed, it must be that another quarter opposite this quarter, whose horizons' latitudes are southern, should be inhabited. For if two circles are drawn, each having a center and intersecting at two opposite points, certainly inclination occurs from both sides. And since the inhabited quarter exists due to the inclination of the ecliptic from the celestial equator, another quarter must be inhabited and there must be another world. When it is day for us, it is night for them, and vice versa; when it is spring for us, it is autumn for them, and vice versa; our west is their east and vice versa. They say that once the king of the West, before the Fortunate Islands [جزایر خالدات] were submerged, conceived the desire to know what lies beyond this sea. He appointed several men to board a ship and sail forth to see where they would arrive and what they would see. When

40.label: text
40.text: 1. Manuscript "م" does not have the phrase "except the Flood, which would be the Day of Resurrection."

41.label: text
41.text: After several days they went on and saw another ship coming from that direction. They sailed close to each other and questioned one another, but neither side knew the other's language. Through context and gestures they made their story known—the objective of both was the same. So if this is true, it indicates that another quarter of the terrestrial globe is opposite this inhabited quarter, and our west is their east, and their east is closer to our west than other directions, and the sea distance would be less—wa Allāh aʿlam.

41.label: text
41.text: Now then, we said that every part of the parts of the earth corresponds to a part [of] the celestial sphere, and several thousand fixed stars that God Almighty created in the regions of the eighth sphere

41.label: text
41.text: each star of these passes over the zenith of some people and place, and the rotation of the spheres and the motion of the wandering and fixed stars appear in a different configuration at each place on earth. Thus each place on earth has a particular property, and the form, appearance, custom, way, language, and terminology of every people and nation differ. Due to their difference in relation to the celestial equator, it is possible that at every place on earth a total change may occur, such as ruin and prosperity, and the customs and conduct of people, and so forth. And the cause of change, by the command of God Most High, may be that a star whose passage is not at the zenith may come to pass at the zenith, or a star that rises and sets may become perpetually invisible, or a star that is perpetually invisible may come to rise and set. For example, Nasr Wāqiʿ (Vega), which at this time—the date being the year 748 from the Hijra of the Messenger—is rising and setting in the vicinity of Khurāsān and ʿIrāq. There may be a time

41.label: text
41.text: 1. Manuscript "M": that a star whose passage is at the zenith may have its passage fall away from the zenith, or a star whose passage is not at the zenith may come to the zenith. 2. Manuscript "M": "būd" instead of "uftad". This section was added from manuscript "M"

42.label: text
42.text: that it becomes perpetually visible, and at this time Nasr Wāqiʿ, which is in the sign of Capricorn, in Bulghār and the regions at the end of the sixth and seventh climes is completely perpetually visible, and like Banāt al-Naʿsh it does not rise and set. And when it reaches the sign of Aquarius, in Khurāsān and Ādharbāyjān the same condition will occur. And when it comes to the signs of Pisces and Aries, in ʿIrāq and Fārs and Kirmān it will also rise and set, and until the sign of Cancer, which is at one hundred [degrees], it becomes perpetually visible this way

42.label: text
42.text: down to the first clime. And when it reaches the beginning of Gemini until the end of the sign of Cancer, in Makka and Ḥijāz it was perpetually visible. Another is the star Suhayl, which at this date in Kirmān and Fārs is rising and setting. When approximately three thousand years pass from the Hijra of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, it will become perpetually hidden and cease to rise and set. And when such a sign occurs for a fixed star, a comprehensive condition will appear among that people and in that place, and several matters will undergo change, and the saying of the Most High: «ويتفكرون في خلق السمواتِ

42.label: text
42.text: والارض ربنا ما خلقت هذا باطلاً سُبْحَانَكَ فَقِنَا عَذَابَ النَّارِ»

42.label: text
42.text: Now then, they have divided the inhabited quarter into seven sections, and each section they call a clime. In the first and second climes there is no cold, and no one] has seen snow and ice

42.label: text
42.text: and in the sixth and seventh climes up to the limit of habitation, despite the long summer days, the air is neither hot nor pestilential. And if there is heat and cold in these four climes that we mentioned, it is relative to the climates of that place. And in the third, fifth, and fourth climes there are both hot lands and cold lands, and the form and appearance and capability and strength and manliness and valor and courage and management of livelihood and luxuries of the people were better and more than in these other three climes. Especially several cities that are in the middle of the longitude

42.label: text
42.text: 1 From here onward one line has fallen out of the Russian manuscript and does not appear in the photograph.

42.label: text
42.text: 2 The word "kas" was added here from the Russian manuscript

43.label: text
43.text: and around the سرة الأرض (Navel of the Earth), the peoples of these regions [were] of loftier ambition and fewer would place the yoke of servitude upon their necks, for the influence of planetary stars in the center of the inhabited quarter is greater and stronger. After that, in the western half in the third, fourth, and fifth climes, settlements and populations were proportionally greater than in other climes

43.label: text
43.text: and the people of the first clime due to heat and burning, and the people of the seventh clime due to cold and rawness, are of low ambition and beast-like nature and lacking in prudence, especially those born in the furthest eastern regions.

43.label: text
43.text: Among the special properties of the earth, one is that every emanation that descends from the rotation and movement of the celestial spheres and stars by the command of God Most High—"يدبر الأمر من السماء الى الارض" (He directs the affair from heaven to earth)—terminates at the earth, for the body of the earth is the center of the universe and the lowest of the four elements. Thus, according to the receptivity of each location, something different takes form, and since celestial configurations and positions are infinite, various compositions are also without limit. Indeed, the earth is the world of generation and corruption

43.label: text
43.text: And another property of the earth is that the four elements, which are simple, through the influence of the celestial spheres and stars by the command of God Most High, intermingle with each other on the surface of the earth. For if it were not so, no composition would take form and no temperaments would appear, and there is no pure earth, wind, water, or fire on the surface of the earth. [Rather,] whichever of the four elements one may conceive, particles of other elements are with it, for the absolutely simple does not have that form and nature. And if a form were required, it would be spherical, just as [if] a piece is thrown into the air, when it comes down it becomes round and spherical. For example, fire that

43.label: text
43.text: 1- The word "بوند" was added here from the Russian manuscript.

43.label: text
43.text: does not have "زمین". 3- The word "بلکه" was added from the Russian manuscript.

43.label: text
43.text: "اگر" was added from the Russian manuscript.

44.label: text
44.text: flames on the surface of the earth, and its place is earthy particles, and its color is airy, and its tongue is fiery. When a piece of paper is held over the tip of the flame, the heat of that fire sets it in motion]. Furthermore, air that freezes and becomes harder and firmer than what is possible to freeze—if a little warmth did not remain in it, all would become ice of one hardness. And if the four elements did not mix with one another and did not break each other's temperament so that the fifth temperament would emerge, no composition would take

44.label: text
44.text: And the belief of the ancient sages is that when God Most High created the celestial and terrestrial worlds, He entrusted the terrestrial beings to the celestial ones and left them to them, for God Most High is [transcendent and] the Cause of all causes. As He said: «وبنينا فوقكم سبعا شدادا وجعلنا سراجاً وهاجاً وآخر لنا من المعصرات ماء فجاجا لتخرج به حبا ونباتا وجنات الفافا».

44.label: text
44.text: As for what lies beyond, the truly pure simple element exists outside the surface of the earth at a complete distance, and every simple part of the elements, spheres, and stars that is farther from the surface of the earth is stronger in simplicity. Just as the sphere of fire, which is three degrees farther from the surface of the earth, has greater power of simplicity, for whatever reaches it is immediately burned. And it is also from this meaning that the fire on the surface of the earth, despite having a temperament mixed with other elements, whatever comes into contact with it quickly becomes hot or is burned, unlike water and air [for if] something is placed in water and air, over the course of time it becomes like them. And the water of the Encompassing Sea, which has descended from the surface of the earth, is purely simple, and no creature takes form in it. That is, simple bodies, the farther from the surface of the earth

44.label: text
44.text: 1- This section was added from the Russian manuscript. 2- The original and Paris manuscript have «گشت»; corrected according to the Russian manuscript.

45.label: text
45.text: the farther away they are, the stronger their power in simplicity becomes. For example, the philosophers have determined through experience that when the planetary stars are at perigee, their influence becomes weak, whereas since the ray of starlight is effective on earth, they should have become stronger because they have come closer to the earth by the measure of the diameter of the eccentric sphere and epicycle, which is the world of compounds.

45.label: text
